A group of rogue wizards, calling themselves the Illuminators, believed that the time had come for the magical and non-magical worlds to merge. They had been performing increasingly bold magical acts in public, risking exposure of our entire society.

Our classes took on a new intensity. In Defense Against the Dark Arts, we learned advanced shielding charms and how to cast spells silently. Potions class focused on brewing concealments and antidotes. Even Herbology took on a more practical bent, as we studied plants that could be used for camouflage or quick escapes.

Despite the tense atmosphere, or perhaps because of it, I found myself thriving. The challenge of learning more advanced magic pushed me to work harder than ever before. My confidence grew with each successful spell, each correctly brewed potion.

One day, as we practiced dueling in Defense Against the Dark Arts, Professor Thorne pulled me aside. "Miss Clarke," he said, his voice low, "I've been impressed with your progress this year. I think you might be ready for some extra training."

And so began my secret lessons with Professor Thorne. Twice a week, after dinner, I would slip away to an unused classroom where he taught me spells far beyond the second-year curriculum. It was exhilarating and exhausting in equal measure.

As the year progressed, news from the outside world grew more alarming. The Illuminators were growing bolder, and there had been several near-misses where magic was almost exposed to the non-magical world. The Ministry of Magic seemed to be struggling to contain the situation.

Then, just before the Christmas holidays, disaster struck. The Illuminators managed to hijack a major television broadcast, using it to perform magic in front of millions of viewers. The magical world was thrown into chaos as we scrambled to contain the fallout.

At Arcanum Academy, tensions reached a fever pitch. Some students were pulled out of school by worried parents. Those of us who remained spent our days in a state of constant vigilance, jumping at every unexpected sound.

It was during this time that I had a breakthrough in my private lessons with Professor Thorne. We had been working on the Patronus Charm, an incredibly advanced spell used to repel dark creatures and send messages. For weeks, I had only managed to produce a faint silver mist. But that night, fueled by my determination to protect the world I had come to love, I finally succeeded.

A brilliant silver fox burst from the tip of my wand, prancing around the room before dissolving into sparks. Professor Thorne was ecstatic. "Exceptional, Miss Clarke!" he exclaimed. "A corporeal Patronus at your age... truly remarkable."

That small victory gave me a renewed sense of hope. If I could master such difficult magic, then surely we could find a way to resolve this crisis.

As we returned from the Christmas holidays, Headmistress Blackwood called an assembly. Her face was grave as she addressed us.

"The situation has escalated," she said. "The Illuminators are planning something big, something that could irrevocably expose our world. The Ministry has asked for our help."

She went on to explain that a team of Aurors (magical law enforcement) would be coming to Arcanum Academy to set up a base of operations. And, to our shock, they wanted to recruit some of the older students to assist in their efforts.

"This is, of course, entirely voluntary," Headmistress Blackwood assured us. "But for those of you who wish to help, this is your chance to make a real difference in protecting our world."

Without hesitation, I volunteered. So did Alex, Lily, and Marcus. We were among the youngest to do so, but our actions during the temporal crisis the previous year had earned us a reputation for being capable beyond our years.

The next few months were a blur of intensive training alongside our regular classes. We learned advanced defensive spells, practiced working as a team, and studied the Illuminators' tactics. It was exhausting, but exhilarating. For the first time, I felt like I was truly part of something bigger than myself.

As the school year drew to a close, we received intelligence that the Illuminators were planning their biggest stunt yet ‚Äì a massive magical display in the heart of London. If they succeeded, there would be no way to obliviate or misdirect so many witnesses. The magical world would be exposed forever.

The night before the planned event, our team gathered in the Great Hall. The atmosphere was tense as the Aurors briefed us on the plan. We would be split into small groups, each tasked with neutralizing a specific threat.

As I looked around at my fellow students, I saw determination mixed with fear on their faces. We were young, yes, but we were also powerful witches and wizards, trained for this very purpose.

The next morning, we were portkeyed to various locations around London. My team, consisting of myself, Alex, and two seventh-year students, was positioned near the London Eye. Our job was to prevent the Illuminators from using the famous landmark as part of their display.

For hours, we waited, our nerves stretched to breaking point. Then, just as the sun was setting, it began. The sky lit up with impossible colors, buildings began to float, and in the distance, we could hear the sound of dragons roaring.

We sprang into action. As Illuminators appeared, attempting to enchant the London Eye, we met them spell for spell. The air crackled with magical energy as curses and counter-curses flew back and forth.

I found myself dueling a witch twice my age, but all my training kicked in. I cast shield charms, fired off stunning spells, and even managed to use my Patronus to momentarily blind my opponent. 

Across the city, similar battles were taking place. Aurors and students working together to contain the chaos and protect the statute of secrecy. It was the largest magical conflict in recent history, all hidden from the eyes of the oblivious Muggles around us.

As the night wore on, we began to gain the upper hand. The Illuminators, for all their grand plans, hadn't expected such fierce resistance. One by one, they were captured or forced to retreat.

Finally, as dawn broke over the city, it was over. We had won. The magical world remained a secret, though it had come perilously close to exposure.

In the days that followed, as we returned to Arcanum Academy, the full scale of what we had accomplished began to sink in. We had faced a threat to our entire way of life, and we had prevailed. 

At the end-of-year feast, Headmistress Blackwood stood to address us one last time. "This year has tested us all," she said, her voice filled with emotion. "But you have risen to the challenge magnificently. Each and every one of you has played a part in protecting our world. You should be immensely proud of yourselves."

As I sat there, surrounded by my friends and fellow students, I felt a profound sense of belonging. This was my world now, with all its wonders and dangers. And I was ready to face whatever challenges the future might bring.

As the train carried us away from Arcanum Academy for the summer, I reflected on how much had changed in just two years. I had arrived as a novice, unsure of my place in this magical world. Now, I left as a witch who had helped save that world from exposure.

But more than that, I had found my purpose. The events of the past year had shown me the importance of what we were learning, the responsibility that came with our magical abilities. As I watched the castle disappear into the distance, I made a silent promise to myself. I would continue to learn, to grow, to push the boundaries of what was possible with magic. Because now I knew ‚Äì the magical world was my home, and I would do whatever it took to protect it.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A dead body is the library floor. The window is wide open and a breeze is moving the curtains. The globe is broken next to the body. A copy of the Bible is placed on the back of the body.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 4000 words.
response:
Here's a screenplay based on the given writing prompt and requirements:

INT. CITY LIBRARY - NIGHT

The grand, ornate interior of a historic city library is dimly lit by scattered desk lamps. Towering bookshelves cast long shadows across the polished marble floor. A large, antique globe stands prominently near the center of the room.

Detective SARAH PARKER (mid-30s, sharp-eyed, no-nonsense) enters, followed by her partner, Detective MIKE REYNOLDS (early 40s, rugged, world-weary). They approach the crime scene, where a body lies face-down on the floor.

OFFICER JENKINS (late 20s, eager rookie) greets them, looking slightly pale.

JENKINS
Detectives, glad you're here. It's a strange one.

Sarah kneels beside the body, her eyes scanning the scene methodically.

SARAH
What do we know so far?

JENKINS
Victim is Dr. Edward Blackwood, head librarian. 
Night security found him about an hour ago.

Mike walks over to the open window, watching the curtains billow in the breeze.

MIKE
Any signs of forced entry?

JENKINS
None that we could find, sir.

Sarah's gaze falls on the broken globe near the body.

SARAH
What's the deal with the globe?

JENKINS
(nervously)
We're not sure. It was like that when we arrived.

Sarah stands, her brow furrowed.

SARAH
And the Bible?

JENKINS
(hesitating)
That's the strangest part. It was placed on 
the victim's back. We haven't touched it.

Mike rejoins the group, his expression grim.

MIKE
This is no ordinary break-in gone wrong.

SARAH
(nodding)
Agreed. This has all the hallmarks of a 
staged crime scene.

Sarah turns to Jenkins.

SARAH (CONT'D)
I want a full sweep of the building. Check 
every nook and cranny. And get me the security 
footage from tonight.

JENKINS
Yes, ma'am.

Jenkins hurries off. Sarah and Mike exchange a look.

MIKE
What are you thinking?

SARAH
I'm thinking we've got a long night ahead of us.

As they begin their investigation, we:

FADE TO:

INT. LIBRARY - LATER THAT NIGHT

The crime scene is now bustling with activity. Forensic technicians photograph and collect evidence while uniformed officers secure the perimeter.

Sarah stands at a distance, observing the scene. Mike approaches, holding a tablet.

MIKE
Got something you might want to see.

He hands her the tablet, which shows security camera footage.

ON THE TABLET: Dr. Blackwood is seen working late, alone in the library. Suddenly, a hooded figure enters the frame.

SARAH
(frowning)
How did they get in?

MIKE
That's the thing. According to the logs, no 
one entered or exited the building after 
hours except for the security guard who 
found the body.

Sarah looks up, her eyes narrowing.

SARAH
So either our killer has a key...

MIKE
(finishing her thought)
Or they never left.

Just then, Jenkins rushes over, looking excited.

JENKINS
Detectives! We found something.

Sarah and Mike follow Jenkins to a nearby bookshelf. He points to a small, hidden camera.

JENKINS (CONT'D)
It's not part of the library's security system.

Sarah leans in for a closer look.

SARAH
Good catch, Jenkins. Let's get this to tech 
and see what it captured.

As Jenkins carefully removes the camera, Sarah turns to Mike.

SARAH (CONT'D)
I want to talk to the security guard who 
found the body. Something doesn't add up.

MIKE
I'll bring him in.

CUT TO:

INT. LIBRARY OFFICE - NIGHT

Sarah sits across from CARL SIMMONS (50s, heavyset, nervous), the night security guard.

SARAH
Walk me through what happened, Mr. Simmons.

CARL
(fidgeting)
Like I told the other officers, I was doing 
my usual rounds when I found Dr. Blackwood.

SARAH
And you're sure you didn't see or hear 
anything unusual earlier in the evening?

CARL
(hesitating)
Well... there was one thing.

Sarah leans forward, her interest piqued.

SARAH
Go on.

CARL
I heard voices coming from Dr. Blackwood's 
office. It sounded like an argument.

SARAH
Did you recognize the other voice?

CARL
(shaking his head)
No, but it was definitely a woman.

Sarah makes a note in her notebook.

SARAH
What time was this?

CARL
Around 9:30, I think.

SARAH
And you didn't think to mention this earlier 
because...?

CARL
(stammering)
I... I didn't think it was important. Dr. 
Blackwood often had late meetings.

Sarah studies Carl for a moment, her expression unreadable.

SARAH
Thank you, Mr. Simmons. We may have more 
questions for you later.

As Carl leaves, Mike enters the office.

MIKE
How'd it go?

SARAH
Our security guard conveniently forgot to 
mention hearing an argument earlier in the 
evening.

MIKE
(raising an eyebrow)
That so?

SARAH
Yeah. A woman's voice. Any luck with the 
hidden camera?

MIKE
Tech's working on it now. Should have 
something soon.

Sarah stands, stretching.

SARAH
Alright. Let's head back to the station and 
start digging into Dr. Blackwood's background. 
I want to know everything about him.

CUT TO:

INT. POLICE STATION - MORNING

Sarah and Mike are at their desks, surrounded by papers and empty coffee cups. The wall behind them is covered with photos and notes about the case.

MIKE
(rubbing his eyes)
So, what do we know about our victim?

SARAH
Dr. Edward Blackwood, 55. Head librarian for 
the past decade. Respected in his field, 
published several papers on rare books and 
manuscripts.

MIKE
Doesn't sound like the type to have enemies.

SARAH
You'd be surprised. I found some interesting 
chatter in academic forums. Apparently, Dr. 
Blackwood was involved in a heated dispute 
over the authenticity of a recently 
discovered ancient text.

MIKE
(interested)
What kind of text?

SARAH
A supposedly lost gospel. If authenticated, 
it could be worth millions.

Before Mike can respond, their captain, JAMES HARPER (60s, stern but fair), approaches.

HARPER
Parker, Reynolds. My office, now.

Sarah and Mike exchange a glance before following Harper.

INT. CAPTAIN'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

Harper sits behind his desk, looking grave.

HARPER
I just got off the phone with the Mayor. 
This case is drawing a lot of attention.

SARAH
(frowning)
Why? It's a homicide, not a political scandal.

HARPER
Apparently, Dr. Blackwood was more than just 
a librarian. He was also the curator of a 
highly valuable collection of religious 
texts owned by the city.

MIKE
Let me guess. One of those texts is missing?

HARPER
(nodding)
A rare illuminated Bible, dating back to the 
15th century. Worth several million dollars.

SARAH
(thoughtful)
That might explain the Bible placed on the 
victim's back. A message, perhaps?

HARPER
Whatever it is, I need this solved quickly 
and quietly. The press is already sniffing 
around.

SARAH
We'll do our best, Captain.

As they leave the office, Sarah turns to Mike.

SARAH (CONT'D)
I think it's time we paid a visit to Dr. 
Blackwood's academic rivals.

CUT TO:

EXT. UNIVERSITY CAMPUS - DAY

Sarah and Mike walk across a bustling college green, approaching an imposing stone building.

MIKE
So, who are we meeting?

SARAH
Dr. Elizabeth Winters. She's the head of the 
Religious Studies department and was one of 
Dr. Blackwood's most vocal critics.

They enter the building and make their way to an office.

INT. DR. WINTERS' OFFICE - DAY

DR. ELIZABETH WINTERS (late 40s, elegant, intimidating) sits behind a large desk, eyeing Sarah and Mike warily.

DR. WINTERS
Detectives, how can I help you?

SARAH
We're investigating the death of Dr. Edward 
Blackwood. We understand you two had some... 
professional disagreements.

DR. WINTERS
(stiffening)
If you're implying that I had something to 
do with Edward's death, you're barking up 
the wrong tree.

MIKE
We're not implying anything, Dr. Winters. 
We're just trying to understand the situation.

DR. WINTERS
(sighing)
Edward and I disagreed on the authenticity 
of a recently discovered text. It's not 
unusual in our field.

SARAH
This wouldn't happen to be the lost gospel 
you were both studying?

DR. WINTERS
(surprised)
You know about that?

SARAH
We do our homework, Doctor. Can you tell us 
more about this text?

DR. WINTERS
It's potentially groundbreaking. If authentic, 
it could challenge some fundamental 
Christian beliefs.

MIKE
Sounds controversial.

DR. WINTERS
(nodding)
Extremely. That's why authentication is so 
crucial. Edward believed it was genuine. I... 
had my doubts.

SARAH
And now?

DR. WINTERS
(hesitating)
I... I'm not sure. Edward was brilliant, but 
he could be... overzealous at times.

SARAH
Where were you last night between 9 and 11 PM?

DR. WINTERS
(frowning)
I was here, grading papers. My assistant can 
confirm that.

SARAH
We'll need to speak with them.

As they stand to leave, Sarah notices a book on Dr. Winters' desk.

SARAH (CONT'D)
That's an interesting Bible you have there.

DR. WINTERS
(smiling)
Good eye, Detective. It's a replica of the 
Gutenberg Bible. A gift from Edward, actually.

Sarah and Mike exchange a look.

MIKE
Thank you for your time, Dr. Winters. We'll 
be in touch.

As they leave the office, Sarah pulls Mike aside.

SARAH
(whispering)
Did you notice how she referred to Dr. 
Blackwood as Edward?

MIKE
(nodding)
Yeah, seemed pretty familiar for academic rivals.

SARAH
My thoughts exactly. Let's dig deeper into 
their relationship.

CUT TO:

INT. POLICE STATION - EVENING

Sarah and Mike are back at their desks, surrounded by even more papers than before.

MIKE
(frustrated)
We've been at this for hours. What are we 
missing?

SARAH
(thoughtful)
We're focusing too much on the academic 
angle. What if this isn't about the lost 
gospel at all?

MIKE
What do you mean?

SARAH
The staged crime scene, the missing Bible... 
It feels like someone's trying to lead us 
down a specific path.

Before Mike can respond, a young tech analyst, ALEX (mid-20s, energetic), rushes over.

ALEX
Detectives! We've got something from the 
hidden camera.

They gather around Alex's computer.

ON THE SCREEN: Grainy footage shows Dr. Blackwood arguing with a woman. Her face is obscured, but she's gesturing angrily.

SARAH
Can you enhance the image?

ALEX
(typing furiously)
I'll try, but the quality isn't great.

As they watch, the woman suddenly grabs the globe and swings it at Dr. Blackwood. He falls, and she kneels beside him, clearly distressed.

MIKE
Well, that explains the broken globe.

SARAH
(leaning closer)
Wait, freeze it there!

Alex pauses the video. Sarah points to the woman's wrist.

SARAH (CONT'D)
That bracelet. I've seen it before.

MIKE
(realizing)
Dr. Winters was wearing one just like it.

Sarah grabs her jacket.

SARAH
Let's go. We need to have another chat with 
Dr. Winters.

CUT TO:

EXT. DR. WINTERS' HOUSE - NIGHT

Sarah and Mike approach a modest suburban home. They knock on the door, but there's no answer.

MIKE
(peering through a window)
Lights are on, but I don't see anyone.

Suddenly, they hear a crash from inside.

SARAH
(drawing her gun)
Police! Open up!

When there's no response, Sarah nods to Mike. He kicks in the door, and they enter.

INT. DR. WINTERS' HOUSE - CONTINUOUS

They move cautiously through the house, guns drawn. As they enter the study, they find Dr. Winters frantically shoving papers into a briefcase.

SARAH
Freeze! Hands where we can see them!

Dr. Winters slowly raises her hands, looking defeated.

DR. WINTERS
(softly)
I never meant for any of this to happen.

MIKE
(handcuffing her)
Dr. Elizabeth Winters, you're under arrest 
for the murder of Dr. Edward Blackwood.

As Mike reads her rights, Sarah notices an open safe in the corner. Inside is an ornate, ancient-looking Bible.

SARAH
I think we just found our missing Bible.

CUT TO:

INT. INTERROGATION ROOM - LATER

Sarah sits across from Dr. Winters, who looks pale and tired.

SARAH
Why don't you tell us what really happened, 
Elizabeth?

DR. WINTERS
(sighing)
Edward and I... we were more than colleagues. 
We'd been having an affair for years.

SARAH
(nodding)
We suspected as much. What went wrong?

DR. WINTERS
The lost gospel. Edward was convinced it was 
authentic, but I had proof it was a forgery.

SARAH
And that led to the argument we saw on the 
hidden camera?

DR. WINTERS
(nodding)
Yes. I confronted him about it. He... he 
admitted that he had forged the text himself.

SARAH
(surprised)
Why would he do that?

DR. WINTERS
For the fame, the recognition. He was 
obsessed with making a groundbreaking 
discovery.

SARAH
So you confronted him, things got heated, 
and you hit him with the globe.

DR. WINTERS
(tearing up)
It was an accident. I never meant to kill him.

SARAH
But you did stage the crime scene.

DR. WINTERS
(nodding)
I panicked. I thought if I made it look like 
a robbery gone wrong, no one would suspect me.

SARAH
And the Bible on his back?

DR. WINTERS
(bitter)
A reminder of his betrayal. Of how he 
corrupted everything we believed in.

Sarah stands, gathering her notes.

SARAH
Thank you for your honesty, Dr. Winters. 
We'll need a full statement.

As Sarah leaves the room, Mike is waiting outside.

MIKE
So, case closed?

SARAH
(nodding)
Looks like it. Crime of passion, not the 
elaborate conspiracy we thought.

MIKE
(smiling)
Sometimes the simplest explanation is the 
right one.

SARAH
(thoughtful)
True. But it's never simple when it comes to 
matters of faith and love.

They walk away, the case solved but the weight of its implications still heavy in the air.

FADE OUT.

THE END

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A woman sits on the edge of a bridge. A man slowly approaches her and talks to her in a low and soothing voice. She responds to his attempt to establish communication. They start talking, and the woman starts crying. He helps her get up. She moves away from the edge while holding the stranger's hand.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 4000 words.
response:
EXT. CITY BRIDGE - NIGHT

The city skyline glimmers in the distance, a stark contrast to the dark, murky waters below. A lone figure, SARAH (30s, disheveled appearance), sits precariously on the edge of the bridge railing. Her legs dangle over the side, swaying slightly in the cool night breeze.

A man, DAVID (40s, kind eyes, casual attire), walks along the pedestrian path of the bridge. He notices Sarah and slows his pace, approaching cautiously.

DAVID
(softly)
Excuse me, miss? Are you alright?

Sarah doesn't respond, her gaze fixed on the water below.

David takes a few steps closer, maintaining a respectful distance.

DAVID (CONT'D)
It's a bit chilly out here tonight, isn't it?

Sarah turns her head slightly, acknowledging David's presence but not making eye contact.

SARAH
(voice barely audible)
I suppose it is.

David leans against the railing, a few feet away from Sarah.

DAVID
I'm David. I hope you don't mind me stopping to chat for a bit.

Sarah shrugs, her eyes still cast downward.

SARAH
(quietly)
I'm Sarah.

DAVID
It's nice to meet you, Sarah. Do you come here often?

Sarah lets out a bitter laugh.

SARAH
No, this is my first time.

David nods, his expression empathetic.

DAVID
I see. Well, I come here sometimes when I need to clear my head. The view can be quite calming.

Sarah finally turns to look at David, her eyes filled with a mix of pain and curiosity.

SARAH
Is that why you're here tonight?

David smiles softly.

DAVID
Actually, I was on my way home from work. I'm a counselor at a community center nearby.

Sarah's eyes widen slightly, and she turns away again.

SARAH
(defensively)
I don't need counseling.

DAVID
(gently)
I didn't say you did. I'm just making conversation.

A moment of silence passes between them.

DAVID (CONT'D)
You know, I've always wondered what it would be like to fly.

Sarah looks at him, confused.

SARAH
What?

DAVID
(gesturing to the skyline)
Looking at all those tall buildings, I sometimes imagine what it would be like to soar between them, free as a bird.

Sarah's expression softens slightly.

SARAH
That... that does sound nice.

DAVID
Have you ever had dreams like that? Where you're flying?

Sarah nods, a ghost of a smile on her lips.

SARAH
When I was little. I used to dream I could fly over my neighborhood, watching all the people below.

DAVID
(smiling)
That sounds wonderful. What else did you dream about as a child?

Sarah's eyes grow distant, lost in memory.

SARAH
I wanted to be an artist. I would spend hours drawing and painting.

DAVID
Are you still painting?

Sarah's face falls, and she shakes her head.

SARAH
(voice breaking)
No, I... I haven't picked up a brush in years.

David takes a small step closer, his voice gentle.

DAVID
What happened, Sarah?

Sarah's eyes fill with tears, and her shoulders begin to shake.

SARAH
(sobbing)
Everything fell apart. I lost my job, my apartment... my family doesn't want anything to do with me. I'm all alone.

David reaches out slowly, offering his hand.

DAVID
You're not alone right now, Sarah. I'm here, and I'm listening.

Sarah looks at David's outstretched hand, hesitating.

SARAH
(through tears)
Why do you care? You don't even know me.

DAVID
Because every life has value, Sarah. Including yours.

Sarah's tears flow freely now as she reaches for David's hand.

DAVID (CONT'D)
That's it. Let's move away from the edge, okay?

Sarah nods, allowing David to help her off the railing and onto solid ground. She stumbles slightly, and David steadies her.

DAVID (CONT'D)
Easy now. You're safe.

Sarah clings to David's hand, her body shaking with sobs.

SARAH
I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.

DAVID
(soothingly)
You have nothing to be sorry for. You're incredibly brave for reaching out.

Sarah looks up at David, her eyes red and puffy.

SARAH
What do I do now?

DAVID
Now, we get you somewhere warm and safe. Would you be willing to come with me to the community center? We have people there who can help.

Sarah hesitates, fear flickering across her face.

SARAH
I don't know...

DAVID
It's okay to be scared. But remember, you've already taken the hardest step by choosing to stay.

Sarah takes a deep breath and nods.

SARAH
Okay. I'll go.

David smiles warmly, still holding Sarah's hand.

DAVID
I'm proud of you, Sarah. Let's take this one step at a time.

They begin to walk slowly away from the bridge's edge, towards the city lights.

FADE TO:

INT. COMMUNITY CENTER - NIGHT

David leads Sarah through the doors of a welcoming, well-lit building. The walls are adorned with colorful artwork and motivational posters. A few people mill about, some in uniforms, others in casual clothes.

RECEPTIONIST
(concerned)
David? Is everything alright?

DAVID
(calmly)
Everything's okay, Lisa. This is Sarah. She needs some help tonight.

LISA (50s, warm smile) nods understandingly.

LISA
Of course. I'll call Dr. Martinez right away.

Sarah tightens her grip on David's hand, looking nervous.

SARAH
(whispering)
I don't know if I can do this.

DAVID
(reassuringly)
You can. And you're not alone. I'll stay with you if you'd like.

Sarah nods gratefully.

SARAH
Please.

David guides Sarah to a comfortable seating area.

DAVID
Let's sit down while we wait. Can I get you some water?

SARAH
(nodding)
Yes, please.

David goes to a nearby water cooler, filling a cup. He returns and hands it to Sarah, who takes it with shaky hands.

SARAH (CONT'D)
Thank you.

DAVID
You're welcome. Sarah, I want you to know that coming here was a big step. You're showing incredible strength.

Sarah takes a sip of water, her eyes downcast.

SARAH
I don't feel strong. I feel... broken.

DAVID
Feeling broken doesn't mean you're not strong. It takes courage to admit when we need help.

Sarah looks up at David, her eyes searching his face.

SARAH
How did you become a counselor?

David leans back, a thoughtful expression on his face.

DAVID
It's a long story, but the short version is that I was once where you are now.

Sarah's eyes widen in surprise.

SARAH
You were?

DAVID
(nodding)
About fifteen years ago. I hit rock bottom, lost everything. I thought my life was over.

SARAH
What happened?

DAVID
Someone reached out to me, just like I reached out to you tonight. They showed me that there was still hope, even when I couldn't see it myself.

Sarah's expression softens, a glimmer of hope in her eyes.

SARAH
And now you do the same for others?

DAVID
(smiling)
I try. Everyone deserves a chance to rediscover their worth.

At that moment, DR. MARTINEZ (60s, kind face, professional demeanor) approaches.

DR. MARTINEZ
Hello, I'm Dr. Martinez. You must be Sarah.

Sarah nods, looking apprehensive.

SARAH
Yes, that's me.

DR. MARTINEZ
(warmly)
It's nice to meet you, Sarah. David, thank you for bringing her in.

DAVID
Of course. Sarah, would you like me to stay with you?

Sarah looks between David and Dr. Martinez, considering.

SARAH
(to David)
I think... I think I'll be okay. Thank you for everything.

David stands, giving Sarah's shoulder a gentle squeeze.

DAVID
You're welcome. Remember, Sarah, you're not alone. We're here to support you.

Sarah manages a small smile.

SARAH
Thank you, David. I won't forget what you did for me tonight.

Dr. Martinez gestures towards a hallway.

DR. MARTINEZ
Shall we go to my office, Sarah? We can talk in private there.

Sarah nods, standing up. She takes a deep breath, squaring her shoulders.

SARAH
I'm ready.

As Sarah follows Dr. Martinez down the hallway, she turns back to give David one last grateful look. David smiles encouragingly, watching as they disappear around a corner.

FADE TO:

INT. COMMUNITY CENTER - DAVID'S OFFICE - DAY (THREE MONTHS LATER)

David sits at his desk, reviewing some paperwork. There's a knock at the door.

DAVID
Come in!

The door opens, revealing Sarah. She looks healthier, more put-together than when we last saw her.

SARAH
(smiling)
Hi, David.

DAVID
(standing, pleasantly surprised)
Sarah! It's great to see you. Please, come in.

Sarah enters the office, closing the door behind her. She's carrying a small, wrapped package.

SARAH
I hope I'm not interrupting anything.

DAVID
Not at all. How have you been?

SARAH
(sitting down)
I've been doing better. Much better, actually. Dr. Martinez has been incredibly helpful.

DAVID
(sitting across from her)
I'm so glad to hear that. You look well.

SARAH
(nodding)
I feel well. For the first time in a long time, I feel... hopeful.

DAVID
That's wonderful, Sarah. You should be proud of yourself.

SARAH
(smiling)
I am. And I wanted to thank you. If it wasn't for you that night on the bridge...

She trails off, emotion filling her voice. David leans forward, his expression kind.

DAVID
You're the one who made the choice to stay, Sarah. I just happened to be there to remind you of your strength.

SARAH
(wiping away a tear)
Well, I'm grateful you were. And I wanted to give you something.

She hands David the wrapped package. He takes it, looking touched.

DAVID
Sarah, you didn't have to-

SARAH
(interrupting gently)
I wanted to. Please, open it.

David carefully unwraps the package, revealing a small, beautifully painted canvas. It shows a bridge at night, with two figures standing together, looking out at a city skyline.

DAVID
(in awe)
Sarah, this is beautiful. Did you paint this?

Sarah nods, smiling shyly.

SARAH
I started painting again. It's been... therapeutic.

DAVID
(examining the painting)
The detail is incredible. You're very talented.

SARAH
Thank you. I wanted you to have it as a reminder of that night. Of how one person can make a difference.

David looks up from the painting, his eyes meeting Sarah's.

DAVID
I'll treasure it, Sarah. Thank you.

SARAH
(standing)
I should go. I have an art class to get to.

DAVID
(standing as well)
That's fantastic. I'm so happy you're pursuing your passion again.

They walk to the door together.

SARAH
(turning to face David)
I just wanted you to know that what you did... it mattered. You saved my life that night.

DAVID
(touched)
You saved your own life, Sarah. I'm just glad I could help you see that it was worth saving.

Sarah impulsively hugs David. He returns the embrace, patting her back gently.

SARAH
(stepping back)
Thank you, David. For everything.

DAVID
(smiling)
You're welcome, Sarah. Take care of yourself.

SARAH
I will. Goodbye, David.

Sarah exits the office. David watches her go, then turns back to look at the painting. He picks it up, studying it with a warm smile before hanging it on his office wall.

FADE TO:

EXT. CITY BRIDGE - NIGHT

The same bridge from the opening scene. David walks along the pedestrian path, his hands in his pockets. He stops at the spot where he first saw Sarah, looking out at the city skyline.

A young man, MICHAEL (20s, troubled expression), leans against the railing, staring down at the water. David notices him and approaches slowly.

DAVID
(softly)
Beautiful view, isn't it?

Michael looks up, startled.

MICHAEL
(warily)
Yeah, I guess.

DAVID
(leaning on the railing nearby)
I'm David. Do you mind if I enjoy the view with you for a bit?

Michael shrugs, turning back to the water.

MICHAEL
Free country.

David nods, looking out at the city lights.

DAVID
You know, I've always wondered what it would be like to fly...

As David begins to engage Michael in conversation, we pan out to see the entire bridge, two figures standing together against the backdrop of the glittering city.

FADE OUT.

THE END

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A person is in his study. The shelves are stacked with books, old maps, and globes. The person is writing on a parchment using his quill. He seems apprehensive. He takes a small knife he uses for opening his letters and he runs the tip of the blade through the candle flame. Then, he makes a small cut and a few blood drops fall on the table. He dips the quill in the blood and as he gets prepared to sign his name at the bottom of the page, black letters spontaneously appear on his arm.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 4000 words.
response:
INT. STUDY - NIGHT

A dimly lit, opulent study filled with floor-to-ceiling bookshelves. Ancient tomes, yellowed maps, and antique globes occupy every available space. The air is thick with the scent of old parchment and burning candles.

THOMAS BLACKWOOD (45), a distinguished man with graying temples and piercing blue eyes, sits at an ornate mahogany desk. His quill scratches across a piece of parchment, the sound echoing in the silent room. Thomas's brow furrows as he writes, his expression a mix of determination and apprehension.

He pauses, lifting the quill from the parchment. His eyes dart to a small, ornate knife resting beside an inkwell. Thomas reaches for it with a trembling hand.

THOMAS
(whispering to himself)
Is this truly the only way?

He takes a deep breath, steeling himself. Thomas holds the knife's blade over a flickering candle flame, watching as it heats to a dull red glow.

With a sharp intake of breath, he presses the heated blade to his palm. A thin line of blood wells up, and Thomas tilts his hand, allowing a few drops to fall onto the parchment.

As he dips the quill into the crimson pool, a chill runs down his spine. Just as he's about to sign his name, black letters begin to materialize on his forearm, as if written by an invisible hand.

Thomas gasps, dropping the quill. He pushes back his chair, staring in horror at the words forming on his skin.

THOMAS (CONT'D)
(reading aloud)
"The price of knowledge is steep, Thomas Blackwood. Are you prepared to pay it?"

A knock at the study door startles Thomas. He quickly rolls down his sleeve, covering the mysterious writing.

THOMAS (CONT'D)
Come in.

The door creaks open, revealing ELIZABETH BLACKWOOD (40), Thomas's wife. She's a striking woman with long, dark hair and worried eyes.

ELIZABETH
Thomas, darling, it's late. Are you coming to bed?

Thomas hesitates, glancing at the parchment on his desk.

THOMAS
I... I'll be there shortly, my dear. Just finishing up some work.

Elizabeth steps into the study, her eyes scanning the room. She notices the knife on the desk and frowns.

ELIZABETH
What are you working on that requires a blade, Thomas?

Thomas quickly moves to block her view of the desk.

THOMAS
Nothing of importance, Elizabeth. Just... opening some letters.

Elizabeth's eyes narrow, unconvinced.

ELIZABETH
You've been spending more and more time in here lately. Is everything alright?

THOMAS
(forcing a smile)
Of course, my love. I've simply been engrossed in my research. You know how I can get when I'm on the verge of a breakthrough.

Elizabeth steps closer, placing a hand on Thomas's arm. He flinches involuntarily.

ELIZABETH
(concerned)
Thomas, you're trembling. What's going on?

Thomas takes Elizabeth's hand in his, careful to keep his palm hidden.

THOMAS
I'm fine, truly. Just a bit tired. Why don't you go on up to bed? I'll join you shortly.

Elizabeth hesitates, then nods reluctantly.

ELIZABETH
Don't be too long. You know I can't sleep without you beside me.

She kisses Thomas on the cheek and exits the study. As soon as the door closes, Thomas slumps against his desk, exhaling heavily.

He rolls up his sleeve, revealing the black letters once more. They seem to shimmer in the candlelight, as if alive.

THOMAS
(whispering)
What have I gotten myself into?

FADE TO BLACK

FADE IN:

INT. STUDY - MORNING

Sunlight streams through the study windows, illuminating dust motes dancing in the air. Thomas is slumped over his desk, having fallen asleep there during the night.

A gentle hand on his shoulder rouses him. Thomas jerks awake, momentarily disoriented.

ELIZABETH
Thomas, you never came to bed.

Thomas blinks, rubbing his eyes. He quickly glances at his arm, relieved to see his sleeve is still rolled down.

THOMAS
I... I must have dozed off while working. I'm sorry, my dear.

Elizabeth's eyes fall on the parchment on the desk. Before Thomas can stop her, she picks it up.

ELIZABETH
(reading)
"I, Thomas Blackwood, hereby agree to the terms set forth by the Order of the Eternal Flame..."

She looks up at Thomas, confusion and concern etched on her face.

ELIZABETH (CONT'D)
What is this, Thomas? What order?

Thomas snatches the parchment from her hands, his face pale.

THOMAS
It's nothing, Elizabeth. Just... just some research I've been conducting.

ELIZABETH
(voice rising)
Research? Thomas, this looks like some sort of contract. And is that... is that blood?

Thomas hastily folds the parchment and tucks it into his desk drawer.

THOMAS
(firmly)
Elizabeth, please. This is delicate work. I can't discuss it with you.

ELIZABETH
(hurt)
Can't discuss it with me? Thomas, I'm your wife. We've never kept secrets from each other.

Thomas stands, running a hand through his disheveled hair.

THOMAS
I know, I know. But this... this is different. It's important work, Elizabeth. Work that could change everything.

ELIZABETH
Change what? Thomas, you're scaring me.

Thomas takes Elizabeth's hands in his, his eyes pleading.

THOMAS
Trust me, my love. Please. I promise I'll explain everything when the time is right.

Elizabeth searches Thomas's face, torn between concern and frustration.

ELIZABETH
(sighing)
Very well. But Thomas, whatever this is... be careful. I have a terrible feeling about all this secrecy.

She turns to leave, pausing at the door.

ELIZABETH (CONT'D)
I love you, Thomas. Don't forget that.

As Elizabeth exits, Thomas slumps back into his chair. He rolls up his sleeve, revealing the black letters once more. They seem to have spread further up his arm.

THOMAS
(whispering)
I love you too, Elizabeth. I just hope you'll understand when this is all over.

CUT TO:

INT. STUDY - NIGHT

Thomas paces the study, muttering to himself. The room is even more cluttered than before, with open books and scattered papers covering every surface.

A knock at the door startles him. Thomas quickly covers his arm and calls out.

THOMAS
Who is it?

MALE VOICE (O.S.)
It's me, Uncle. May I come in?

Thomas relaxes slightly.

THOMAS
Of course, James. Enter.

JAMES BLACKWOOD (25), Thomas's nephew, enters the study. He's a handsome young man with a keen intelligence in his eyes.

JAMES
Uncle, I hope I'm not disturbing you. Aunt Elizabeth mentioned you've been... preoccupied lately.

Thomas waves his hand dismissively.

THOMAS
Your aunt worries too much. I'm fine, James. Just busy with my research.

James's eyes roam the cluttered study.

JAMES
What exactly are you researching, Uncle? This looks far more... intense than your usual historical studies.

Thomas hesitates, torn between secrecy and the desire to confide in someone.

THOMAS
James, my boy... what I'm about to tell you must remain between us. Can I trust you?

James nods solemnly.

JAMES
Of course, Uncle. You know you can always trust me.

Thomas takes a deep breath, then begins to roll up his sleeve.

THOMAS
What I'm about to show you may seem... impossible. But I assure you, it's very real.

As Thomas reveals his arm, James gasps. The black letters have spread further, now covering most of his forearm.

JAMES
(shocked)
Uncle, what... what is this?

THOMAS
The price of knowledge, James. The key to unlocking secrets beyond our wildest imaginations.

James steps closer, examining the writing.

JAMES
But how? Where did this come from?

Thomas walks to his desk, pulling out the parchment from earlier.

THOMAS
It started with this. A contract, of sorts. With an organization known as the Order of the Eternal Flame.

JAMES
I've never heard of such an order.

THOMAS
Few have. They operate in the shadows, guarding ancient knowledge and powerful artifacts.

James looks from the parchment to Thomas's arm, his expression a mix of fascination and concern.

JAMES
And this writing on your arm... it's connected to the contract?

Thomas nods gravely.

THOMAS
It appeared the moment I prepared to sign. A warning, perhaps. Or a test.

JAMES
A test of what?

THOMAS
My resolve. My willingness to sacrifice for knowledge.

James shakes his head, clearly worried.

JAMES
Uncle, this sounds dangerous. Have you considered the consequences?

Thomas's eyes flash with a mixture of excitement and fear.

THOMAS
The consequences? James, the knowledge this could unlock... it could change the world. Rewrite history as we know it.

JAMES
But at what cost? Look at what it's already doing to you.

Thomas glances at his arm, a flicker of doubt crossing his face.

THOMAS
(softly)
The price of knowledge is steep, James. But some prices are worth paying.

James places a hand on Thomas's shoulder.

JAMES
Uncle, please. Let me help you. We can research this Order together, find a safer way to‚Äî

Thomas jerks away, his expression hardening.

THOMAS
No! I've come too far to turn back now. I just need... I need more time.

JAMES
(pleading)
At least tell Aunt Elizabeth. She's worried sick about you.

Thomas shakes his head vehemently.

THOMAS
I can't involve Elizabeth in this. It's too dangerous. Promise me you won't tell her, James. Promise me!

James hesitates, clearly torn.

JAMES
I... I promise, Uncle. But please, be careful.

Thomas nods, some of the tension leaving his body.

THOMAS
Thank you, James. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have work to do.

James reluctantly leaves the study. As soon as the door closes, Thomas collapses into his chair, exhausted.

He rolls up his sleeve again, staring at the black writing. It seems to pulse faintly in the candlelight.

THOMAS
(whispering)
Just a little longer. I'm so close to understanding it all.

FADE TO BLACK

FADE IN:

INT. STUDY - NIGHT (LATER)

Thomas sits at his desk, surrounded by even more books and papers than before. His hair is unkempt, his clothes rumpled. He hasn't slept in days.

The black writing has spread further, now covering his entire arm and creeping up his neck. Thomas scratches at it absently as he pores over an ancient tome.

Suddenly, he sits up straight, his eyes wide.

THOMAS
(excited)
That's it! The final piece of the puzzle!

He frantically scribbles notes on a piece of parchment. As he writes, the black writing on his skin begins to glow faintly.

A knock at the door interrupts his feverish writing.

ELIZABETH (O.S.)
Thomas? Thomas, please. It's been days. You need to eat something.

Thomas ignores her, continuing to write.

ELIZABETH (O.S.) (CONT'D)
(more insistent)
Thomas, I'm coming in.

The door opens, and Elizabeth enters, carrying a tray of food. She gasps at the sight of Thomas.

ELIZABETH
(horrified)
Thomas! What... what's happened to you?

Thomas looks up, startled. He quickly tries to cover his arm and neck, but it's too late.

THOMAS
Elizabeth, I can explain‚Äî

Elizabeth drops the tray, food clattering to the floor.

ELIZABETH
(voice shaking)
What have you done to yourself? Is this... is this because of that contract?

Thomas stands, reaching out to her.

THOMAS
My love, please. It's not what you think. I'm on the verge of a great discovery.

Elizabeth backs away, her eyes filled with fear and sorrow.

ELIZABETH
Discovery? Thomas, look at yourself! This... this isn't natural. It isn't right.

THOMAS
(pleading)
Elizabeth, if you'll just let me explain‚Äî

Suddenly, the black writing on Thomas's skin flares brightly. He cries out in pain, falling to his knees.

ELIZABETH
(screaming)
Thomas!

She rushes to his side, cradling his head.

THOMAS
(through gritted teeth)
The... the contract. I have to... finish it.

Elizabeth looks around frantically, her eyes falling on the parchment on the desk.

ELIZABETH
Is that it? The contract?

Thomas nods weakly. Elizabeth stands, determination replacing fear in her eyes.

ELIZABETH (CONT'D)
Then I'll destroy it. End this madness once and for all.

She grabs the parchment, but as soon as her fingers touch it, she cries out in pain. The black writing begins to spread to her hand.

THOMAS
(shouting)
No! Elizabeth, let it go!

But it's too late. The writing spreads rapidly up Elizabeth's arm, mirroring Thomas's condition.

ELIZABETH
(panicking)
Thomas, what's happening? Make it stop!

Thomas struggles to his feet, stumbling towards Elizabeth.

THOMAS
I'm sorry, my love. I'm so sorry. I never meant for this to happen.

As they embrace, the black writing on their skin begins to glow even brighter. The room starts to shake, books falling from shelves.

Suddenly, the study door bursts open. James rushes in, his eyes widening at the scene before him.

JAMES
Uncle! Aunt Elizabeth!

Thomas turns to James, his eyes filled with regret and fear.

THOMAS
James, my boy. I'm sorry. I should have listened to you.

James tries to approach, but an invisible force holds him back.

JAMES
(desperate)
What's happening? How can I help?

Thomas shakes his head sadly.

THOMAS
It's too late, James. The contract... it's being fulfilled.

Elizabeth clings to Thomas, her body shaking.

ELIZABETH
Thomas, I'm scared. What's going to happen to us?

Thomas holds her tightly, looking over her shoulder at James.

THOMAS
James, listen to me. In my desk, there's a journal. It explains everything. You must find it, understand it. Don't let our sacrifice be in vain.

James nods, tears in his eyes.

JAMES
I promise, Uncle. I'll find a way to help you both.

The glow from Thomas and Elizabeth intensifies, becoming almost blinding. James shields his eyes.

THOMAS
(voice fading)
Remember, James. The price of knowledge...

A flash of brilliant light fills the room. When it fades, Thomas and Elizabeth are gone. All that remains is a faint, shimmering outline where they stood.

James falls to his knees, stunned.

JAMES
(whispering)
...is steep.

He looks around the now-quiet study, his eyes falling on Thomas's desk. With a shaking hand, he opens the drawer and pulls out a leather-bound journal.

JAMES (CONT'D)
I'll find a way, Uncle. I promise.

As James opens the journal, we see the first page. Written in Thomas's handwriting are the words: "The Order of the Eternal Flame: A Journey into the Unknown."

FADE TO BLACK

FADE IN:

INT. STUDY - DAY (ONE WEEK LATER)

The study has been cleaned and reorganized. James sits at Thomas's desk, poring over the journal. His eyes are red-rimmed from lack of sleep, his clothes rumpled.

A knock at the door startles him.

JAMES
Come in.

DETECTIVE HARRIS (50), a gruff, no-nonsense man, enters the study.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Mr. Blackwood? I'm Detective Harris. I'm here about your uncle and aunt's disappearance.

James closes the journal, sliding it under some papers.

JAMES
Of course, Detective. Please, have a seat.

Detective Harris remains standing, his eyes scanning the room.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
I'll stand, thank you. Mr. Blackwood, you were the last person to see your uncle and aunt, correct?

James nods, his expression carefully neutral.

JAMES
That's right. I came to check on them and... and they were gone.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Just like that? No sign of struggle, no note?

James hesitates, choosing his words carefully.

JAMES
My uncle had been... working on something. Something important. But I'm afraid I don't know the details.

Detective Harris's eyes narrow.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Something important enough to make two people vanish into thin air?

JAMES
(defensively)
I don't know what happened, Detective. If I did, don't you think I'd tell you?

Detective Harris pulls out a small notebook, flipping through it.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
We've interviewed the staff. They mentioned your uncle had been acting strangely in the days leading up to the disappearance. Locking himself in the study, barely eating or sleeping.

James nods, his expression somber.

JAMES
Uncle Thomas was... dedicated to his work. Sometimes to a fault.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
And what exactly was this work?

James pauses, considering his answer.

JAMES
Historical research, mainly. Uncle Thomas was always fascinated by ancient mysteries, lost civilizations.

Detective Harris makes a note in his book.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Mr. Blackwood, I'll be frank. This whole situation doesn't add up. Two people don't just vanish without a trace. If you're hiding something‚Äî

James stands abruptly, his patience wearing thin.

JAMES
I've told you everything I know, Detective. My uncle and aunt are missing, and I'm just as desperate to find them as you are.

Detective Harris studies James for a moment, then nods.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Very well, Mr. Blackwood. But this investigation is far from over. We'll be in touch.

As the detective leaves, James slumps back into his chair. He pulls out Thomas's journal, running his fingers over the cover.

JAMES
(whispering)
Where are you, Uncle? What really happened that night?

He opens the journal, flipping to a page marked with a ribbon. A sketch of a strange symbol catches his eye ‚Äì a flame encircled by arcane writing.

JAMES (CONT'D)
The Order of the Eternal Flame. What secrets are you hiding?

Suddenly, James notices something strange. The ink of the symbol seems to be... moving. As he watches, fascinated and horrified, the flame in the sketch begins to flicker, as if alive.

James drops the journal, stumbling back from the desk. But it's too late. A thin tendril of black ink snakes out from the page, reaching for his hand.

JAMES (CONT'D)
(panicked)
No, no, no!

As the ink touches his skin, James gasps. Black writing begins to appear on his hand, just as it did on Thomas's arm.

JAMES (CONT'D)
(reading aloud)
"The cycle continues. Are you prepared to pay the price, James Blackwood?"

James stares at his hand, a mix of fear and determination in his eyes.

JAMES (CONT'D)
For you, Uncle Thomas. For Aunt Elizabeth. I'll find a way to bring you back.

He picks up the journal again, ignoring the writing spreading up his arm. As he begins to read, the candles in the study flicker ominously.

FADE TO BLACK

END

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: Three people are riding the elevator when it suddenly stops. One of the people starts panicking as she is claustrophobic. The other person calms her down, while the third one tries to find some help. It becomes obvious that they would spend some time together stuck on the 11th floor. They start talking, when the woman who is afraid of closed spaces discovers the identity of one of the people there.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 4000 words.
response:
Here's a screenplay based on the given writing prompt and requirements:

INT. OFFICE BUILDING ELEVATOR - DAY

The sleek, modern elevator ascends smoothly. Three people stand inside, each lost in their own thoughts. 

SARAH COLLINS (35), a well-dressed businesswoman with an air of confidence, checks her watch impatiently. Her perfectly manicured nails tap against her leather briefcase.

Next to her, MICHAEL RODRIGUEZ (42), a casually dressed IT technician, scrolls through his phone. His relaxed demeanor contrasts sharply with Sarah's rigid posture.

In the corner, EMMA THOMPSON (28), a shy librarian, clutches a stack of books to her chest. She glances nervously at the other occupants, then fixes her gaze on the floor numbers as they light up.

The elevator reaches the 11th floor when suddenly, it jerks to a halt. The lights flicker ominously.

SARAH
(alarmed)
What was that?

MICHAEL
(calmly)
Looks like we've stopped.

EMMA
(voice trembling)
Oh no... oh no, no, no...

Sarah presses the buttons frantically, but nothing happens. Emma's breathing becomes rapid and shallow.

SARAH
(frustrated)
Great. Just great. I have a meeting in ten minutes.

She notices Emma's distress and softens her tone.

SARAH (CONT'D)
Hey, are you okay?

EMMA
(panicking)
I... I can't... I can't breathe. We're trapped. We're going to die in here!

Michael steps forward, his voice gentle and reassuring.

MICHAEL
Hey, it's alright. We're not trapped. This happens sometimes. They'll have us out in no time.

EMMA
(gasping)
But... but what if they don't? What if we run out of air?

SARAH
(concerned)
Is she claustrophobic?

MICHAEL
(nodding)
Looks like it. 

(to Emma)
What's your name?

EMMA
(between breaths)
Emma... Emma Thompson.

MICHAEL
Okay, Emma. I'm Michael, and this is...

SARAH
Sarah. Sarah Collins.

MICHAEL
Right. Emma, I need you to focus on my voice, okay? Can you do that for me?

Emma nods, her eyes wide with fear.

MICHAEL (CONT'D)
Good. Now, I want you to breathe with me. In through your nose, out through your mouth. Ready?

Michael demonstrates, taking a deep breath. Emma tries to follow, her breath still shaky.

MICHAEL (CONT'D)
That's it. Again. In... and out.

As Michael continues to guide Emma through breathing exercises, Sarah examines the elevator panel.

SARAH
There's an emergency call button here. I'll try to get some help.

She presses the button and waits. After a moment, a crackly voice comes through the speaker.

MAINTENANCE VOICE (O.S.)
This is maintenance. What seems to be the problem?

SARAH
We're stuck in the elevator on the 11th floor. Can you get us out?

MAINTENANCE VOICE (O.S.)
We're aware of the situation, ma'am. There's been a power surge that's affected several elevators. We're working on it, but it might take a while. Are you all okay in there?

Sarah glances at Emma, who's still focusing on her breathing with Michael's help.

SARAH
We're fine, but one of us is claustrophobic. How long is "a while"?

MAINTENANCE VOICE (O.S.)
We're doing our best to resolve the issue as quickly as possible. It could be anywhere from 30 minutes to a couple of hours. We'll keep you updated. Try to stay calm and conserve energy.

SARAH
(sighing)
Understood. Thank you.

The connection cuts off. Sarah turns to the others.

SARAH (CONT'D)
Well, looks like we're going to be here for a bit.

MICHAEL
(to Emma)
How are you feeling now?

EMMA
(breathing easier)
A little better. Thank you.

SARAH
They said it could be up to a couple of hours.

EMMA
(panic rising again)
Hours?

MICHAEL
(quickly)
It's okay, Emma. We're safe here. The elevator isn't going to fall or anything. We just need to wait it out.

SARAH
(sitting down)
Might as well get comfortable.

Michael and Emma follow suit, sitting on the elevator floor. Emma still looks uneasy but less panicked than before.

MICHAEL
So, Emma, I noticed you're carrying some books. Are you a student?

EMMA
(shaking her head)
No, I'm a librarian. I was just returning some books to the law firm upstairs.

SARAH
(interest piqued)
Oh? Which firm?

EMMA
Caldwell & Associates. Do you work there?

SARAH
(nodding)
I'm a partner there. I don't think I've seen you before, though.

EMMA
I usually deal with the paralegal team. They often need reference materials.

MICHAEL
(to Sarah)
And what kind of law do you practice?

SARAH
Corporate law, mainly. Mergers and acquisitions, that sort of thing.

MICHAEL
Sounds... intense.

SARAH
(smiling slightly)
It can be. What about you, Michael? What brings you to this building?

MICHAEL
I'm an IT consultant. I was here to upgrade the security systems for one of the companies on the 15th floor.

EMMA
(curiosity overcoming fear)
That sounds interesting. What kind of security systems?

MICHAEL
Oh, you know, the usual. Firewalls, encryption, that sort of thing. Nothing too exciting.

SARAH
(skeptically)
Really? I would think cybersecurity is quite exciting these days.

MICHAEL
(shrugging)
I suppose it depends on your perspective. To me, it's just another day at the office.

An awkward silence falls over the group. Emma fidgets nervously, her eyes darting around the confined space.

SARAH
(trying to keep the conversation going)
So, Emma, what made you choose to become a librarian?

EMMA
(grateful for the distraction)
Oh, I've always loved books. There's something magical about being surrounded by so much knowledge, you know? And I enjoy helping people find the information they need.

MICHAEL
That's admirable. In this digital age, it's nice to know there are still people who appreciate physical books.

EMMA
(nodding enthusiastically)
Exactly! Don't get me wrong, digital resources are incredibly useful, but there's just something special about holding a book in your hands.

SARAH
(smiling)
I can understand that. I still prefer physical copies of contracts and legal documents. It's easier to catch details that way.

MICHAEL
(chuckling)
And here I am, trying to digitize everything.

They all laugh, the tension in the elevator easing slightly.

EMMA
(to Michael)
How did you get into IT?

MICHAEL
(hesitating)
Oh, you know... I've always been good with computers. It seemed like a natural career path.

SARAH
(noticing his hesitation)
There's more to it than that, isn't there?

MICHAEL
(sighing)
Well, if you must know, I used to be a hacker in my younger days.

EMMA
(eyes widening)
Really? Like, breaking into computer systems and stuff?

MICHAEL
(nodding)
Yeah, but nothing malicious. I was more interested in exposing security flaws than causing damage. Eventually, I realized I could make a legitimate career out of it.

SARAH
(intrigued)
So you went from breaking security systems to building them?

MICHAEL
Exactly. Who better to protect against hackers than a former hacker, right?

EMMA
That's fascinating! It's like... like a reformed burglar becoming a security consultant.

MICHAEL
(laughing)
That's a pretty good analogy, actually.

SARAH
(thoughtfully)
It must have been quite a transition. How did you manage to go legit without facing legal consequences?

MICHAEL
(shifting uncomfortably)
Well, let's just say I had some help from understanding people who saw my potential.

Sarah nods, but her expression suggests she's filing this information away for later.

EMMA
(to Sarah)
What about you? How did you end up in corporate law?

SARAH
(smiling)
Family tradition, I'm afraid. Both my parents were lawyers. I practically grew up in a courtroom.

EMMA
Did you ever consider doing something else?

SARAH
(pausing)
I... I wanted to be a chef, actually. I love cooking.

MICHAEL
(surprised)
Really? That's quite different from corporate law.

SARAH
(nodding)
I know. But my parents... well, they had certain expectations. And I do enjoy my work, most of the time.

EMMA
(softly)
It's never too late to pursue your passions, you know.

SARAH
(wistfully)
Maybe. But for now, I'm content where I am.

Another silence falls, each lost in their own thoughts. Suddenly, the elevator jerks slightly, causing Emma to gasp.

MICHAEL
(quickly)
It's okay, Emma. That's probably just them working on getting us out. Remember your breathing.

Emma nods, taking deep breaths. Sarah checks her watch and sighs.

SARAH
We've been in here for almost an hour now.

MICHAEL
Time flies when you're having fun, right?

EMMA
(giggling nervously)
I wouldn't exactly call this fun, but... it hasn't been as bad as I feared.

SARAH
(smiling)
I agree. You two are much better company than my usual elevator companions.

MICHAEL
(dramatically)
Why, thank you, counselor. We aim to please.

They all laugh, the mood lightening once again.

EMMA
(to Sarah)
So, if you weren't a lawyer, and you pursued cooking instead, what kind of restaurant would you want to have?

SARAH
(eyes lighting up)
Oh, I've actually thought about this a lot. I'd love to open a small bistro, focusing on fusion cuisine. Combining different culinary traditions to create something new and exciting.

MICHAEL
That sounds amazing. Any specific combinations in mind?

SARAH
(enthusiastically)
Well, I've been experimenting with blending French and Japanese cuisines. The delicacy of French cooking techniques with the bold flavors and presentation of Japanese dishes... it's magical when done right.

EMMA
(impressed)
Wow, that does sound incredible. I'd definitely eat at your restaurant.

MICHAEL
Me too. Maybe you should consider it as a side business?

SARAH
(laughing)
Maybe someday. For now, I'll stick to impressing my friends at dinner parties.

EMMA
(to Michael)
What about you? Any secret passions or dreams?

MICHAEL
(thoughtfully)
You know, I've always been fascinated by space exploration. If I wasn't in IT, I might have tried to become an astronaut or work for NASA.

SARAH
(raising an eyebrow)
From hacker to astronaut? That's quite a career change.

MICHAEL
(grinning)
Hey, they both involve exploring unknown territories, right?

EMMA
(excitedly)
That's so cool! I love reading about space. Have you ever been to any of the NASA facilities?

MICHAEL
(nodding)
I visited Kennedy Space Center once. It was incredible. Standing next to those massive rockets... it really puts things in perspective.

SARAH
I can imagine. It must make our problems seem pretty small in comparison.

MICHAEL
Exactly. It's humbling, but also inspiring. Reminds you of what humans are capable of when we work together.

EMMA
(smiling)
That's a nice thought. Especially when we're stuck in an elevator.

They all chuckle. Suddenly, Sarah's phone buzzes. She checks it and frowns.

SARAH
It's my assistant. Apparently, the client I was supposed to meet is getting impatient.

MICHAEL
Can't you explain the situation?

SARAH
(sighing)
I did, but this client is... difficult. He's threatening to take his business elsewhere.

EMMA
(concerned)
Oh no, that's terrible. Is there anything you can do?

SARAH
(shaking her head)
Not from in here. I'll just have to deal with the fallout later.

MICHAEL
(sympathetically)
I'm sorry. That sounds stressful.

SARAH
(forcing a smile)
It's part of the job. But thank you.

Emma fidgets nervously, then takes a deep breath.

EMMA
I... I might be able to help.

SARAH
(confused)
What do you mean?

EMMA
(hesitantly)
Well, I... I'm not just a librarian. I'm also a notary public.

SARAH
(surprised)
Really? That's... wait, how does that help?

EMMA
(explaining)
If your client needs any documents notarized, I could do it right here. It might show them that you're still working on their case, even in these circumstances.

SARAH
(eyes widening)
That... that could actually work. The contract does need to be notarized. But how would we get the documents?

MICHAEL
(stepping in)
I might be able to help with that. If I can get a signal on my phone, I could potentially access your work computer remotely and print the documents to a nearby office.

SARAH
(skeptical)
Is that... legal?

MICHAEL
(grinning)
With your permission, of course. Consider it an emergency protocol.

SARAH
(considering)
I... suppose desperate times call for desperate measures. Let's do it.

Michael pulls out his phone and starts working on it. Sarah dictates her login information, careful to keep her voice low.

EMMA
(watching them)
This is like something out of a movie. A lawyer, a hacker, and a notary public, trapped in an elevator, working together to save a business deal.

SARAH
(laughing)
When you put it that way, it does sound rather dramatic.

MICHAEL
(focused on his phone)
Okay, I'm in. Which documents do you need?

SARAH
The Merger Agreement for Anderson Corp. It should be on my desktop.

MICHAEL
Got it. Now, to find a printer...

He works for a few more minutes, his fingers flying over the phone screen.

MICHAEL (CONT'D)
Alright, I've sent it to a printer on the 12th floor. Your assistant should be able to retrieve it.

SARAH
(impressed)
That's... incredible. Thank you, Michael.

She quickly types out a message on her phone.

SARAH (CONT'D)
I've told my assistant to get the documents and bring them here. Now we just need to figure out how to get them into the elevator.

EMMA
(thinking)
Maybe they could slip them through the gap between the doors?

MICHAEL
Good idea. I'll see if I can pry them open a bit.

Michael moves to the elevator doors and tries to create a small opening. After a few attempts, he manages to create a narrow gap.

MICHAEL (CONT'D)
There we go. It's not much, but it should be enough for paper.

They wait in tense silence for a few minutes. Finally, they hear footsteps approaching.

ASSISTANT (O.S.)
Ms. Collins? Are you there?

SARAH
(relieved)
Yes, Jessica. Do you have the documents?

ASSISTANT (O.S.)
I do. Where should I put them?

SARAH
There's a small gap in the elevator doors. Can you see it?

ASSISTANT (O.S.)
Yes, I see it. I'm slipping the papers through now.

One by one, the documents slide into the elevator. Sarah gathers them up, checking to make sure everything is there.

SARAH
Perfect. Thank you, Jessica. Please inform Mr. Anderson that we'll have the notarized documents to him shortly.

ASSISTANT (O.S.)
Of course, Ms. Collins. Is there anything else you need?

SARAH
No, that's all for now. Thank you.

They hear the assistant's footsteps retreating. Sarah turns to Emma with a grateful smile.

SARAH (CONT'D)
Alright, Emma. Are you ready to save the day?

EMMA
(nervously)
I'll do my best. Do you have a pen?

Sarah rummages in her briefcase and produces a pen. Emma takes it, along with the documents, and starts reviewing them.

MICHAEL
(watching)
This is pretty amazing. We're like a little mobile office in here.

SARAH
(nodding)
It's certainly not how I expected my day to go, but I'm grateful for both of you.

EMMA
(looking up)
Okay, I think I'm ready. Sarah, I'll need you to sign here, here, and here.

Sarah signs where indicated. Emma then pulls out a small notary stamp from her bag and carefully applies it to the documents.

EMMA (CONT'D)
There. It's done.

SARAH
(sighing in relief)
Thank you so much, Emma. You've just saved me from a major headache.

MICHAEL
(grinning)
And possibly saved a multi-million dollar deal?

SARAH
(smiling)
Possibly. Though I try not to discuss the details of my cases.

EMMA
(curiously)
Is it always this exciting? The corporate law world, I mean.

SARAH
(laughing)
Hardly. Most days it's just a lot of paperwork and meetings. But every now and then, you get days like this that remind you why you do it.

MICHAEL
(teasingly)
You mean you don't regularly conduct business from stuck elevators?

SARAH
(playing along)
Oh, all the time. It's my preferred office, actually.

They all laugh, the tension from earlier completely dissipated. Suddenly, the elevator jerks again, this time more forcefully.

EMMA
(startled)
What was that?

Before anyone can answer, the lights flicker and the elevator starts moving again.

MICHAEL
(relieved)
Looks like we're back in business.

SARAH
(checking her watch)
Just in time, too. We've been in here for nearly two hours.

The elevator descends smoothly, finally reaching the ground floor. As the doors open, they're met by a crowd of maintenance workers and concerned office employees.

MAINTENANCE WORKER
Is everyone alright in there?

SARAH
(stepping out)
We're fine, thank you. Just a bit stiff from sitting on the floor.

As they exit the elevator, Emma takes a deep breath, clearly relieved to be in open space again.

EMMA
(to Michael and Sarah)
Thank you both so much. I don't think I could have made it through that without you.

MICHAEL
(smiling)
You did great, Emma. You should be proud of yourself.

SARAH
Absolutely. And thank you again for your help with the documents.

They stand awkwardly for a moment, unsure of how to proceed now that their shared ordeal is over.

SARAH (CONT'D)
Well, I should probably get these documents to my client.

MICHAEL
And I need to finish my work on the 15th floor.

EMMA
I guess I'll head back to the library then.

They start to go their separate ways, but Sarah suddenly turns back.

SARAH
Listen, I was thinking... would you both like to have dinner sometime? My treat, as a thank you for today.

MICHAEL
(surprised but pleased)
I'd like that.

EMMA
(smiling)
Me too. It would be nice to talk more when we're not in crisis mode.

SARAH
(grinning)
Great. I'll email you both to set it up. And who knows? Maybe I'll even cook something.

MICHAEL
(laughing)
Looking forward to it. Just as long as it's not in an elevator.

They all laugh and exchange contact information before finally parting ways. As they leave, each of them can't help but smile, thinking about the unexpected friendship that bloomed in the most unlikely of places.

FADE OUT.

THE END

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A dinner scene. A large dining table, with different kinds of food and expensive cutlery. The guests are well-dressed and well-rehearsed in etiquette. A senior member of the family announces a change in his will. Everybody on the table is horrified.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 4000 words.
response:
Here's a screenplay based on the given writing prompt and requirements:

INT. MANSION - DINING ROOM - NIGHT

A grand, opulent dining room adorned with crystal chandeliers and ornate wallpaper. A long, mahogany table dominates the center of the room, set with fine china, crystal glasses, and polished silver cutlery. Expensive oil paintings and family portraits line the walls.

At the head of the table sits EDWARD BLACKWOOD (75), a distinguished gentleman with silver hair and piercing blue eyes. To his right is his wife, MARGARET BLACKWOOD (70), elegant and poised in a pearl necklace.

Their children and their spouses occupy the remaining seats:

JAMES BLACKWOOD (50), the eldest son, sits next to his wife VICTORIA (45). Both exude an air of entitlement.

ELIZABETH CARTER (48), the only daughter, fidgets nervously beside her husband ROBERT (52), a stern-looking man.

MICHAEL BLACKWOOD (45), the youngest son, slouches slightly in his chair, his wife SARAH (40) casting worried glances his way.

The family's long-time butler, HARRISON (60), stands attentively near the door.

Edward clears his throat, drawing everyone's attention.

EDWARD
Before we begin our meal, I'd like to make an announcement.

The room falls silent, all eyes on Edward.

EDWARD (CONT'D)
As you all know, I've been reviewing my will lately. After much consideration, I've decided to make some... significant changes.

Tension fills the air. Margaret's eyes widen slightly, but she maintains her composure.

JAMES
(leaning forward)
What kind of changes, Father?

EDWARD
(smiling enigmatically)
All in good time, James. Let's enjoy our meal first, shall we?

Edward nods to Harrison, who begins serving the first course.

ELIZABETH
(nervously)
Father, surely you can give us a hint?

EDWARD
(chuckling)
Patience, my dear. You'll all know soon enough.

The family exchanges worried glances as they begin to eat. Michael takes a large gulp of wine.

MICHAEL
(muttering)
I have a bad feeling about this.

SARAH
(whispering)
Shh, Michael. Not now.

As the meal progresses, conversation is stilted and forced. Victoria attempts to break the tension.

VICTORIA
Margaret, the table settings are lovely. Are these the new Limoges plates you mentioned?

MARGARET
(distracted)
Hmm? Oh, yes. Thank you, Victoria.

ROBERT
(to Edward)
How's the market treating Blackwood Industries these days, Edward?

EDWARD
(cryptically)
Oh, you know how it is, Robert. Ups and downs. But I've always believed in planning for the future.

James and Elizabeth exchange a worried look.

JAMES
(clearing his throat)
Father, about these changes to your will...

EDWARD
(interrupting)
I said we'd discuss it after dinner, James. 

JAMES
(frustrated)
But-

MARGARET
(sharply)
James, mind your manners. Your father said we'd discuss it later.

James sulks, stabbing at his food with more force than necessary.

As the main course is served, Edward watches his family with amusement. Elizabeth nervously drops her fork, causing a loud clatter.

ELIZABETH
(flustered)
Oh, I'm so sorry!

ROBERT
(under his breath)
Get it together, Elizabeth.

ELIZABETH
(hissing back)
I'm trying, Robert!

Michael leans back in his chair, loosening his tie.

MICHAEL
Is it hot in here, or is it just me?

SARAH
(concerned)
Are you feeling alright, dear?

MICHAEL
(sarcastically)
Oh, just peachy. Nothing like a surprise announcement about the family fortune to aid digestion.

VICTORIA
(coolly)
Really, Michael. There's no need for sarcasm.

MICHAEL
(rolling his eyes)
Of course not. We're all just having a lovely, normal family dinner, aren't we?

EDWARD
(sternly)
That's enough, Michael.

The room falls silent again. Harrison quietly refills wine glasses.

As dessert is served, the tension in the room is palpable. Edward sits back, a small smile playing on his lips.

EDWARD
Well, I suppose you've all been patient enough. Shall we discuss the changes to my will?

All eyes snap to Edward, forks frozen midair.

JAMES
(eagerly)
Yes, please, Father.

ELIZABETH
(nervously)
If you think it's appropriate at the dinner table...

EDWARD
(chuckling)
Oh, I think it's the perfect time. We're all here, after all.

Edward takes a sip of wine, savoring the moment.

EDWARD (CONT'D)
I've decided to leave the bulk of my estate to charity.

A collective gasp echoes around the table. Margaret's hand flies to her chest.

JAMES
(sputtering)
What? Father, you can't be serious!

ELIZABETH
(voice trembling)
But... but what about us?

MICHAEL
(laughing bitterly)
Well, didn't see that coming.

EDWARD
(calmly)
I'm quite serious. The Blackwood Foundation for Children's Education will receive 80% of my estate upon my death.

VICTORIA
(outraged)
This is outrageous! James is your eldest son, the heir to Blackwood Industries!

EDWARD
(firmly)
James will inherit my shares in the company, as planned. But the rest of my personal fortune will go to those who truly need it.

ROBERT
(leaning forward)
Edward, surely you can't mean to leave your own family with nothing?

EDWARD
I said the bulk of my estate, Robert, not all of it. Each of you will receive a modest inheritance.

JAMES
(angrily)
Modest? What exactly do you mean by 'modest,' Father?

EDWARD
(sighing)
One million dollars each, to be exact.

Another shocked silence falls over the table.

ELIZABETH
(weakly)
One... one million?

MICHAEL
(sarcastically)
Well, that should cover groceries for a week or two.

SARAH
(elbowing Michael)
Michael, please.

MARGARET
(speaking for the first time)
Edward, darling... don't you think this is a bit... extreme?

EDWARD
(taking Margaret's hand)
I've given this a lot of thought, Margaret. It's what I want to do.

JAMES
(standing abruptly)
This is ridiculous! I won't stand for it!

VICTORIA
(pulling James down)
James, sit down. You're making a scene.

JAMES
(hissing)
A scene? Father's the one making a scene, dropping this bomb on us at dinner!

ELIZABETH
(tearfully)
But Father, what about our children? Your grandchildren?

EDWARD
(softening slightly)
I've set up trust funds for each of my grandchildren. They'll receive a substantial sum when they turn 25, provided they complete their education.

ROBERT
(skeptically)
And what exactly qualifies as 'substantial'?

EDWARD
(firmly)
That's between me and my grandchildren, Robert.

Michael lets out a low whistle, leaning back in his chair.

MICHAEL
Well, this is one hell of a family dinner.

SARAH
(whispering)
Michael, please try to be respectful.

MICHAEL
(loudly)
Respectful? Our dear old dad just told us he's giving away our inheritance to charity. I think we're a bit past respectful, don't you?

EDWARD
(sternly)
It's my money, Michael. I've earned the right to do with it as I please.

JAMES
(bitterly)
And what about everything we've done for the company, Father? Don't we deserve something for that?

EDWARD
(raising an eyebrow)
You've been well-compensated for your work, James. Or are you saying you've only been putting in effort in anticipation of my death?

James flushes red, sputtering indignantly.

VICTORIA
(smoothly)
Of course not, Edward. James is just... surprised, that's all.

ELIZABETH
(wiping her eyes)
Father, please. Can't we discuss this further? Perhaps come to some sort of... compromise?

EDWARD
(firmly)
My decision is final, Elizabeth. The papers have already been drawn up and signed.

ROBERT
(leaning forward)
