Surely there must be some way to contest this, Edward. It seems... hasty.

EDWARD
(narrowing his eyes)
Hasty? I've been considering this for years, Robert. And I assure you, everything is ironclad.

Margaret places a hand on Edward's arm, a worried expression on her face.

MARGARET
Edward, perhaps we should discuss this in private. As a family.

EDWARD
(patting Margaret's hand)
There's nothing to discuss, my dear. What's done is done.

JAMES
(standing again)
This is absurd! I won't accept this!

VICTORIA
(tugging at James' sleeve)
James, please sit down.

JAMES
(shrugging her off)
No, Victoria! Father, you can't do this to us. To the family name!

EDWARD
(calmly)
The family name will be just fine, James. In fact, I'd argue it will be enhanced by this charitable endeavor.

ELIZABETH
(sobbing quietly)
But Father, what about our lifestyles? Our homes?

EDWARD
(sighing)
Elizabeth, you and your siblings are all successful adults. You have careers, savings. This inheritance was never meant to be a crutch.

MICHAEL
(sarcastically)
Oh, of course. We'll just tighten our belts a bit. Maybe sell a yacht or two.

SARAH
(hissing)
Michael, you're not helping.

ROBERT
(leaning towards Edward)
Edward, be reasonable. Think about the impact this will have on your family.

EDWARD
(firmly)
I have thought about it, Robert. Extensively. And I believe this is the right thing to do.

James slams his fist on the table, causing the dishes to rattle.

JAMES
The right thing? How is abandoning your family the right thing?

MARGARET
(sharply)
James! Mind your tone!

EDWARD
(calmly)
I'm not abandoning anyone, James. I'm simply choosing to use my wealth in a way that I believe will do the most good.

VICTORIA
(coldly)
And your family's well-being doesn't qualify as 'good,' Edward?

EDWARD
(sighing)
Victoria, look around you. You're all sitting in a mansion, eating off fine china. You have successful careers, beautiful homes. You don't need my money.

ELIZABETH
(sniffling)
But Father, we're your children. Don't we deserve...

EDWARD
(interrupting gently)
Deserve what, Elizabeth? To inherit wealth you didn't earn? To live off my legacy rather than create your own?

A heavy silence falls over the table. Michael breaks it with a bitter laugh.

MICHAEL
Well, I guess we know where we stand now, don't we?

SARAH
(placing a hand on Michael's arm)
Michael, please. Let's not say anything we'll regret.

JAMES
(seething)
Oh, I think Father's the one who's going to have regrets.

EDWARD
(raising an eyebrow)
Is that a threat, James?

JAMES
(backpedaling)
I... no, of course not. I just meant...

VICTORIA
(smoothly)
James merely means that you might come to regret this decision, Edward. It's quite... drastic.

EDWARD
(firmly)
I assure you, I won't. This decision has been a long time coming.

ELIZABETH
(tearfully)
But why, Father? Why now? Why like this?

EDWARD
(softening slightly)
Because it's time, Elizabeth. I've watched all of you grow into successful adults. But I've also watched you become... complacent. Entitled.

JAMES
(indignantly)
Entitled? How dare you-

EDWARD
(holding up a hand)
Let me finish, James. I built Blackwood Industries from nothing. I worked hard, made sacrifices. And yes, I've enjoyed the fruits of my labor. But I've never forgotten where I came from.

Edward looks around the table, meeting each person's eyes.

EDWARD (CONT'D)
I want my legacy to be more than just providing my children with a lavish lifestyle. I want to make a real difference in the world.

MICHAEL
(sarcastically)
And we're just collateral damage in your quest for a legacy, is that it?

MARGARET
(sharply)
Michael! That's quite enough!

EDWARD
(calmly)
No, Margaret. Let him speak. Michael, do you truly believe you'll be damaged by this decision?

MICHAEL
(flustered)
Well, I... that is...

SARAH
(quietly)
We'll be fine, Edward. It's just... a shock.

EDWARD
(nodding)
I understand that. And I'm sorry for the abrupt way I've delivered this news. But I stand by my decision.

JAMES
(bitterly)
Of course you do. You've always been stubborn.

VICTORIA
(placing a hand on James' arm)
James, dear. Perhaps we should take some time to process this before saying anything... rash.

ELIZABETH
(wiping her eyes)
Father, isn't there any way we can change your mind?

EDWARD
(gently)
No, Elizabeth. My mind is made up.

ROBERT
(leaning forward)
Edward, surely we can come to some sort of arrangement. Perhaps a smaller percentage to charity, and the rest divided among the family?

EDWARD
(firmly)
The decision is final, Robert. The papers have been signed.

A heavy silence falls over the table. Harrison quietly begins clearing the dessert plates.

MARGARET
(attempting to lighten the mood)
Shall we move to the drawing room for coffee?

JAMES
(standing abruptly)
I think we'll be going.

VICTORIA
(standing as well)
Yes, thank you for dinner, Margaret, Edward.

ELIZABETH
(tearfully)
We should go too, Robert.

ROBERT
(nodding curtly)
Yes, I think that's best.

MICHAEL
(standing unsteadily)
Well, this has been fun. Same time next week?

SARAH
(helping Michael up)
I'm sorry, Edward, Margaret. We'll see ourselves out.

Edward watches as his children and their spouses file out of the dining room, a mix of anger, shock, and disappointment on their faces. Margaret turns to him, a worried expression on her face.

MARGARET
Edward, are you sure about this?

EDWARD
(taking her hand)
Yes, my dear. I am.

MARGARET
(sighing)
They'll come around, won't they?

EDWARD
(smiling sadly)
In time, perhaps. But even if they don't, I know I've done the right thing.

As Harrison begins to clear the remaining dishes, Edward and Margaret sit in silence, the echoes of the evening's revelations still hanging in the air.

FADE OUT.

INT. BLACKWOOD MANSION - JAMES AND VICTORIA'S GUEST ROOM - NIGHT

James paces furiously while Victoria sits on the edge of the bed, watching him.

JAMES
(fuming)
I can't believe this. After everything we've done for the company, for him!

VICTORIA
(calmly)
James, darling, you need to calm down. Getting angry won't change anything.

JAMES
(whirling to face her)
Calm down? How can I calm down? He's giving away our inheritance, Victoria!

VICTORIA
(standing)
I know, dear. But there must be a way around this. We just need to think strategically.

JAMES
(bitterly)
Strategic thinking won't change a signed will.

VICTORIA
(smiling slyly)
Perhaps not. But there are always... other options.

James stops pacing, looking at Victoria with interest.

JAMES
What do you mean?

VICTORIA
(moving closer)
Well, your father isn't getting any younger. And wills can be... challenged.

JAMES
(lowering his voice)
Are you suggesting what I think you're suggesting?

VICTORIA
(shrugging)
I'm not suggesting anything, darling. I'm simply pointing out that we have options.

James sits heavily on the bed, running a hand through his hair.

JAMES
I don't know, Victoria. This is my father we're talking about.

VICTORIA
(sitting beside him)
And he's the one who's chosen to betray his family. To betray you.

James looks at Victoria, a conflict of emotions playing across his face.

JAMES
I... I need to think about this.

VICTORIA
(patting his hand)
Of course, dear. Take all the time you need.

Victoria stands and moves to the window, a calculating look in her eyes.

FADE TO:

INT. BLACKWOOD MANSION - ELIZABETH AND ROBERT'S GUEST ROOM - NIGHT

Elizabeth sits at the vanity, tears streaming down her face as she removes her jewelry. Robert paces behind her.

ELIZABETH
(sobbing)
How could he do this to us, Robert? Doesn't he love us?

ROBERT
(gruffly)
This isn't about love, Elizabeth. It's about control.

ELIZABETH
(turning to face him)
What do you mean?

ROBERT
(sitting on the bed)
Your father has always been a controlling man. This is just his final power play.

ELIZABETH
(wiping her eyes)
But why? Why would he want to hurt us like this?

ROBERT
(leaning forward)
He's not trying to hurt us, Elizabeth. He's trying to manipulate us. To keep us under his thumb even after he's gone.

ELIZABETH
(confused)
I don't understand.

ROBERT
(sighing)
Think about it. By leaving the bulk of his fortune to charity, he's ensuring that we'll always be dependent on the company. On his legacy.

ELIZABETH
(realization dawning)
Oh... oh, I see.

ROBERT
(standing)
We can't let him get away with this, Elizabeth. We need to fight back.

ELIZABETH
(hesitantly)
But how? The will is already signed.

ROBERT
(smiling grimly)
There are ways, my dear. Legal channels we can explore. And if those don't work...

ELIZABETH
(alarmed)
Robert, what are you saying?

ROBERT
(placing a hand on her shoulder)
I'm saying that we need to be prepared to do whatever it takes to protect our future. Our children's future.

Elizabeth looks up at Robert, a mix of fear and determination in her eyes.

ELIZABETH
(softly)
Whatever it takes?

ROBERT
(nodding)
Whatever it takes.

FADE TO:

INT. BLACKWOOD MANSION - MICHAEL AND SARAH'S GUEST ROOM - NIGHT

Michael sits on the floor, leaning against the bed, a half-empty bottle of scotch beside him. Sarah kneels next to him, concern etched on her face.

SARAH
Michael, please. You've had enough.

MICHAEL
(slurring)
Have I? I don't think so, Sarah. I don't think I've had nearly enough to deal with this... this...

SARAH
(gently)
I know it's a shock, but drinking won't solve anything.

MICHAEL
(laughing bitterly)
No? Then what will? Because I'm fresh out of ideas.

SARAH
(taking his hand)
We'll figure it out together. We don't need your father's money.

MICHAEL
(pulling his hand away)
Don't we? Have you looked at our bank account lately?

SARAH
(frowning)
What do you mean?

MICHAEL
(taking another drink)
I mean, we're broke, Sarah. Or we will be, very soon.

SARAH
(shocked)
What? How? Your salary from the company...

MICHAEL
(interrupting)
Isn't enough to cover our debts. Not anymore.

SARAH
(realization dawning)
The gambling... oh, Michael. You promised me you'd stopped.

MICHAEL
(hanging his head)
I tried. I really did. But then there was that big deal with the Japanese investors, and I thought... I thought I could double our money, pay off everything...

SARAH
(closing her eyes)
How much, Michael?

MICHAEL
(softly)
Everything. Our savings, the kids' college funds... and then some.

Sarah sits back, stunned.

SARAH
What are we going to do?

MICHAEL
(laughing humorlessly)
Well, I was counting on dear old dad's inheritance to bail us out. So much for that plan.

SARAH
(determinedly)
We'll figure something out. We'll talk to your father, explain the situation...

MICHAEL
(bitterly)
Oh yes, I'm sure he'll be very understanding. "Sorry, Dad, I gambled away my future. Mind changing your will back?"

SARAH
(standing)
Then we'll find another way. We'll sell the house, cut back on expenses...

MICHAEL
(looking up at her)
It won't be enough, Sarah. You know it won't.

SARAH
(desperately)
Then what? What are you saying?

MICHAEL
(standing unsteadily)
I'm saying that maybe James and Robert have the right idea. Maybe it's time to take matters into our own hands.

SARAH
(backing away)
Michael, you can't be serious. Whatever they're planning... it's wrong.

MICHAEL
(advancing on her)
Is it? Is it wrong to want to protect our family? Our children?

SARAH
(tearfully)
Not like this, Michael. Please... there has to be another way.

MICHAEL
(softening)
I'm sorry, Sarah. But I don't think there is.

Sarah looks at Michael, fear and desperation in her eyes.

FADE TO:

INT. BLACKWOOD MANSION - MASTER BEDROOM - NIGHT

Edward sits on the edge of the bed, lost in thought. Margaret emerges from the en-suite bathroom, wearing a silk robe.

MARGARET
Edward? Are you alright?

EDWARD
(sighing)
I'm not sure, Margaret. I knew they wouldn't take it well, but...

MARGARET
(sitting beside him)
You couldn't have anticipated their reactions, dear. It was a shock to all of us.

EDWARD
(taking her hand)
Do you think I've made a mistake?

MARGARET
(hesitating)
I... I think your intentions are good, Edward. But perhaps the execution was a bit... harsh.

EDWARD
(standing)
Harsh? Margaret, I'm trying to teach them the value of hard work, of making their own way in the world.

MARGARET
(gently)
I know, dear. But they're our children. They're not perfect, but they're ours.

EDWARD
(pacing)
And that's precisely why I need to do this. They've become too dependent, too entitled. This is for their own good.

MARGARET
(worriedly)
But at what cost, Edward? You saw how they reacted. I'm afraid this might tear the family apart.

EDWARD
(stopping)
They'll come around, Margaret. They have to.

MARGARET
(standing)
And if they don't? Edward, I'm worried. The way James looked at you... the things Michael was muttering...

EDWARD
(waving a hand dismissively)
They were upset. They'll calm down once they've had time to process everything.

MARGARET
(moving to the window)
I hope you're right, Edward. But I can't shake this feeling... this dread.

EDWARD
(coming up behind her)
What are you saying, Margaret?

MARGARET
(turning to face him)
I'm saying that I'm scared, Edward. For you, for us, for our family.

Edward pulls Margaret into an embrace, but his eyes are troubled as he looks out the window into the dark night.

FADE TO BLACK.

INT. BLACKWOOD INDUSTRIES - BOARDROOM - DAY

A week has passed since the fateful dinner. Edward sits at the head of a long table, surrounded by his children and their spouses. The atmosphere is tense, with James, Elizabeth, and Michael avoiding eye contact with their father.

EDWARD
(clearing his throat)
Thank you all for coming. I thought it was time we discussed the changes to my will in a more... professional setting.

JAMES
(coldly)
Is there anything left to discuss, Father? You've made your decision quite clear.

EDWARD
(sighing)
James, I understand you're upset-

JAMES
(interrupting)
Upset? You've essentially disinherited us, Father. 'Upset' doesn't begin to cover it.

ELIZABETH
(softly)
Father, please. Can't we find a compromise?

EDWARD
(firmly)
My decision is final, Elizabeth. The Blackwood Foundation will receive the bulk of my estate.

MICHAEL
(bitterly)
And we get the scraps. How generous of you.

SARAH
(placing a hand on Michael's arm)
Michael, please...

EDWARD
(leaning forward)
I'm not doing this to punish you. I'm doing this because I believe it's the right thing to do.

VICTORIA
(coolly)
And your family's well-being doesn't factor into your definition of 'right,' Edward?

EDWARD
(frustrated)
Of course it does. But you're all successful adults. You don't need my money to survive.

ROBERT
(leaning forward)
With all due respect, Edward, that's not for you to decide.

EDWARD
(raising an eyebrow)
Isn't it? It's my money, after all.

JAMES
(standing abruptly)
Money that we helped you earn! I've given my life to this company, Father!

EDWARD
(calmly)
And you've been well-compensated for your work, James. Your shares in the company will remain yours.

ELIZABETH
(tearfully)
But Father, what about our children? Your grandchildren?

EDWARD
(softening slightly)
I've told you, Elizabeth. I've set up trust funds for each of them.

MICHAEL
(sarcastically)
Oh, how magnanimous of you.

EDWARD
(sternly)
That's enough, Michael. I've made my decision, and it's final.

A heavy silence falls over the room. James sits back down, his face red with anger.

VICTORIA
(smoothly)
Edward, surely there must be some room for negotiation. Perhaps a smaller percentage to charity?

EDWARD
(shaking his head)
The papers have been signed, Victoria. It's done.

ROBERT
(leaning forward)
And what if we were to challenge the will? Legally?

EDWARD
(narrowing his eyes)
You're welcome to try, Robert. But I assure you, everything is ironclad.

Another tense silence descends. Michael takes a long drink from his water glass, his hand shaking slightly.

SARAH
(hesitantly)
Edward, I know this is your decision, but... have you considered the impact this might have on the family? On relationships?

EDWARD
(sighing)
Of course I have, Sarah. But I believe this is necessary. For all of you.

JAMES
(bitterly)
Necessary? How is abandoning your family necessary?

EDWARD
(firmly)
I'm not abandoning anyone, James. I'm trying to ensure that you all learn to stand on your own two feet.

ELIZABETH
(tearfully)
But we're your children, Father. Don't we deserve...

EDWARD
(interrupting gently)
Deserve what, Elizabeth? To inherit wealth you didn't earn? To live off my legacy rather than create your own?

The room falls silent again. Edward looks around at his family, a mix of determination and sadness in his eyes.

EDWARD (CONT'D)
I know this is difficult for all of you to accept. But I truly believe this is the right thing to do. Not just for the world, but for our family.

JAMES
(standing)
Well, if that's all you have to say, Father, I think we're done here.

VICTORIA
(standing as well)
Yes, I believe we are.

ELIZABETH
(wiping her eyes)
Father, please... reconsider.

EDWARD
(softly)
I'm sorry, Elizabeth. My mind is made up.

MICHAEL
(standing unsteadily)
Well, this has been fun. Same time next week?

SARAH
(helping Michael up)
I think we should go, Michael.

As the family files out of the boardroom, Edward remains seated, watching them go with a mixture of sadness and resolve.

FADE TO:

INT. BLACKWOOD MANSION - EDWARD'S STUDY - NIGHT

Edward sits at his desk, reviewing some papers. A soft knock at the door interrupts him.

EDWARD
Come in.

Margaret enters, carrying a cup of tea.

MARGARET
I thought you might need this, dear.

EDWARD
(smiling tiredly)
Thank you, Margaret.

Margaret sets the tea down and perches on the edge of the desk.

MARGARET
How did the meeting go?

EDWARD
(sighing)
About as well as you'd expect. They're still angry, still hurt.

MARGARET
(gently)
Can you blame them, Edward? This is a lot for them to process.

EDWARD
(leaning back)
I know. But I truly believe this is the right thing to do, Margaret. For them, for the world.

MARGARET
(hesitating)
Edward... I'm worried.

EDWARD
(frowning)
About what?

MARGARET
(softly)
About the children. The way they looked at you today... I'm afraid they might do something drastic.

EDWARD
(dismissively)
They're upset, Margaret. They'll come around.

MARGARET
(standing)
I hope you're right, Edward. For all our sakes.

As Margaret leaves the study, Edward turns back to his papers, but his expression is troubled.

FADE TO:

INT. JAMES AND VICTORIA'S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT

James paces furiously while Victoria watches from the couch.

JAMES
We can't let him get away with this, Victoria. We have to do something.

VICTORIA
(calmly)
I agree, darling. But we need to be smart about this. Rash actions will only make things worse.

JAMES
(stopping)
What do you suggest?

VICTORIA
(standing)
We need allies. Your siblings... they're just as angry as we are. If we work together...

JAMES
(nodding slowly)
Yes... yes, you're right. We need a plan.

VICTORIA
(smiling)
Leave it to me, darling. I'll arrange everything.

As Victoria leaves the room, James turns to look out the window, a determined expression on his face.

FADE TO:

INT. ELIZABETH AND ROBERT'S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT

Elizabeth sits on the bed, crying softly. Robert enters, his face grim.

ROBERT
Elizabeth, we need to talk.

ELIZABETH
(looking up)
About what?

ROBERT
(sitting beside her)
About your father. About what we're going to do.

ELIZABETH
(fearfully)
What do you mean, 'do'?

ROBERT
(taking her hand)
Your father has left us no choice, Elizabeth. We need to take action.

ELIZABETH
(pulling away)
Robert, no. Whatever you're thinking... it's wrong.

ROBERT
(firmly)
Is it wrong to want to protect our family? Our future?

Elizabeth looks at Robert, conflict clear in her eyes.

FADE TO:

INT. MICHAEL AND SARAH'S HOUSE - KITCHEN - NIGHT

Michael sits at the table, a bottle of whiskey in front of him. Sarah enters, her face pale.

SARAH
Michael, we need to talk about this.

MICHAEL
(without looking up)
About what? How my father has ruined us?

SARAH
(sitting across from him)
About what we're going to do. Michael... I'm scared.

MICHAEL
(looking up)
Of what?

SARAH
(softly)
Of what you might do. What your siblings might do.

MICHAEL
(bitterly)
Whatever it takes, Sarah. That's what it's come to.

Sarah reaches across the table, taking Michael's hand.

SARAH
Please, Michael. There has to be another way.

Michael looks at Sarah, his eyes haunted.

FADE TO:

INT. BLACKWOOD MANSION - MASTER BEDROOM - NIGHT

Edward and Margaret prepare for bed. Edward notices Margaret's worried expression.

EDWARD
What's wrong, my dear?

MARGARET
(hesitating)
Edward... I can't shake this feeling. This dread.

EDWARD
(embracing her)
Everything will be alright, Margaret. You'll see.

As they climb into bed, the camera pans out of the window, showing the vast Blackwood estate under a starry sky.

FADE TO BLACK.

THE END.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A married couple is having a fight about the wife's infidelity. Things get heated, and then the husband confesses to having multiple affairs. Suddenly both of them stop talking. There is heavy silence between the two spouses.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 4000 words.
response:
Here's a well-structured screenplay based on the given writing prompt:

INT. SUBURBAN HOME - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT

The living room of a middle-class suburban home. It's tastefully decorated with a mix of modern and traditional elements. A large sectional sofa dominates the space, facing a flat-screen TV mounted on the wall. Family photos adorn the side tables and walls.

SARAH MITCHELL (35), an attractive woman with shoulder-length brown hair, paces back and forth in front of the sofa. She's wearing business attire ‚Äì a pencil skirt and blouse ‚Äì suggesting she's just returned from work. Her face is a mix of guilt and defiance.

DAVID MITCHELL (38), a handsome man with salt-and-pepper hair, sits rigidly on the edge of the sofa. He's wearing casual clothes ‚Äì jeans and a polo shirt. His jaw is clenched, and his eyes follow Sarah's movements with barely contained anger.

DAVID
(voice tight with emotion)
How long has this been going on, Sarah?

Sarah stops pacing and turns to face David. She takes a deep breath before answering.

SARAH
(hesitantly)
Three months.

David stands up abruptly, his fists clenched at his sides.

DAVID
(shouting)
Three months? You've been lying to me for three months?

Sarah flinches at the volume of his voice but stands her ground.

SARAH
(defensively)
I didn't mean for it to happen, David. It just... did.

David laughs bitterly, running a hand through his hair in frustration.

DAVID
Oh, it just happened? Like you accidentally fell into bed with another man?

SARAH
(angrily)
Don't be crude. It wasn't like that.

DAVID
Then what was it like, Sarah? Please, enlighten me.

Sarah moves to sit on the sofa, suddenly looking exhausted.

SARAH
(softly)
I was lonely, David. You're always working late, always on business trips. We barely see each other anymore.

David's anger seems to deflate slightly at her words. He sits down on the opposite end of the sofa, maintaining distance between them.

DAVID
(quietly)
That doesn't justify cheating, Sarah.

SARAH
(nodding)
I know. I'm not trying to justify it. I'm just... trying to explain.

They sit in silence for a moment, the weight of Sarah's confession hanging heavy in the air.

DAVID
(breaking the silence)
Who is he?

Sarah looks up, meeting David's gaze.

SARAH
Does it matter?

DAVID
(firmly)
Yes, it matters. I want to know who's been sleeping with my wife.

Sarah sighs, looking down at her hands.

SARAH
It's... it's Mark from accounting.

David's eyes widen in shock and betrayal.

DAVID
(incredulously)
Mark? My colleague Mark? The one we had dinner with last month?

Sarah nods, unable to meet David's eyes.

SARAH
(whispering)
Yes.

David stands up abruptly, pacing the room as Sarah had done earlier.

DAVID
(angrily)
I can't believe this. My own colleague. In our home. At our dinner table.

SARAH
(defensively)
It wasn't like that, David. We never... not here. Never in our home.

DAVID
(sarcastically)
Oh, well that makes it all better then, doesn't it?

Sarah stands up, her own anger rising to match David's.

SARAH
(shouting)
What do you want me to say, David? That I'm sorry? I am sorry. I'm sorry I hurt you. I'm sorry I betrayed your trust. But I'm not sorry for feeling something again.

David turns to face her, his expression a mix of hurt and anger.

DAVID
Feeling something? What's that supposed to mean?

SARAH
(exasperated)
It means I felt alive again, David. Desired. Appreciated. When was the last time you looked at me the way you used to?

David's anger seems to falter for a moment, replaced by a flicker of guilt.

DAVID
(softly)
I didn't realize...

SARAH
(interrupting)
No, you didn't. You were too busy with your work, your ambitions. I became an afterthought.

David's guilt quickly turns back to anger.

DAVID
(defensively)
I was working hard for us, Sarah. For our future. For the family we talked about having.

SARAH
(bitterly)
What family, David? We're hardly even a couple anymore.

David turns away, running his hands through his hair in frustration.

DAVID
(muttering)
This is unbelievable.

Sarah takes a step towards him, her voice softening.

SARAH
David, I know I made a mistake. A terrible mistake. But we can work through this. We can fix this.

David turns back to face her, his expression hard.

DAVID
(coldly)
Can we, Sarah? Can we really?

Sarah reaches out to touch his arm, but David pulls away.

SARAH
(pleadingly)
Yes, we can. If we both want to. Do you want to?

David doesn't answer immediately. He walks over to the window, staring out into the darkness.

DAVID
(quietly)
I don't know.

Sarah's face falls at his words. She sits back down on the sofa, her shoulders slumping in defeat.

SARAH
(softly)
What do you mean, you don't know?

David continues to stare out the window, his back to Sarah.

DAVID
(sighing)
I mean... I don't know if I can forgive this, Sarah.

Sarah stands up, anger flaring in her eyes once more.

SARAH
(heatedly)
You don't know if you can forgive me? After everything we've been through? After fifteen years of marriage?

David turns to face her, his expression pained.

DAVID
Fifteen years that apparently meant nothing to you when you decided to sleep with Mark.

SARAH
(shouting)
That's not fair! You have no idea what I've been going through!

DAVID
(shouting back)
And you have no idea what I've been going through!

They stand there, facing each other, both breathing heavily from their outburst.

SARAH
(breaking the silence)
What's that supposed to mean?

David's face suddenly changes, a look of guilt washing over his features.

DAVID
(quietly)
Nothing. Forget it.

Sarah takes a step closer to him, her eyes narrowing suspiciously.

SARAH
No, David. What did you mean by that?

David turns away, unable to meet her gaze.

DAVID
(muttering)
It's nothing, Sarah. Drop it.

Sarah grabs his arm, forcing him to face her.

SARAH
(firmly)
No, I won't drop it. What aren't you telling me, David?

David pulls his arm away, walking to the other side of the room.

DAVID
(defensively)
You're not the only one who's felt lonely, Sarah.

Sarah's eyes widen as realization dawns on her face.

SARAH
(shocked)
What are you saying, David?

David turns to face her, his expression a mix of guilt and defiance.

DAVID
I'm saying... I'm saying you're not the only one who's made mistakes.

Sarah stumbles backward, sitting heavily on the sofa.

SARAH
(whisper)
You've cheated on me?

David nods slowly, unable to meet her eyes.

SARAH (CONT'D)
(voice rising)
How many times? With who?

David hesitates, clearly uncomfortable.

DAVID
(quietly)
Does it matter?

SARAH
(angrily)
Of course it matters! You just spent the last hour crucifying me for my affair, and now you're telling me you've done the same thing?

David sits down in an armchair across from Sarah, his head in his hands.

DAVID
(muffled)
It wasn't the same thing.

Sarah stands up, her anger palpable.

SARAH
(shouting)
How was it not the same thing? Explain it to me, David!

David looks up at her, his eyes red-rimmed.

DAVID
(softly)
It wasn't just once, Sarah.

Sarah's anger seems to deflate, replaced by shock.

SARAH
(whisper)
What?

DAVID
(sighing)
It wasn't just once. And it wasn't just one person.

Sarah collapses back onto the sofa, her face pale.

SARAH
(stunned)
How many?

David stands up, moving to the window again.

DAVID
(quietly)
Three. Over the past two years.

Sarah sits in stunned silence, processing this information.

SARAH
(voice shaking)
Two years? You've been cheating on me for two years?

David nods, still facing the window.

DAVID
(softly)
Yes.

Sarah stands up abruptly, grabbing a vase from the side table and hurling it at the wall. It shatters, pieces scattering across the floor.

SARAH
(screaming)
You hypocrite! You goddamn hypocrite!

David turns to face her, his expression a mix of guilt and anger.

DAVID
(defensively)
I never meant for it to happen, Sarah. Just like you didn't mean for your affair to happen.

SARAH
(furiously)
Don't you dare compare my one mistake to your... your serial cheating!

DAVID
(angrily)
Why not? Cheating is cheating, isn't it? Or does the fact that you only slept with one man somehow make you morally superior?

Sarah grabs another decorative object, ready to throw it.

SARAH
(through gritted teeth)
At least I had the decency to feel guilty about it!

David takes a step towards her, his voice rising.

DAVID
Who says I didn't feel guilty? You think this has been easy for me?

Sarah lowers her arm, placing the object back on the table.

SARAH
(bitterly)
Apparently it was easy enough for you to do it three times.

David runs his hands through his hair in frustration.

DAVID
(exasperated)
It wasn't like that, Sarah. It wasn't... it wasn't about the sex.

Sarah laughs bitterly.

SARAH
(sarcastically)
Oh, please. Enlighten me, David. What was it about then?

David sits back down in the armchair, suddenly looking exhausted.

DAVID
(quietly)
It was about feeling something. Anything.

Sarah's anger seems to falter slightly at his words.

SARAH
(softly)
What do you mean?

David looks up at her, his eyes filled with a mixture of pain and regret.

DAVID
I mean... I felt like I was drowning, Sarah. In work, in responsibilities, in the expectations everyone had of me. Including you.

Sarah sits down on the sofa, her anger giving way to confusion.

SARAH
(confused)
What expectations?

DAVID
(sighing)
To be the perfect husband. The successful businessman. The future father. I felt like I was losing myself under the weight of it all.

Sarah leans forward, her voice softening.

SARAH
Why didn't you talk to me about this?

David laughs humorlessly.

DAVID
(bitterly)
When, Sarah? When you were busy with your own career? When we were both too exhausted to do more than eat dinner and fall into bed?

Sarah looks down at her hands, guilt washing over her face.

SARAH
(softly)
I didn't realize...

DAVID
(interrupting)
No, you didn't. Just like I didn't realize how lonely you were feeling.

They sit in silence for a moment, the weight of their confessions hanging heavy in the air.

SARAH
(breaking the silence)
So what happens now?

David looks up, meeting her gaze.

DAVID
(quietly)
I don't know.

Sarah stands up, walking over to the broken vase and kneeling to pick up the pieces.

SARAH
(as she cleans)
We can't go back, can we?

David watches her for a moment before standing up to help.

DAVID
(kneeling beside her)
No, I don't think we can.

They clean up the broken pieces in silence, both lost in their thoughts.

SARAH
(softly)
Do you still love me, David?

David pauses in his cleaning, looking at Sarah.

DAVID
(hesitantly)
I... I think I do. But I'm not sure if that's enough anymore.

Sarah nods, understanding in her eyes.

SARAH
I know what you mean.

They finish cleaning up the broken vase, standing up and facing each other.

DAVID
(quietly)
What do you want to do, Sarah?

Sarah takes a deep breath, considering her words carefully.

SARAH
I think... I think we need some time apart. To figure out what we really want.

David nods slowly, a mix of relief and sadness on his face.

DAVID
I think you're right.

Sarah moves towards the stairs, pausing at the bottom.

SARAH
(turning back)
I'll pack a bag. I can stay with my sister for a while.

David nods, watching her ascend the stairs.

INT. SUBURBAN HOME - BEDROOM - NIGHT

Sarah enters the bedroom, moving to the closet and pulling out a suitcase. She begins to pack clothes methodically, her movements automatic and devoid of emotion.

David appears in the doorway, leaning against the frame and watching her pack.

DAVID
(softly)
I'm sorry, Sarah.

Sarah pauses in her packing, looking up at him.

SARAH
(sadly)
I'm sorry too, David.

They look at each other for a long moment, years of love and hurt passing between them.

DAVID
(breaking the silence)
Do you think we can fix this?

Sarah zips up her suitcase, considering his question.

SARAH
(honestly)
I don't know. But I think we owe it to ourselves to try.

David nods, moving to help her with the suitcase.

DAVID
(as they walk downstairs)
Maybe we could try counseling?

Sarah nods, a small smile on her face.

SARAH
I think that's a good idea.

They reach the front door, both hesitating.

SARAH (CONT'D)
(softly)
I'll call you in a few days?

David nods, opening the door for her.

DAVID
Take care of yourself, Sarah.

Sarah steps out onto the porch, turning back to face David.

SARAH
You too, David.

They share one last look before Sarah turns and walks to her car. David watches from the doorway as she drives away, the weight of their confessions and the uncertainty of their future hanging in the air.

INT. SARAH'S CAR - NIGHT

Sarah drives through the quiet suburban streets, tears streaming down her face. She reaches a stoplight and takes a moment to compose herself, looking at her reflection in the rearview mirror.

SARAH
(to herself)
You can get through this. One day at a time.

The light turns green, and Sarah continues driving, her expression determined despite her tears.

INT. SUBURBAN HOME - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT

David closes the front door and leans against it, closing his eyes and taking a deep breath. He looks around the empty living room, the silence deafening.

He walks over to the side table, picking up a framed photo of him and Sarah on their wedding day. He stares at it for a long moment before placing it face down on the table.

DAVID
(to himself)
One day at a time.

He walks to the kitchen, opening a cabinet and pulling out a bottle of whiskey. He pours himself a glass and sits at the kitchen table, staring into space.

FADE TO BLACK.

INT. THERAPIST'S OFFICE - DAY - TWO WEEKS LATER

A cozy, professional office with comfortable chairs and soft lighting. DR. LISA THOMPSON (50s), a kind-looking woman with glasses, sits in an armchair, notepad in hand. Sarah and David sit on a small sofa across from her, a noticeable gap between them.

DR. THOMPSON
Thank you both for coming today. I know this isn't easy, but it's a positive step that you're here together.

Sarah and David nod, both looking uncomfortable.

DR. THOMPSON (CONT'D)
Why don't we start by talking about what brought you here?

Sarah and David exchange a look, silently debating who should speak first.

SARAH
(hesitantly)
We... we both had affairs.

Dr. Thompson nods, her expression neutral.

DR. THOMPSON
I see. And how has this affected your relationship?

DAVID
(bitterly)
How hasn't it affected our relationship?

Dr. Thompson turns her attention to David.

DR. THOMPSON
David, can you elaborate on that?

David sighs, running a hand through his hair.

DAVID
It's like... everything we thought we knew about our marriage has been turned upside down. I don't know how to trust Sarah anymore, and I know she feels the same about me.

Sarah nods in agreement.

SARAH
It's true. I feel like I'm living with a stranger sometimes.

DR. THOMPSON
These feelings are normal after such a significant breach of trust. But the fact that you're both here shows that you want to work on your relationship. That's a good starting point.

Sarah and David exchange a look, a glimmer of hope passing between them.

DR. THOMPSON (CONT'D)
Let's talk about communication. How would you describe your communication before the affairs came to light?

SARAH
(hesitantly)
I think... I think we stopped really talking to each other a long time ago.

David nods in agreement.

DAVID
We were like ships passing in the night. Always busy, always distracted.

DR. THOMPSON
And how do you think this lack of communication contributed to the affairs?

Sarah and David are silent for a moment, considering the question.

SARAH
(softly)
I think... I felt like David didn't see me anymore. Didn't hear me.

DAVID
(nodding)
And I felt overwhelmed and unable to express my own struggles.

Dr. Thompson makes a note on her pad.

DR. THOMPSON
It sounds like you both felt isolated within your marriage. Let's work on rebuilding that connection. I want you to try an exercise.

Sarah and David look at her expectantly.

DR. THOMPSON (CONT'D)
I want you to turn and face each other.

Sarah and David hesitantly turn on the sofa to face one another.

DR. THOMPSON (CONT'D)
Now, I want you to look into each other's eyes and take turns sharing one thing you appreciate about the other person. Sarah, why don't you start?

Sarah takes a deep breath, meeting David's gaze.

SARAH
(softly)
I appreciate your dedication. To your work, to our home... to me, even when I didn't see it.

David's expression softens slightly.

DAVID
I appreciate your strength. You've always been the one to push us forward, to strive for better.

Dr. Thompson nods encouragingly.

DR. THOMPSON
Good. Now, I want you to share one regret you have about your actions.

Sarah and David both tense up slightly.

SARAH
(voice shaking)
I regret betraying your trust. I regret hurting you so deeply.

David's eyes fill with tears.

DAVID
(quietly)
I regret taking you for granted. I regret not being the husband you deserved.

Dr. Thompson allows a moment of silence as Sarah and David process their emotions.

DR. THOMPSON
Thank you both for your honesty. This is just the beginning of the work we'll be doing together. It won't be easy, but if you're both committed to rebuilding your relationship, it is possible.

Sarah and David turn back to face Dr. Thompson, both looking emotionally drained but slightly more hopeful.

DR. THOMPSON (CONT'D)
For our next session, I'd like you to work on a communication exercise at home. Each day, I want you to set aside 15 minutes to talk to each other without distractions. No phones, no TV, just the two of you. Can you commit to that?

Sarah and David exchange a look before nodding.

SARAH
We can try.

DAVID
Yes, we'll do it.

DR. THOMPSON
Excellent. Remember, healing takes time. Be patient with yourselves and with each other.

Sarah and David stand up, shaking Dr. Thompson's hand before leaving the office.

INT. HALLWAY OUTSIDE THERAPIST'S OFFICE - DAY

Sarah and David stand awkwardly in the hallway, neither sure what to say.

SARAH
(breaking the silence)
That was... intense.

David nods, looking at Sarah.

DAVID
Yeah, it was. But... maybe helpful?

Sarah gives him a small smile.

SARAH
I think so. It's a start, at least.

They begin walking towards the elevator.

DAVID
(hesitantly)
Do you... do you want to grab a coffee? We could start that communication exercise.

Sarah considers for a moment before nodding.

SARAH
I'd like that.

As they step into the elevator, there's a sense of cautious hope between them. The doors close, leaving them to face their future together, one step at a time.

FADE TO BLACK.

THE END

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A person packs her belongings into card boxes because she plans to move into a new apartment. She finds a photo of her and her best friend. A moment of happiness on her face is quickly substituted for a sad, nostalgic smile.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 4000 words.
response:
Here's a well-structured screenplay based on the given writing prompt:

INT. SARAH'S APARTMENT - DAY

Sunlight streams through half-open blinds, illuminating a cozy but cluttered living room. Cardboard boxes are scattered around, some already sealed, others still open and waiting to be filled.

SARAH (late 20s, brunette, casually dressed) stands in the middle of the room, hands on her hips, surveying the chaos around her. She takes a deep breath and runs a hand through her messy hair.

SARAH
(to herself)
Alright, Sarah. You can do this. One box at a time.

She moves to a bookshelf and starts pulling books off, placing them carefully into an open box. As she works, her phone buzzes. She glances at it, sees the caller ID, and answers.

SARAH (CONT'D)
Hey, Mom.

MOM (V.O.)
Hi, sweetie. How's the packing going?

SARAH
(sighing)
It's going. Slowly but surely.

Sarah continues to pack as she talks, moving from the bookshelf to a nearby desk.

MOM (V.O.)
Do you need any help? I could come over...

SARAH
(interrupting)
No, no. I've got it under control. Thanks, though.

MOM (V.O.)
Are you sure? It's a big job, and-

SARAH
(firmly)
Mom, I'm fine. Really. I'll call if I need anything, okay?

MOM (V.O.)
(resigned)
Okay, honey. Just remember, there's no shame in asking for help.

SARAH
(softening)
I know, Mom. Love you.

MOM (V.O.)
Love you too. Good luck with the packing.

Sarah ends the call and sets her phone down, looking around the room with a sigh.

SARAH
(muttering)
Maybe I should've taken her up on that offer.

She shakes her head and returns to packing, this time tackling a drawer full of papers and miscellaneous items.

As she sorts through the drawer, she pulls out a small photo album. She pauses, running her fingers over the cover before opening it.

CLOSE ON: A photo of Sarah and another young woman, both laughing and covered in paint. They have their arms around each other, clearly best friends.

Sarah's face breaks into a wide smile as she looks at the photo. Then, slowly, the smile fades into something more melancholic.

SARAH (CONT'D)
(softly)
Oh, Lily...

She traces the outline of her friend's face in the photo, lost in thought. After a moment, she shakes herself out of it and starts to close the album. As she does, a loose photo slips out and flutters to the floor.

Sarah bends to pick it up, turning it over in her hands. It's another photo of her and Lily, this time at a beach. They're building a sandcastle together, both grinning at the camera.

FLASHBACK:

EXT. BEACH - DAY (5 YEARS AGO)

The sun is high in the sky, and the beach is crowded with people enjoying the summer day. Sarah and LILY (mid-20s, blonde, athletic) are kneeling in the sand, working on an elaborate sandcastle.

LILY
(laughing)
I think we might have gotten a little carried away.

SARAH
(grinning)
No such thing! This is going to be the best sandcastle this beach has ever seen.

Lily adds a small shell to one of the towers.

LILY
There. Perfect.

Sarah stands up, brushing sand off her knees.

SARAH
Wait! We need a picture of this masterpiece.

She fumbles in her beach bag for her phone.

LILY
(teasing)
You and your pictures. We're not all Instagram models, you know.

SARAH
(rolling her eyes)
Oh, shut up. You love it.

Sarah holds up her phone, trying to get both them and the sandcastle in frame.

SARAH (CONT'D)
Scoot closer!

Lily obliges, throwing an arm around Sarah's shoulders. They both grin at the camera as Sarah takes the picture.

SARAH (CONT'D)
(looking at the result)
Oh, that's a good one. We look cute.

LILY
(peering at the phone)
We always look cute.

They share a laugh, then turn back to their sandcastle.

LILY (CONT'D)
So, what's next for this architectural marvel?

SARAH
(pondering)
Hmm... I'm thinking a moat.

LILY
(nodding seriously)
Good call. Every castle needs a good defense system.

They start digging around the base of their castle, occasionally splashing each other with water and laughing.

END FLASHBACK

INT. SARAH'S APARTMENT - DAY (PRESENT)

Sarah is still holding the photo, lost in the memory. She blinks rapidly, fighting back tears.

SARAH
(whispering)
I miss you, Lil.

She takes a deep breath, composing herself. Then she carefully tucks the loose photo back into the album and places it in one of the boxes.

Just then, there's a knock at the door. Sarah looks up, startled out of her reverie.

SARAH (CONT'D)
Coming!

She makes her way through the maze of boxes to the door and opens it. On the other side is ALEX (early 30s, tall, friendly face), holding a paper bag.

ALEX
(grinning)
I come bearing gifts of caffeine and sugar.

Sarah's face lights up.

SARAH
Alex! You're a lifesaver.

She steps back to let him in. Alex surveys the room as he enters, whistling low.

ALEX
Wow, you weren't kidding about the chaos.

SARAH
(grimacing)
Yeah, it's... a process.

Alex sets the bag down on a clear spot on the coffee table and starts pulling out coffee cups and a box of donuts.

ALEX
Well, that's why I'm here. Fuel up, and then we'll tackle this together.

Sarah gratefully accepts the coffee he hands her, taking a long sip.

SARAH
(sighing contentedly)
You're the best, you know that?

ALEX
(mock preening)
I've been told once or twice.

They share a laugh, then settle on the couch, careful not to disturb the precariously balanced boxes around them.

ALEX (CONT'D)
So, how's it really going? And don't say 'fine' because I know that's your default answer.

Sarah takes another sip of coffee, considering her answer.

SARAH
It's... harder than I expected. Not just the physical work, but...

She trails off, gesturing vaguely around the room.

ALEX
(gently)
But?

SARAH
(sighing)
But going through all this stuff, all these memories... It's bringing up a lot.

Alex nods understandingly.

ALEX
That's natural. You've lived here for what, five years?

SARAH
Almost six.

ALEX
That's a lot of life to pack up.

Sarah nods, her gaze drifting to the box where she put the photo album.

SARAH
I found some old photos earlier. Of me and Lily.

Alex's expression softens with sympathy.

ALEX
Oh, Sarah...

SARAH
(forcing a smile)
It's okay. It was nice to see them, actually. To remember the good times.

ALEX
(carefully)
Have you... heard from her at all?

Sarah shakes her head, her smile fading.

SARAH
Not since... you know. The fight.

FLASHBACK:

INT. SARAH'S APARTMENT - NIGHT (2 YEARS AGO)

The apartment looks different - more lived-in, with photos and knick-knacks everywhere. Sarah and Lily are facing each other, both looking upset.

LILY
(angrily)
I can't believe you're doing this!

SARAH
(defensive)
Doing what? Following my dreams?

LILY
Abandoning everything! Abandoning me!

SARAH
(exasperated)
I'm not abandoning anything, Lily. It's a job opportunity. A really good one.

LILY
On the other side of the country!

SARAH
(pleading)
It's not forever. And we'll still talk all the time. Nothing has to change.

LILY
(bitterly)
Everything's already changing. You're just too selfish to see it.

Sarah recoils as if slapped.

SARAH
(hurt)
Selfish? How is wanting to advance my career selfish?

LILY
Because you're only thinking about yourself! What about our plans? What about all the things we were going to do together?

SARAH
(frustrated)
We can still do those things! Just... not right away. Why can't you be happy for me?

LILY
(coldly)
Because I know you. You'll go off to your fancy new job and forget all about us here. About me.

SARAH
(incredulous)
How can you say that? You're my best friend!

LILY
(sadly)
Am I? Because right now, it feels like I'm just something you're leaving behind.

She turns and storms out of the apartment, slamming the door behind her. Sarah stands there, stunned and hurt.

END FLASHBACK

INT. SARAH'S APARTMENT - DAY (PRESENT)

Sarah blinks, coming back to the present. Alex is watching her with concern.

ALEX
You okay?

SARAH
(forcing a smile)
Yeah, just... remembering.

ALEX
(gently)
You know, it's not too late. You could reach out to her.

Sarah shakes her head, her expression hardening slightly.

SARAH
No. She made her feelings pretty clear. And besides, that was two years ago. She's probably moved on with her life.

ALEX
(cautiously)
And have you?

Sarah doesn't answer immediately, her gaze drifting around the room.

SARAH
(softly)
I'm trying to.

Alex reaches out and squeezes her hand comfortingly.

ALEX
Well, that's what today is about, right? Moving forward.

Sarah nods, squeezing his hand back.

SARAH
Yeah. You're right.

She takes a deep breath, then stands up, pulling Alex with her.

SARAH (CONT'D)
(with forced cheerfulness)
Alright, enough moping. We've got work to do.

ALEX
(saluting playfully)
Yes, ma'am. Where do we start?

Sarah looks around, considering.

SARAH
How about the bedroom? I haven't even started in there yet.

ALEX
(dramatically)
Into the unknown we go!

Sarah laughs, leading the way to the bedroom. As they pass the box with the photo album, she pauses for a moment, her hand hovering over it. Then she shakes her head and continues on.

INT. SARAH'S BEDROOM - DAY

The bedroom is just as cluttered as the living room, with clothes strewn about and more half-packed boxes. Sarah and Alex stand in the doorway, surveying the scene.

ALEX
(whistling)
Well, this is... impressive.

SARAH
(grimacing)
Yeah, I may have been avoiding this room.

ALEX
(teasingly)
No kidding. Did a tornado hit in here?

Sarah playfully swats his arm.

SARAH
Hey, no judging. I've been busy.

ALEX
(raising an eyebrow)
Busy avoiding packing, you mean?

SARAH
(laughing)
Shut up and help me with these clothes.

They start sorting through the piles of clothes, creating separate stacks for keeping, donating, and throwing away.

ALEX
(holding up a sparkly top)
Please tell me you're keeping this work of art.

SARAH
(groaning)
Oh god, I forgot I even had that. That's from my 'going out' phase in college.

ALEX
(grinning)
I bet you rocked it.

SARAH
(laughing)
I looked like a disco ball threw up on me.

She snatches the top from him and tosses it in the donation pile.

As they continue sorting, Sarah comes across a small jewelry box. She opens it, revealing a delicate silver bracelet with a heart charm.

SARAH (CONT'D)
(softly)
Oh...

ALEX
(noticing her pause)
What is it?

Sarah holds up the bracelet.

SARAH
Lily gave me this for my 21st birthday. We got matching ones.

FLASHBACK:

INT. SARAH'S OLD APARTMENT - NIGHT (7 YEARS AGO)

The room is decorated with balloons and streamers. A banner reading "HAPPY 21ST BIRTHDAY SARAH!" hangs on the wall. Sarah, looking younger and more carefree, is sitting on the couch, surrounded by gift wrap and presents. Lily sits next to her, holding a small wrapped box.

LILY
(excitedly)
Okay, last one!

She hands the box to Sarah, who takes it with a grin.

SARAH
Ooh, it's tiny. Is it jewelry?

LILY
(teasingly)
You'll have to open it and see, won't you?

Sarah laughs and carefully unwraps the box. She opens it to reveal the silver bracelet.

SARAH
(gasping)
Oh, Lily... it's beautiful!

She lifts the bracelet out of the box, admiring the way it catches the light.

LILY
(smiling)
Look at the charm.

Sarah examines the heart charm more closely. On one side, it's engraved with an 'S', and on the other, an 'L'.

SARAH
(touched)
Our initials...

LILY
I have one too.

She holds up her wrist, showing an identical bracelet.

LILY (CONT'D)
I thought... well, we're always talking about how we're going to be friends forever, right? So I wanted us to have something to remind us of that. No matter where life takes us.

Sarah's eyes fill with tears.

SARAH
(emotionally)
Lily... I don't know what to say.

LILY
(softly)
You don't have to say anything. Just promise me we'll always be there for each other, okay?

SARAH
(nodding)
I promise. Best friends forever.

They hug tightly, both a little teary-eyed.

END FLASHBACK

INT. SARAH'S BEDROOM - DAY (PRESENT)

Sarah is still holding the bracelet, lost in thought. Alex watches her, his expression sympathetic.

ALEX
(gently)
You miss her, don't you?

Sarah nods, not trusting herself to speak. She clears her throat after a moment.

SARAH
(quietly)
We were supposed to be friends forever, you know? We had all these plans...

ALEX
(carefully)
What happened?

Sarah sighs, setting the bracelet down on the dresser.

SARAH
Life happened. I got the job offer in New York, and Lily... she didn't take it well.

ALEX
(understanding)
Ah. The fight you mentioned earlier?

Sarah nods.

SARAH
She accused me of abandoning her, of being selfish. Said I'd forget all about her once I left.

ALEX
(frowning)
That's not fair. It was a great opportunity for you.

SARAH
(sighing)
I know. And part of me was so angry at her for not being supportive. But another part...

She trails off, looking at the bracelet again.

SARAH (CONT'D)
Another part wonders if she was right. If I did abandon her.

ALEX
(firmly)
Hey, no. You didn't abandon anyone. You made a choice to pursue your career, and there's nothing wrong with that.

SARAH
(uncertainly)
But what if I could have tried harder? To make it work, to keep in touch?

ALEX
(gently)
Relationships are a two-way street, Sarah. If she wanted to stay in touch, she could have reached out too.

Sarah nods, but she doesn't look entirely convinced.

SARAH
I guess. It's just... seeing all these memories, all these reminders of our friendship... It makes me wonder what could have been different.

ALEX
(thoughtfully)
You know, it's not too late to find out.

SARAH
(surprised)
What do you mean?

ALEX
I mean, you could reach out to her. See if she's willing to talk.

Sarah shakes her head, looking scared.

SARAH
I don't know, Alex. It's been two years. What if she doesn't want to hear from me?

ALEX
(encouragingly)
But what if she does? What if she's been thinking about you too, wondering if she should reach out?

Sarah bites her lip, considering.

SARAH
I wouldn't even know what to say.

ALEX
(smiling)
How about 'Hello'? It's a good place to start.

Sarah laughs softly, then looks at the bracelet again. After a moment, she picks it up and fastens it around her wrist.

SARAH
(determinedly)
Okay. I'll think about it.

ALEX
(grinning)
That's my girl. Now, shall we continue this archaeological dig through your closet?

Sarah laughs, the tension broken.

SARAH
Yes, please. And if you find any more embarrassing clothes from my past, feel free to throw them directly in the trash.

They return to sorting through the clothes, the mood lighter than before. As they work, Sarah occasionally touches the bracelet on her wrist, a small smile playing on her lips.

Time passes, shown through a series of quick cuts of Sarah and Alex packing different areas of the bedroom. Finally, they stand back, surveying their work. The room is now mostly packed, with neat stacks of boxes lining the walls.

ALEX
(wiping his brow)
I think we can officially declare this room conquered.

SARAH
(gratefully)
I couldn't have done it without you. Seriously, thank you.

ALEX
(smiling)
What are friends for? Now, I don't know about you, but I'm starving. Pizza?

SARAH
(enthusiastically)
God, yes. I'll order.

They make their way back to the living room. Sarah grabs her phone and starts to dial, then pauses, looking at the box where she put the photo album earlier.

SARAH (CONT'D)
(hesitantly)
Hey, Alex?

ALEX
(looking up)
Yeah?

SARAH
(taking a deep breath)
I think... I think I'm going to try calling Lily. After we eat.

Alex's face breaks into a wide smile.

ALEX
(warmly)
I think that's a great idea.

Sarah nods, a mix of nervousness and determination on her face.

SARAH
Yeah. Yeah, I think so too.

She turns back to her phone, dialing the pizza place. As she places their order, she keeps glancing at the box with the photo album, a spark of hope in her eyes.

FADE TO BLACK.

INT. SARAH'S APARTMENT - EVENING

The living room is bathed in the warm glow of the setting sun. Empty pizza boxes are stacked on the coffee table, and Sarah and Alex are lounging on the couch, looking satisfied.

ALEX
(patting his stomach)
I think I'm in a food coma.

SARAH
(laughing)
Same. But it was so worth it.

She glances at her phone, which is sitting on the arm of the couch. Her expression turns nervous.

ALEX
(noticing her look)
You okay?

SARAH
(sighing)
Yeah, just... psyching myself up, I guess.

ALEX
(encouragingly)
For calling Lily?

Sarah nods, picking up her phone and turning it over in her hands.

SARAH
What if she doesn't want to talk to me? What if she hangs up as soon as she hears my voice?

ALEX
(gently)
Then at least you'll know you tried. And hey, maybe she'll be happy to hear from you.

SARAH
(uncertainly)
Maybe...

She takes a deep breath, then starts scrolling through her contacts. She pauses when she gets to Lily's name.

SARAH (CONT'D)
(surprised)
Her number's still in here. I thought I'd deleted it.

ALEX
(smiling)
Maybe part of you always knew you'd want to reach out someday.

Sarah nods, her thumb hovering over the call button. She looks at Alex, who gives her an encouraging nod.

SARAH
(taking a deep breath)
Okay. Here goes nothing.

She presses the call button and puts the phone to her ear. The room is silent as they listen to it ring.

Once... twice... three times...

Sarah's face falls slightly with each unanswered ring. Just as she's about to hang up, there's a click.

LILY (V.O.)
(hesitantly)
Hello?

Sarah's eyes widen in surprise. She hadn't really expected Lily to answer.

SARAH
(nervously)
Lily? Hi... it's Sarah.

There's a pause on the other end of the line. Sarah holds her breath, her knuckles white as she grips the phone.

LILY (V.O.)
(softly)
Sarah... I didn't expect to hear from you.

SARAH
(quickly)
I know, I'm sorry. I just... I found some old photos today, and I've been thinking about you, and I... I miss you.

Another pause. Sarah closes her eyes, bracing herself for rejection.

LILY (V.O.)
(emotional)
I miss you too.

Sarah's eyes fly open, filling with tears. She looks at Alex, who's watching her with a big smile.

SARAH
(voice cracking)
You do?

LILY (V.O.)
(laughing softly)
Of course I do, you idiot. You're my best friend.

SARAH
(laughing through her tears)
Even after everything?

LILY (V.O.)
(seriously)
Sarah, I'm so sorry about what I said. I was hurt and scared, and I lashed out. I've regretted it every day since.

SARAH
(wiping her eyes)
I'm sorry too. I should have tried harder to make things work, to keep in touch.

LILY (V.O.)
We both could have done things differently. But... maybe it's not too late?

SARAH
(hopefully)
Yeah?

LILY (V.O.)
(warmly)
Yeah. I'd really like to try and fix things. If you want to.

SARAH
(smiling)
I'd like that. I'd like that a lot.

They continue talking, their voices fading into the background as we focus on Sarah's face. She's smiling, really smiling, for the first time since we've seen her. As she talks, she absently touches the bracelet on her wrist.

Alex watches her, a proud and happy expression on his face. He quietly gets up and starts cleaning up the pizza boxes, giving Sarah some privacy for her conversation.

FADE TO:

INT. SARAH'S NEW APARTMENT - DAY (ONE MONTH LATER)

The apartment is bright and airy, with boxes still scattered around but many already unpacked. Sarah is standing in the living room, hanging a framed photo on the wall.

CLOSE ON: The photo is the one from the beach, showing Sarah and Lily building the sandcastle.

The doorbell rings, and Sarah hurries to answer it. She opens the door to reveal Lily, standing there with a nervous smile and a potted plant in her hands.

LILY
(hesitantly)
Hey. Housewarming gift?

Sarah's face breaks into a wide smile. She takes the plant and sets it aside, then pulls Lily into a tight hug.

SARAH
(emotionally)
I'm so glad you're here.

Lily hugs her back just as tightly.

LILY
(softly)
Me too.

They pull apart, both a little teary-eyed but smiling.

SARAH
(gesturing inside)
Come on in. I've got so much to show you.

As Lily enters the apartment, her eyes fall on the framed beach photo.

LILY
(touched)
You kept that?

SARAH
(smiling)
Of course I did. It's one of my favorite memories.

Lily reaches out and touches the frame gently.

LILY
Mine too.

They share a look of understanding and renewed friendship. Then Sarah grins and grabs Lily's hand.

SARAH
(excitedly)
Come on, let me give you the grand tour. And then maybe we can go get coffee and catch up properly?

LILY
(laughing)
Sounds perfect.

As they move further into the apartment, chatting and laughing, we see that they're both wearing their silver friendship bracelets. The camera lingers on this detail before we

FADE TO BLACK.

THE END

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A woman is swimming in a pool when suddenly a man in a wet suit attacks her and pulls her down. She is fighting for her life, but the man manages to overpower her completely.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 4000 words.
response:
Here's a screenplay based on the given writing prompt:

EXT. LUXURY RESORT - DAY

The sun shines brightly over a picturesque luxury resort nestled in a tropical paradise. Palm trees sway gently in the breeze, and the sound of waves crashing on a nearby beach can be heard in the distance.

INT. RESORT LOBBY - DAY

SARAH MILLER, a 32-year-old successful businesswoman with long dark hair and an athletic build, approaches the check-in desk. She's dressed in casual but expensive resort wear, exuding confidence and sophistication.

RECEPTIONIST
Welcome to Paradise Cove Resort, ma'am. How may I assist you?

SARAH
(smiling)
Hi, I have a reservation under Sarah Miller.

The receptionist types on her computer, then looks up with a warm smile.

RECEPTIONIST
Ah, yes, Ms. Miller. We have you booked for a week-long stay in our Oceanview Suite. Is this your first time visiting us?

SARAH
(nodding)
It is. I've heard great things about your resort, especially the pools and spa facilities.

RECEPTIONIST
(beaming)
You've heard correctly. Our infinity pool is particularly popular among guests. Here's your room key and a resort map. Please let us know if you need anything during your stay.

Sarah takes the key and map, thanking the receptionist before heading towards the elevators.

INT. OCEANVIEW SUITE - DAY

Sarah enters her luxurious suite, admiring the spacious room and the breathtaking ocean view from the balcony. She sets her luggage down and begins to unpack.

As she hangs up her clothes, her phone rings. She answers it, putting it on speaker.

SARAH
Hello?

MARK (V.O.)
(through the phone)
Hey, Sarah. How's the resort?

SARAH
(smiling)
Mark, it's beautiful. I can't wait to explore everything.

MARK (V.O.)
I'm glad you're taking this vacation. You've been working too hard lately.

SARAH
(sighing)
I know, I know. But the Kensington deal was important. We couldn't afford to lose it.

MARK (V.O.)
And we didn't, thanks to you. Now it's time to relax and recharge. Promise me you won't think about work for the next week.

SARAH
(laughing)
I'll try my best. No guarantees though.

MARK (V.O.)
Sarah...

SARAH
(rolling her eyes playfully)
Alright, alright. I promise. No work for a week.

MARK (V.O.)
Good. Enjoy yourself, okay? You deserve it.

SARAH
Thanks, Mark. I'll check in with you later.

She ends the call and continues unpacking, a small smile on her face.

EXT. RESORT GROUNDS - DAY

Sarah explores the resort, taking in the lush gardens, the various restaurants, and the spa facilities. She stops by the main pool area, her eyes widening at the sight of the stunning infinity pool overlooking the ocean.

INT. RESORT GYM - DAY

Sarah, dressed in workout clothes, enters the state-of-the-art gym. She begins her routine on a treadmill, increasing the speed gradually. As she runs, she notices a man in the corner of the gym, doing pull-ups. This is JAMES CARTER, 35, with a muscular build and an intense focus.

Their eyes meet briefly, and James gives her a small nod before returning to his workout. Sarah continues her run, occasionally glancing in James's direction.

After her workout, Sarah heads to the water cooler. James approaches, grabbing a towel nearby.

JAMES
(smiling)
Impressive run. You must be training for something.

SARAH
(slightly breathless)
Thanks. No training, just trying to stay in shape.

JAMES
Well, you're doing a great job. I'm James, by the way.

SARAH
Sarah. Nice to meet you.

JAMES
Are you here on vacation?

SARAH
(nodding)
Yeah, just arrived today. Needed a break from work.

JAMES
(grinning)
What a coincidence. I'm here for the same reason. Maybe we could grab a drink later? Swap stories about our high-stress jobs?

Sarah hesitates for a moment, then smiles.

SARAH
Sure, why not? I could use some company.

JAMES
Great. How about we meet at the Tiki Bar by the pool around 7?

SARAH
Sounds good. See you then.

As Sarah leaves the gym, James watches her go, a calculating look in his eyes.

EXT. TIKI BAR - NIGHT

Sarah, dressed in a stylish sundress, sits at the bar. James arrives, looking handsome in a casual button-down shirt and khaki shorts.

JAMES
(sitting next to her)
Hope I didn't keep you waiting.

SARAH
(smiling)
Not at all. I just got here myself.

They order drinks and begin chatting.

JAMES
So, what kind of work do you do that requires such intense workouts?

SARAH
(laughing)
I'm a corporate lawyer. The workouts are more for stress relief than anything else. What about you?

JAMES
(grinning)
I'm in finance. Lots of long hours and high-pressure situations.

SARAH
(nodding)
I can relate to that. It's why I needed this vacation so badly.

JAMES
(raising his glass)
Well, here's to leaving work behind and enjoying paradise.

They clink glasses and continue their conversation, laughing and sharing stories as the night goes on.

INT. SARAH'S SUITE - NIGHT

Sarah enters her room, a slight flush on her cheeks from the drinks and the pleasant evening. She changes into her pajamas and settles into bed, setting her alarm for an early morning swim.

INT. SARAH'S SUITE - MORNING

The alarm blares, waking Sarah. She groggily gets up and changes into a sleek one-piece swimsuit, grabbing a towel before heading out.

EXT. INFINITY POOL - EARLY MORNING

The pool area is deserted as Sarah approaches. The rising sun casts a golden glow over the water, making it shimmer invitingly. Sarah sets her towel on a nearby lounger and does some light stretching before diving into the pool.

She begins swimming laps, her strokes smooth and practiced. As she reaches the far end of the pool, she pauses to catch her breath, admiring the view of the ocean beyond.

Suddenly, a dark figure emerges from the water behind her. Before Sarah can react, strong arms wrap around her, pulling her under the surface.

UNDERWATER

Sarah struggles against her attacker, kicking and thrashing. She manages to break free momentarily and surfaces, gasping for air.

SARAH
(screaming)
Help! Someone help me!

Her cries are cut short as she's dragged back under. The attacker, dressed in a black wetsuit with a mask covering their face, maintains a tight grip on her.

Sarah fights desperately, her lungs burning for air. She claws at the attacker's mask, managing to pull it off. To her shock, she recognizes James's face.

They both surface briefly.

SARAH
(gasping)
James? What are you doing? Stop!

JAMES
(coldly)
Sorry, Sarah. It's nothing personal. Just business.

He forces her back under the water. Sarah's movements become weaker as she struggles to hold her breath. Just as she feels she can't fight anymore, a loud whistle pierces the air.

EXT. INFINITY POOL - MORNING

A LIFEGUARD rushes towards the pool, blowing his whistle frantically. James, hearing the commotion, releases Sarah and swims quickly to the edge of the pool, pulling himself out and sprinting away.

Sarah surfaces, coughing and sputtering. The lifeguard dives in and helps her to the pool's edge.

LIFEGUARD
(concerned)
Ma'am, are you alright? What happened?

SARAH
(between coughs)
He... he tried to drown me. James... the man I was with last night.

Other resort staff begin to arrive, alerted by the commotion. 

RESORT MANAGER
(approaching quickly)
What's going on here?

LIFEGUARD
This guest was just attacked in the pool, sir.

RESORT MANAGER
(shocked)
Attacked? By whom?

SARAH
(still catching her breath)
His name is James. He said he was here on vacation, but... I think he was lying.

RESORT MANAGER
(to a nearby staff member)
Call the police immediately.

(to Sarah)
Ms. Miller, I am so sorry this happened. Let's get you inside and taken care of. We'll need to get a statement from you for the police.

Sarah nods weakly as the lifeguard helps her out of the pool. A staff member wraps a large towel around her shoulders.

INT. RESORT SECURITY OFFICE - DAY

Sarah, now dressed in dry clothes, sits in a chair, a blanket draped over her shoulders and a cup of hot tea in her hands. She's speaking with two police officers, DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ and OFFICER CHEN.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Ms. Miller, can you tell us exactly what happened this morning?

SARAH
(taking a deep breath)
I went for an early swim in the infinity pool. I was alone, or so I thought. Suddenly, someone grabbed me from behind and pulled me under the water. I fought back, but he was too strong.

OFFICER CHEN
(taking notes)
And you're certain it was the man you met last night? James?

SARAH
(nodding)
Yes, I managed to pull off his mask underwater. It was definitely him.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Did he say anything to you during the attack?

SARAH
(frowning)
When we surfaced for a moment, I asked him why he was doing this. He said it was "just business."

The detectives exchange a glance.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Ms. Miller, is there anyone who might want to harm you? Perhaps related to your work?

SARAH
(hesitating)
I... I'm a corporate lawyer. I've been involved in some high-profile cases, but I can't think of anyone who'd want to kill me over them.

OFFICER CHEN
What about the case you just finished? The Kensington deal?

SARAH
(surprised)
How did you know about that?

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
We did some preliminary research on you, Ms. Miller. The Kensington deal was in the news recently. It was quite contentious, wasn't it?

SARAH
(nodding slowly)
Yes, it was. There were... a lot of parties involved who weren't happy with the outcome.

OFFICER CHEN
Could one of those parties have hired someone to... eliminate you?

SARAH
(shocked)
I... I suppose it's possible. But who would go to such lengths?

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
That's what we need to find out. Ms. Miller, we're going to need more details about your recent cases, especially the Kensington deal. We'll also need access to your phone and email records.

SARAH
(nodding)
Of course, whatever you need. I just want to understand why this happened.

As Sarah begins to recount the details of her recent work, we cut to:

EXT. RESORT GROUNDS - DAY

Police officers are scouring the resort grounds, questioning staff and guests. Security footage is being reviewed, and the pool area has been cordoned off as a crime scene.

INT. POLICE STATION - DAY

Detective Rodriguez is pinning photos and documents to a large board, creating a timeline of events. Officer Chen enters with a file.

OFFICER CHEN
Detective, we've got something. Resort security cameras caught our suspect leaving the grounds shortly after the attack.

She hands over some printouts of security camera stills showing James running through the parking lot and getting into a car.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
(examining the photos)
Good. Run the plates. And get me everything you can on this James Carter. I want to know if that's even his real name.

OFFICER CHEN
Already on it. There's something else. We've been digging into the Kensington deal, and it seems there was a lot more at stake than just money.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
(interested)
What do you mean?

OFFICER CHEN
The deal involved the acquisition of a tech company that was developing some cutting-edge AI technology. Rumor has it, this tech could have military applications.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
(whistling)
Now that's the kind of thing people kill for. Good work, Chen. Keep digging. I want to know every player involved in this deal, especially those who lost out.

As Officer Chen leaves, Detective Rodriguez turns back to the board, studying it intently.

INT. SARAH'S SUITE - NIGHT

Sarah paces in her room, talking on the phone with Mark.

SARAH
Mark, I'm telling you, someone tried to kill me today.

MARK (V.O.)
(concerned)
Sarah, are you sure? Maybe it was just some kind of accident or misunderstanding?

SARAH
(frustrated)
An accident? Mark, he held me underwater and told me it was "just business." How is that an accident?

MARK (V.O.)
Okay, okay. I'm sorry. I just... I can't believe someone would do this. Do the police have any leads?

SARAH
They're investigating, but they seem to think it might be related to the Kensington deal.

MARK (V.O.)
(surprised)
The Kensington deal? But why? We won that case fair and square.

SARAH
I don't know, Mark. But I'm scared. What if he comes back?

MARK (V.O.)
(firmly)
He won't. The police are looking for him, and I'm sure the resort has increased security. You're safe, Sarah.

SARAH
(sighing)
I hope you're right. I just want this nightmare to be over.

MARK (V.O.)
It will be soon. Try to get some rest, okay? I'll call you in the morning.

Sarah ends the call and sits on the edge of her bed, her head in her hands. After a moment, she gets up and double-checks that her door and windows are locked before trying to settle in for an uneasy night.

EXT. RESORT GROUNDS - DAY

The next morning, Sarah emerges from her room, looking tired and on edge. She's escorted by a plainclothes police officer acting as her temporary bodyguard.

As they walk towards the restaurant for breakfast, Sarah notices increased security presence around the resort. She also sees other guests whispering and pointing in her direction, having obviously heard about the incident.

INT. RESORT RESTAURANT - DAY

Sarah sits at a table with her bodyguard nearby. As she picks at her food, Detective Rodriguez approaches.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Ms. Miller, may I join you?

SARAH
(nodding)
Of course, Detective. Do you have any news?

Detective Rodriguez sits down, pulling out a small notebook.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
We've made some progress. The man who attacked you isn't James Carter. That was an alias. His real name is Eric Wolfe, and he's a known contract killer.

SARAH
(shocked)
A contract killer? So someone really did hire him to... to kill me?

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
(nodding grimly)
It appears so. We're still trying to track him down, but he seems to have gone to ground. What I need from you now is to think carefully about who might have hired him.

SARAH
(shaking her head)
I've been wracking my brain, Detective, but I just can't think of anyone who'd want me dead.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Let's approach this from a different angle. In the Kensington deal, who stood to lose the most?

SARAH
(thinking)
Well, there were several competing bidders for the tech company. The biggest one was probably Nexus Corp. They were furious when they lost the bid.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
(writing in his notebook)
Nexus Corp. What can you tell me about them?

SARAH
They're a major player in the tech industry, known for their aggressive business tactics. Their CEO, Victor Krane, has a reputation for being ruthless.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Ruthless enough to order a hit?

SARAH
(hesitating)
I... I don't know. It seems extreme, even for him.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
We'll look into it. In the meantime, I want you to stay alert and stick close to your protection detail. We're doing everything we can to find Wolfe, but until we do, you're still at risk.

Sarah nods, looking worried. As Detective Rodriguez leaves, she pushes her plate away, having lost her appetite.

EXT. RESORT BEACH - DAY

Sarah walks along the beach with her bodyguard, trying to clear her head. Despite the beautiful surroundings, she looks tense and distracted.

Suddenly, her phone rings. She answers it, putting it on speaker so her bodyguard can hear.

SARAH
Hello?

JAMES/ERIC (V.O.)
(through the phone)
Hello, Sarah. Did you enjoy our little swim yesterday?

Sarah freezes, her face paling. The bodyguard immediately signals for backup on his radio.

SARAH
(shakily)
James... or should I say, Eric?

JAMES/ERIC (V.O.)
(chuckling)
Ah, so the police have been doing their homework. Good for them.

SARAH
What do you want?

JAMES/ERIC (V.O.)
To finish what I started, of course. You've proven to be quite resilient, Sarah. I admire that. But I always complete my contracts.

SARAH
(angrily)
Who hired you? Was it Victor Krane?

There's a pause on the other end of the line.

JAMES/ERIC (V.O.)
(amused)
You're smarter than I gave you credit for, Sarah. But knowing who hired me won't save you.

SARAH
Why are you calling me? To taunt me?

JAMES/ERIC (V.O.)
Consider it a professional courtesy. I wanted to let you know that your time is running out. Enjoy your last few hours in paradise.

The line goes dead. Sarah looks at her bodyguard, fear evident in her eyes.

BODYGUARD
(into his radio)
This is Officer Davis. We need to move Ms. Miller to a secure location immediately. The suspect just made contact.

As more security personnel arrive, they quickly escort Sarah off the beach.

INT. POLICE STATION - DAY

Detective Rodriguez is briefing his team, a photo of Eric Wolfe displayed on a screen behind him.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Alright, people. Our suspect has made contact with the victim. He's still on the island, and he's planning to make another attempt. I want every available officer on this. Check every hotel, every rental property. He has to be somewhere.

As the team disperses, Officer Chen approaches Detective Rodriguez.

OFFICER CHEN
Detective, I've been looking into Nexus Corp and Victor Krane. There's something you should see.

She hands him a file. As Rodriguez flips through it, his eyebrows raise.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
This is bigger than we thought. Get me a secure line to the FBI. We're going to need their help on this one.

INT. SAFE HOUSE - NIGHT

Sarah sits in a sparsely furnished room, looking out the window at the night sky. Two police officers stand guard outside her door. Detective Rodriguez enters the room.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Ms. Miller, how are you holding up?

SARAH
