The room is dimly lit, with only the soft glow of a bedside lamp illuminating the space. SARAH, a woman in her late 20s with long brown hair, tosses and turns in her bed. Empty wine bottles and scattered pill bottles litter her nightstand.

Sarah's eyes flutter open, unfocused and disoriented. She reaches for her phone, squinting at the bright screen.

SARAH
(groggy)
Ugh... What time is it?

She struggles to sit up, holding her head in her hands.

SARAH (CONT'D)
(to herself)
Never mixing wine and pills again...

Sarah stumbles out of bed, her movements unsteady. She makes her way to the bathroom, flicking on the light.

INT. SARAH'S BATHROOM - CONTINUOUS

Sarah splashes water on her face, then looks up at her reflection in the mirror. Her eyes widen in shock.

SARAH
What the...

Her reflection appears normal, but the bathroom behind her is bathed in an eerie, neon glow. Sarah whirls around, blinking rapidly.

The tiles on the floor are a vibrant blue, the walls a pulsating green. Even the toilet seems to glow with an unnatural purple hue.

SARAH (CONT'D)
(panicked)
This can't be real. I'm dreaming. I have to be dreaming.

She pinches herself hard, wincing at the pain.

SARAH (CONT'D)
Okay, not dreaming. What's happening to me?

Sarah rushes out of the bathroom, nearly tripping over her own feet.

INT. SARAH'S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS

The neon colors have invaded her bedroom as well. The walls shimmer with a soft orange glow, while her bed sheets have turned a vivid electric blue.

Sarah grabs her phone from the nightstand, frantically dialing a number.

SARAH
(into phone)
Come on, pick up. Pick up!

INTERCUT WITH:

INT. ALEX'S APARTMENT - NIGHT

ALEX, a man in his early 30s with tousled black hair, groggily answers his phone.

ALEX
(sleepy)
Sarah? Do you have any idea what time it is?

SARAH
Alex, thank God. Something's wrong. Everything's... different.

ALEX
(concerned)
Different how? Are you okay?

SARAH
I don't know. The colors... everything's neon. It's like I'm in some kind of acid trip, but I swear I didn't take anything.

ALEX
(sitting up in bed)
Whoa, slow down. What do you mean everything's neon?

SARAH
(growing hysterical)
I mean exactly that! My walls are glowing orange, my sheets are electric blue. Even the damn toilet is purple!

ALEX
(alarmed)
Sarah, listen to me. Stay calm. I'm coming over, okay? Don't do anything, just stay put.

SARAH
(voice breaking)
Please hurry. I'm scared, Alex.

Sarah ends the call and sinks to the floor, hugging her knees to her chest.

EXT. SARAH'S HOUSE - DAWN

Alex's car pulls up in front of Sarah's house. He jumps out, looking around in confusion.

The sky is a brilliant pink, streaked with neon blue clouds. The trees lining the street have vibrant orange leaves, while the grass is a deep, unnatural purple.

ALEX
(to himself)
What the hell?

He runs up to Sarah's front door, knocking frantically.

ALEX (CONT'D)
Sarah! Sarah, it's me! Open up!

The door swings open, revealing a terrified Sarah. She immediately throws herself into Alex's arms.

SARAH
(sobbing)
Alex, thank God you're here. You can see it too, right? Tell me I'm not going crazy.

ALEX
(holding her tightly)
I see it. I don't understand it, but I see it.

They pull apart, both looking around at the surreal landscape.

ALEX (CONT'D)
We need to figure out what's going on. Let's go inside and talk.

INT. SARAH'S LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER

The living room is a kaleidoscope of neon colors. The couch glows a soft green, while the coffee table seems to pulse with a blue light.

Sarah and Alex sit on the couch, both looking uncomfortable and out of place in the bizarre setting.

ALEX
Okay, let's think this through. When did you first notice the changes?

SARAH
(taking a deep breath)
I woke up feeling awful. I thought it was just a hangover, but when I went to the bathroom, everything was... like this.

ALEX
And you're sure you didn't take any hallucinogens?

SARAH
(defensive)
Of course not! I had some wine last night, and I took a couple of sleeping pills, but that's it.

ALEX
(frowning)
Sleeping pills? Sarah, you know you're not supposed to mix those with alcohol.

SARAH
(irritated)
I know, I know. But that doesn't explain... this!

She gestures wildly at their surroundings.

ALEX
(thoughtful)
No, it doesn't. But it might be related. What else happened last night?

Sarah's expression changes, a flicker of guilt crossing her face.

SARAH
(hesitant)
I... I went to see Marcus.

ALEX
(surprised)
Your ex? Why?

SARAH
(sighing)
He called, said he wanted to talk. I thought maybe... I don't know what I thought.

ALEX
(concerned)
Did something happen?

SARAH
(avoiding eye contact)
We argued. He wanted to get back together, but I told him no. He got angry, said some things...

ALEX
What kind of things?

SARAH
(voice trembling)
He said I'd regret it. That I'd wake up to a world I didn't recognize.

Alex stands up abruptly, pacing the room.

ALEX
Sarah, this is important. Did Marcus give you anything? A drink, maybe?

SARAH
(thinking hard)
I... I'm not sure. Everything's a bit fuzzy. I remember having a glass of wine at his place, but after that...

ALEX
(urgently)
We need to go see Marcus. Now.

EXT. CITY STREETS - MORNING

Sarah and Alex drive through the neon-lit city. The buildings are a riot of colors, each one seeming to glow with its own internal light.

People on the streets appear normal, going about their day as if nothing is amiss. Sarah stares out the window in disbelief.

SARAH
How can they not see this? How are they just going about their lives like everything's normal?

ALEX
(focused on driving)
I don't know. Maybe whatever's affecting us isn't affecting them.

SARAH
(frustrated)
But why us? What makes us so special?

ALEX
(grimly)
I have a feeling we're about to find out.

They pull up in front of a modern apartment building, its facade a pulsating mix of blue and green.

INT. MARCUS'S APARTMENT BUILDING - ELEVATOR - MOMENTS LATER

Sarah and Alex ride the elevator in tense silence. The walls of the elevator car shift colors, cycling through the spectrum like a demented light show.

SARAH
(nervously)
What if he doesn't know anything? What if this is all just some weird coincidence?

ALEX
(reassuring)
Then we'll figure something else out. But right now, he's our best lead.

The elevator dings, doors sliding open to reveal a hallway bathed in a soft purple glow.

INT. MARCUS'S APARTMENT BUILDING - HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS

Sarah and Alex approach Marcus's door. Sarah raises her hand to knock, then hesitates.

ALEX
(softly)
It's okay. I'm right here with you.

Sarah nods, then knocks firmly on the door. After a moment, it swings open, revealing MARCUS, a man in his early 30s with a charismatic smile and piercing green eyes.

MARCUS
(smirking)
Well, well. I was wondering when you'd show up.

SARAH
(angry)
What did you do to me, Marcus?

MARCUS
(feigning innocence)
I'm not sure what you mean, Sarah. Why don't you both come in? We have a lot to talk about.

He steps aside, gesturing for them to enter. Sarah and Alex exchange a wary glance before stepping into the apartment.

INT. MARCUS'S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS

The apartment is a stark contrast to the neon world outside. Everything appears normal, with no sign of the vivid colors that have taken over Sarah and Alex's perception.

SARAH
(confused)
I don't understand. Why does everything look normal in here?

MARCUS
(closing the door)
Because this is my space. My rules.

He walks over to a sleek bar in the corner of the living room, pouring himself a drink.

MARCUS (CONT'D)
Can I offer either of you a drink? No? Suit yourselves.

ALEX
(stern)
Cut the crap, Marcus. What did you do to Sarah?

MARCUS
(sipping his drink)
I simply opened her eyes to the truth. The world isn't what you think it is, Sarah. I've given you the gift of sight.

SARAH
(incredulous)
Gift? You call this a gift? I feel like I'm going insane!

MARCUS
(setting down his glass)
That's because you're fighting it. Embrace it, Sarah. See the world for what it really is.

ALEX
(stepping forward)
And what exactly is that?

Marcus turns to Alex, his eyes suddenly glowing with an otherworldly light.

MARCUS
Energy. Pure, unfiltered energy. The colors you see? That's the life force of everything around you.

SARAH
(shaking her head)
This is crazy. You're crazy.

MARCUS
(laughing)
Am I? Or am I the only sane one in a world of blind sheep?

He walks over to Sarah, reaching out to touch her face. She flinches away.

MARCUS (CONT'D)
I've been trying to show you for years, Sarah. But you were always too afraid to see.

ALEX
(intervening)
Back off, Marcus. How do we undo this?

MARCUS
(turning to Alex)
Undo it? Why would you want to? This is evolution, my friend. The next step in human consciousness.

SARAH
(desperate)
Please, Marcus. I can't live like this. Just tell me how to make it stop.

Marcus's expression softens, a hint of regret crossing his face.

MARCUS
(sighing)
It's not that simple, Sarah. What's been seen can't be unseen. But...

He walks over to a bookshelf, pulling out an old, leather-bound book.

MARCUS (CONT'D)
There might be a way to... dial it back, so to speak.

ALEX
(suspicious)
What's the catch?

MARCUS
(smirking)
Smart man. The catch is, it requires a sacrifice. Something precious, something tied to your very essence.

SARAH
(determined)
I'll do it. Whatever it is, I'll do it.

MARCUS
(warning)
Be careful what you wish for, Sarah. The price might be higher than you're willing to pay.

He opens the book, flipping through pages covered in strange symbols and diagrams.

MARCUS (CONT'D)
Ah, here we are. "To dim the sight, one must relinquish a light." Poetic, isn't it?

ALEX
(impatient)
What does that mean?

MARCUS
It means, dear Sarah, that to return your vision to normal, you must give up something that brings light to your life. A passion, a dream, a loved one...

Sarah's eyes widen in realization. She looks at Alex, then back at Marcus.

SARAH
(whispering)
No. There has to be another way.

MARCUS
(closing the book)
I'm afraid not. The universe demands balance. To lose one sight, you must sacrifice another.

ALEX
(angry)
This is bullshit. Come on, Sarah. We're leaving.

He grabs Sarah's arm, pulling her towards the door.

MARCUS
(calling after them)
You can run, but you can't hide from the truth, Sarah! It's in you now!

EXT. MARCUS'S APARTMENT BUILDING - DAY

Sarah and Alex burst out of the building, the neon world assaulting their senses once more.

SARAH
(panicking)
What are we going to do, Alex? I can't live like this!

ALEX
(determined)
We'll figure it out. There has to be a rational explanation for all this.

SARAH
(hysterical)
Rational? Look around us! There's nothing rational about this!

Alex grabs Sarah by the shoulders, forcing her to look at him.

ALEX
Listen to me. We're going to get through this together, okay? I'm not leaving your side.

Sarah nods, tears streaming down her face.

SARAH
(softly)
Thank you.

They embrace, standing out like normal figures in a world of neon chaos.

INT. SARAH'S LIVING ROOM - EVENING

Sarah sits on the couch, staring blankly at the TV. The news plays, but the anchors and graphics are distorted by the neon colors that now define her vision.

Alex enters from the kitchen, carrying two mugs of tea.

ALEX
Here, drink this. It might help calm your nerves.

Sarah takes the mug, her hands shaking slightly.

SARAH
(sipping the tea)
I don't know how much more of this I can take, Alex. Everything's so... intense.

ALEX
(sitting beside her)
I know. But we'll get through this. I've been doing some research...

He pulls out his phone, scrolling through some articles.

ALEX (CONT'D)
There are cases of people experiencing similar symptoms after traumatic events or drug interactions. It's called Alice in Wonderland Syndrome.

SARAH
(skeptical)
But you can see it too. How does that explain it?

ALEX
(sighing)
I don't know. Maybe it's some kind of shared hallucination? Or maybe...

He trails off, looking uncomfortable.

SARAH
(pressing)
Maybe what?

ALEX
(hesitant)
Maybe Marcus was telling the truth. Maybe this is... real.

Sarah stands up abruptly, pacing the room.

SARAH
(agitated)
No. No, I can't accept that. There has to be a logical explanation.

ALEX
(standing to join her)
I'm just saying we should consider all possibilities. We don't know what we're dealing with here.

SARAH
(turning to face him)
So what, you think I should make some kind of sacrifice? Give up something I love?

ALEX
(carefully)
If it would help you... maybe it's worth considering.

Sarah's expression hardens.

SARAH
And what if the thing I have to give up is you?

ALEX
(taken aback)
What? Sarah, no...

SARAH
(tears forming)
You heard Marcus. A passion, a dream, a loved one. What if you're the light I have to give up?

ALEX
(moving closer)
That's not going to happen. We'll find another way.

SARAH
(backing away)
But what if we don't? What if this is the only way?

She runs her hands through her hair, clearly distressed.

SARAH (CONT'D)
I can't ask you to give up your normal life for me. It's not fair.

ALEX
(firmly)
You're not asking. I'm choosing to be here, with you, no matter what.

He reaches out to her, but she steps back.

SARAH
(voice breaking)
I need some time alone. Please, just... go.

ALEX
(hurt)
Sarah...

SARAH
(pleading)
Please, Alex. I need to think.

Alex nods reluctantly, gathering his things.

ALEX
(at the door)
Call me if you need anything. Anytime, day or night.

Sarah nods, not meeting his eyes. Alex leaves, the door closing behind him with a soft click.

INT. SARAH'S BEDROOM - NIGHT

Sarah lies in bed, staring at the ceiling. The neon colors swirl and pulse around her, a constant reminder of her altered reality.

She picks up her phone, scrolling through old photos of her and Alex. Tears stream down her face as she looks at their smiling, normal faces.

SARAH
(to herself)
I'm sorry, Alex. I'm so sorry.

She gets up, moving to her desk. She pulls out a pen and paper, beginning to write.

SARAH (V.O.)
Dear Alex, By the time you read this, I'll be gone. I can't ask you to live in this crazy, neon world with me. You deserve a normal life, full of normal colors and experiences. I love you too much to drag you into this madness.

She continues writing, her tears staining the paper.

EXT. CITY STREETS - DAWN

Sarah walks through the empty streets, her backpack slung over her shoulder. The neon world glows around her, the pink sky beginning to lighten with the approaching dawn.

She stops at a crossroads, looking back towards her home, then forward to the unknown. Taking a deep breath, she steps forward, disappearing into the neon landscape.

FADE TO BLACK.

FADE IN:

EXT. FOREST CLEARING - DAY

A year has passed. The neon world persists, but Sarah has learned to navigate it. She sits cross-legged in a clearing, surrounded by trees with glowing orange leaves and purple grass.

Her eyes are closed, her breathing steady. As she meditates, the colors around her seem to pulse in rhythm with her breaths.

Suddenly, a twig snaps nearby. Sarah's eyes fly open.

SARAH
(calling out)
Who's there?

From behind a tree, Alex steps into view. He looks older, more weathered, but his eyes light up at the sight of Sarah.

ALEX
(softly)
I found you.

Sarah jumps to her feet, a mix of emotions playing across her face.

SARAH
(shocked)
Alex? How... how did you find me?

ALEX
(smiling)
I never stopped looking. And I had a little help.

From behind Alex, Marcus emerges. Sarah tenses, ready to run.

MARCUS
(raising his hands)
Easy, Sarah. I'm not here to cause trouble.

SARAH
(suspicious)
Then why are you here?

ALEX
He's been helping me understand... all of this.

He gestures at the neon world around them.

ALEX (CONT'D)
And he's been teaching me how to see it too.

SARAH
(confused)
What? But... why?

MARCUS
(stepping forward)
Because I realized I made a mistake. I gave you this gift, but I didn't give you the tools to understand it. That wasn't fair.

SARAH
(to Alex)
And you've been working with him? After everything he did?

ALEX
(nodding)
It wasn't easy at first. But Sarah, this world... it's incredible once you understand it.

He walks towards her, reaching out his hand.

ALEX (CONT'D)
I'm sorry it took me so long to find you. But I'm here now, and I want to explore this new reality with you. If you'll have me.

Sarah looks at his outstretched hand, then at Marcus, then back to Alex. Slowly, a smile spreads across her face.

SARAH
(taking Alex's hand)
Together?

ALEX
(squeezing her hand)
Together.

They turn to face Marcus, who watches them with a mixture of pride and regret.

MARCUS
(clearing his throat)
So, shall we begin your first lesson?

Sarah and Alex exchange a look, then nod in unison.

SARAH
We're ready.

The three of them sit in a circle on the purple grass. As Marcus begins to speak, the neon world around them seems to come alive, pulsing with energy and possibility.

FADE OUT.

THE END

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A man goes into a church wanting to confess something to a priest.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 4000 words.
response:
Here's a well-structured screenplay based on the given writing prompt:

INT. ST. MICHAEL'S CATHOLIC CHURCH - AFTERNOON

The grand interior of St. Michael's Catholic Church is bathed in soft, golden light filtering through stained glass windows. Rows of wooden pews line the nave, leading to an ornate altar at the front. The air is heavy with the scent of incense and the weight of centuries of prayer.

FATHER THOMAS (mid-50s), a kind-faced priest with salt-and-pepper hair, stands near the altar, arranging flowers. He hums softly to himself, at peace in the quiet sanctuary.

The heavy wooden doors at the back of the church creak open, and MICHAEL DONOVAN (early 40s) steps inside. He's a well-built man with a rugged face, dressed in a rumpled suit that looks like it's been slept in. His eyes are bloodshot, and he moves with the hesitant gait of someone who's not entirely sure they should be there.

Father Thomas looks up at the sound of footsteps echoing through the church. He smiles warmly as Michael approaches.

FATHER THOMAS
Welcome, my son. How can I help you today?

Michael stops a few feet away from the priest, his hands fidgeting nervously at his sides.

MICHAEL
(voice rough)
I... I need to confess, Father.

Father Thomas nods, his expression turning serious as he senses the urgency in Michael's voice.

FATHER THOMAS
Of course. Let's step into the confessional.

He gestures towards a wooden confessional booth near the side of the church. Michael follows, his steps slow and heavy.

INT. CONFESSIONAL BOOTH - CONTINUOUS

The small, dimly lit confessional is divided into two sections by a wooden screen with a small window. Father Thomas settles into his side, while Michael enters the penitent's side, kneeling on the worn cushion.

FATHER THOMAS (O.S.)
In the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit. Amen.

MICHAEL
(hesitantly)
Bless me, Father, for I have sinned. It's been...
(pauses, thinking)
...twenty years since my last confession.

FATHER THOMAS (O.S.)
Welcome back, my son. The Lord rejoices when a lost sheep returns to the fold. What weighs on your heart?

Michael takes a deep breath, his hands gripping the edge of the kneeler tightly.

MICHAEL
Father, I've done something terrible. Something I can't take back.

FATHER THOMAS (O.S.)
God's mercy is infinite, my son. Whatever you've done, He is ready to forgive you if you're truly repentant.

MICHAEL
(voice breaking)
I don't know if I deserve forgiveness, Father. I... I killed someone.

A heavy silence falls in the confessional. Father Thomas takes a moment to process this revelation.

FATHER THOMAS (O.S.)
(gently)
That is indeed a grave sin, my son. But remember, even the greatest sinners can find redemption. Can you tell me more about what happened?

Michael closes his eyes, his body trembling slightly as he begins to speak.

MICHAEL
It was an accident... at least, that's what I've been telling myself for the past week. But I'm not so sure anymore.

INT. MICHAEL'S CAR - NIGHT (FLASHBACK)

Michael is behind the wheel of his car, driving down a dimly lit suburban street. His eyes are unfocused, and an empty whiskey bottle rolls around on the passenger seat.

MICHAEL (V.O.)
I'd been drinking. A lot. My wife left me a month ago, took the kids with her. I couldn't handle it, so I turned to the bottle.

The car swerves slightly, narrowly missing a parked vehicle.

MICHAEL (V.O.)
I knew I shouldn't have been driving. But I was angry, and stupid, and I thought I could make it home.

Suddenly, a figure steps out onto the road ‚Äì a young woman, SARAH (mid-20s), walking her dog. Michael's eyes widen in shock.

MICHAEL (V.O.)
She came out of nowhere. I tried to swerve, but...

The car strikes Sarah, sending her flying. The dog's leash slips from her hand as she falls. Michael slams on the brakes, the car screeching to a halt.

INT. CONFESSIONAL BOOTH - PRESENT DAY

Michael's face is pale, his eyes haunted as he relives the memory.

MICHAEL
I hit her, Father. I got out of the car, and she was just lying there, so still. Her dog was barking, pulling at the leash, trying to wake her up.

FATHER THOMAS (O.S.)
(softly)
What did you do then, my son?

Michael's hands clench into fists, his knuckles turning white.

MICHAEL
I panicked. I... I got back in the car and drove away. I left her there, Father. Alone, in the dark.

FATHER THOMAS (O.S.)
Have you spoken to the authorities about this?

MICHAEL
(shaking his head)
No. I've been hiding ever since. I can't eat, can't sleep. Every time I close my eyes, I see her face.

FATHER THOMAS (O.S.)
I understand you're frightened, my son, but you must take responsibility for your actions. Have you learned what happened to the young woman?

Michael nods, tears welling up in his eyes.

MICHAEL
I've been checking the local news obsessively. Her name was Sarah Thompson. She... she died at the scene.

FATHER THOMAS (O.S.)
I'm so sorry, my son. For both you and for Sarah and her family. This is a heavy burden you carry.

MICHAEL
(voice cracking)
I've destroyed so many lives, Father. Sarah's family, my own family... How can I ever make this right?

FATHER THOMAS (O.S.)
The path to redemption is never easy, but it begins with honesty and a genuine desire to atone for our sins. You've taken the first step by confessing here today.

Michael wipes his eyes with the back of his hand, his shoulders slumped under the weight of his guilt.

MICHAEL
What should I do, Father? I'm so lost.

FATHER THOMAS (O.S.)
You must turn yourself in to the authorities, my son. It's the only way to truly begin making amends. Sarah's family deserves to know the truth, and you need to face the consequences of your actions.

MICHAEL
(nodding slowly)
I know you're right. I've known it all along, I just... I've been too much of a coward to do it.

FATHER THOMAS (O.S.)
It takes great courage to admit our faults and seek forgiveness. Remember, God's love is unconditional. He will be with you through this difficult journey.

MICHAEL
Thank you, Father. I... I think I'm ready to do what needs to be done.

FATHER THOMAS (O.S.)
I'm proud of you, my son. Would you like to pray together before you go?

MICHAEL
Yes, please.

FATHER THOMAS (O.S.)
Let us pray. Lord, we come before you with heavy hearts...

As Father Thomas begins the prayer, we slowly fade out of the confessional.

EXT. ST. MICHAEL'S CATHOLIC CHURCH - LATE AFTERNOON

Michael emerges from the church, blinking in the fading sunlight. He looks different now ‚Äì still troubled, but with a sense of purpose in his stride. He takes a deep breath, then pulls out his cell phone.

He dials a number with trembling fingers, then raises the phone to his ear.

MICHAEL
(into phone)
Hello, is this the police department? I... I need to report a crime.

As Michael continues to speak into the phone, we slowly pan up to the church spire, reaching towards the sky.

FADE TO BLACK.

INT. POLICE STATION - INTERROGATION ROOM - NIGHT

Michael sits at a metal table, his hands clasped in front of him. The room is stark and cold, with harsh fluorescent lighting. Across from him sits DETECTIVE SARAH RODRIGUEZ (late 30s), a no-nonsense woman with sharp eyes and a stern expression.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Mr. Donovan, I want to make sure I understand this correctly. You're confessing to the hit-and-run that killed Sarah Thompson last week?

MICHAEL
(nodding)
Yes, that's right.

Detective Rodriguez leans back in her chair, studying Michael intently.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Why now? Why come forward after a week?

Michael takes a deep breath, his eyes meeting the detective's.

MICHAEL
I couldn't live with the guilt anymore. I spoke to a priest today, and... I realized I needed to face what I'd done.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
(skeptically)
A week is a long time to suddenly develop a conscience, Mr. Donovan.

MICHAEL
(voice tight with emotion)
I know. I was a coward. I was scared and... and selfish. But I can't run from this anymore. Sarah and her family deserve justice.

Detective Rodriguez nods slowly, then opens a file on the table.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Tell me exactly what happened that night.

Michael closes his eyes briefly, steeling himself, then begins to recount the events.

MICHAEL
I'd been drinking at O'Malley's Bar on 5th Street. I was there most of the evening, drowning my sorrows. When they closed up around 2 AM, I... I stupidly thought I could drive myself home.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
(interrupting)
How much had you had to drink?

MICHAEL
(ashamed)
Too much. I'd lost count. Mostly whiskey.

Detective Rodriguez makes a note in her file, then gestures for Michael to continue.

MICHAEL
I was driving down Elm Street, near the park. I wasn't paying attention... my vision was blurry. Suddenly, there was someone in the road. I tried to swerve, but...

His voice trails off, choked with emotion. Detective Rodriguez waits patiently for him to compose himself.

MICHAEL
(continuing)
I hit her. I got out of the car and saw her lying there. Her dog was barking... I panicked. I got back in the car and drove away.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Where did you go after that?

MICHAEL
Home. I parked in my garage and haven't driven the car since.

Detective Rodriguez leans forward, her eyes intense.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Mr. Donovan, I need to ask you this directly. Are you absolutely certain it was you who hit Sarah Thompson?

Michael looks confused by the question.

MICHAEL
(firmly)
Yes, I'm certain. Why do you ask?

Detective Rodriguez exchanges a glance with the mirror on the wall ‚Äì behind which, we assume, other officers are watching.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Because, Mr. Donovan, we arrested someone else for this crime two days ago.

Michael's eyes widen in shock.

MICHAEL
What? But... that's impossible. I know what I did.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
The man we arrested, Jason Lee, confessed to the crime. His car had damage consistent with the accident, and we found traces of the victim's DNA.

Michael shakes his head vehemently.

MICHAEL
No, no, there must be some mistake. I did this. I'm the one responsible.

Detective Rodriguez studies Michael carefully.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Mr. Donovan, false confessions are more common than you might think. Sometimes, people convince themselves they've committed a crime out of guilt or a desire for attention.

MICHAEL
(angrily)
This isn't a false confession! I know what I did. I've been living with this guilt for a week. I can describe exactly what happened!

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
(calmly)
Many details of the accident were reported in the media. It's possible you've incorporated those into your memory.

Michael stands up abruptly, his chair scraping loudly against the floor.

MICHAEL
This is insane! I'm telling you I did it! Why won't you believe me?

The door to the interrogation room opens, and another officer steps in, whispering something to Detective Rodriguez. She nods, then turns back to Michael.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Mr. Donovan, please sit down. We're going to take a short break, and then we'll continue this conversation.

Michael sinks back into his chair, looking bewildered and frustrated.

INT. POLICE STATION - OBSERVATION ROOM - CONTINUOUS

Behind the two-way mirror, several officers and a man in a suit ‚Äì DISTRICT ATTORNEY JAMES PARKER (50s) ‚Äì are watching the interrogation.

OFFICER JENKINS
What do you think, sir? Is he for real?

DISTRICT ATTORNEY PARKER
(thoughtfully)
I'm not sure. His emotion seems genuine, but the facts don't add up. We need to dig deeper.

INT. POLICE STATION - INTERROGATION ROOM - LATER

Michael is still seated at the table, looking exhausted and confused. Detective Rodriguez re-enters, carrying a fresh file.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Mr. Donovan, we've done some checking. Can you tell me where you were last Saturday night, around 10 PM?

Michael furrows his brow, thinking.

MICHAEL
Saturday? I... I was at home, I think. Why?

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Are you certain about that?

MICHAEL
(hesitantly)
I... I'm not sure. The days have all blurred together this past week.

Detective Rodriguez opens the file and slides a photograph across the table. It shows Michael at a bar, the timestamp clearly showing last Saturday at 10:23 PM.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
This is you at O'Malley's Bar last Saturday night. The bartender remembers you clearly because you got into an altercation with another patron.

Michael stares at the photo, his face a mask of confusion.

MICHAEL
I don't... I don't remember this. How is this possible?

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Mr. Donovan, I think you might be experiencing some memory issues. The accident that killed Sarah Thompson happened last Tuesday night, not last week as you initially stated.

Michael shakes his head, looking increasingly distressed.

MICHAEL
No, that can't be right. I remember it so clearly. The empty streets, the sound of the impact, the dog barking...

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
(gently)
Sometimes our minds can play tricks on us, especially when we're under stress. You mentioned your wife left you recently?

MICHAEL
(nodding)
A month ago. She took our kids.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
And you've been drinking heavily since then?

MICHAEL
(ashamed)
Yes.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Mr. Donovan, I think you might be experiencing alcoholic blackouts. It's possible you heard about the accident on the news and, in your distressed state, convinced yourself you were responsible.

Michael puts his head in his hands, overwhelmed.

MICHAEL
But it felt so real. I can see it all so clearly in my mind.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
The human mind is complex. Sometimes, especially when we're dealing with trauma or substance abuse, our memories can become distorted or even fabricated.

She leans forward, her tone compassionate.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Mr. Donovan, I don't believe you killed Sarah Thompson. But I do think you need help. Would you be willing to speak with a mental health professional?

Michael looks up, his eyes filled with a mix of confusion, relief, and shame.

MICHAEL
I... I don't know what to think anymore. Maybe you're right. I just... I felt so guilty.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
Guilt can be a powerful emotion, even when it's misplaced. The important thing now is to get you the support you need.

Michael nods slowly, a tear rolling down his cheek.

MICHAEL
What happens now?

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
We're not going to charge you with anything related to Sarah Thompson's death. But I would strongly recommend you seek treatment for your alcohol use and mental health. Would you like us to help you find some resources?

MICHAEL
(quietly)
Yes, please. I think... I think I need help.

Detective Rodriguez stands, offering a small smile.

DETECTIVE RODRIGUEZ
You've taken a big step today, Mr. Donovan. It takes courage to face our demons, even if they turn out to be different than we thought.

As Detective Rodriguez leads Michael out of the interrogation room, we...

FADE TO BLACK.

FADE IN:

EXT. REHABILITATION CENTER - THREE MONTHS LATER - DAY

A serene facility surrounded by lush gardens. Michael, looking healthier and more put-together than we've seen him before, walks out of the main building. Father Thomas is waiting for him near the entrance.

FATHER THOMAS
(smiling warmly)
Michael, it's good to see you. How are you feeling?

MICHAEL
(returning the smile)
Better, Father. Much better. Thank you for coming.

They begin to walk together through the gardens.

FATHER THOMAS
I'm glad to hear it. You've been in my prayers.

MICHAEL
I appreciate that. These past few months... they've been challenging, but enlightening.

FATHER THOMAS
How so?

Michael pauses, looking out over the peaceful landscape.

MICHAEL
I've learned a lot about myself. About the power of guilt, and how our minds can twist reality when we're in pain.

FATHER THOMAS
And about forgiveness?

MICHAEL
(nodding)
Yes, especially that. Forgiving myself has been the hardest part.

They reach a bench and sit down.

FATHER THOMAS
You carried a heavy burden, even if it wasn't the one you thought. How do you feel about Sarah Thompson now?

Michael's expression turns somber.

MICHAEL
I still think about her every day. I know now that I wasn't responsible for her death, but... I feel connected to her somehow. Her story became intertwined with mine in a way I never expected.

FATHER THOMAS
And have you found a way to honor her memory?

MICHAEL
(smiling slightly)
I have, actually. I've started volunteering at a local youth center, working with kids who've lost parents to drunk driving accidents. It feels like... like I'm doing something positive out of all this.

Father Thomas nods approvingly.

FATHER THOMAS
That's wonderful, Michael. You've taken a painful experience and found a way to bring light from it.

MICHAEL
I couldn't have done it without support. You, the therapists here, even Detective Rodriguez... you all helped me face the truth and find a path forward.

FATHER THOMAS
Remember, Michael, that the strength to change was within you all along. You just needed help to find it.

Michael nods, his eyes misting slightly.

MICHAEL
I know I have a long road ahead. Rebuilding my life, making amends with my family... it won't be easy.

FATHER THOMAS
No, it won't. But you've already shown incredible courage and resilience. Have faith in yourself, and in God's plan for you.

MICHAEL
(smiling)
I will, Father. Thank you.

They stand, and Father Thomas places a comforting hand on Michael's shoulder.

FATHER THOMAS
Are you ready to go home?

MICHAEL
(taking a deep breath)
I am. It's time to start the next chapter.

As they walk towards the parking lot, we slowly pan up to the clear blue sky, a symbol of hope and new beginnings.

FADE TO BLACK.

THE END

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A serial killer is planning his new killing while mocking the incompetence of the police.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 4000 words.
response:
Here's a screenplay based on the given writing prompt and requirements:

INT. DIMLY LIT BASEMENT - NIGHT

A cramped, windowless room with concrete walls. Newspaper clippings and photographs cover one wall, illuminated by a single swinging light bulb. A tall, slender man in his late 30s, MARCUS, stands before the wall, studying the images intently.

Marcus runs his fingers along the edge of a newspaper headline that reads "SERIAL KILLER STRIKES AGAIN - POLICE BAFFLED." A cruel smile plays across his lips.

MARCUS
(to himself)
Oh, you poor, simple fools.

He turns away from the wall and moves to a workbench cluttered with various tools and implements. Marcus picks up a sharp hunting knife, examining its blade in the dim light.

MARCUS (CONT'D)
You have no idea what's coming next.

The basement door creaks open, and footsteps can be heard descending the stairs. DETECTIVE SARAH COLLINS, a determined woman in her early 40s, enters the room.

SARAH
Marcus? Are you down here?

Marcus quickly puts down the knife and turns to face Sarah, his demeanor instantly changing to that of a mild-mannered, slightly nervous man.

MARCUS
Oh, Sarah! I didn't hear you come in. What brings you by so late?

Sarah looks around the basement, her eyes narrowing as she takes in the newspaper clippings and photographs.

SARAH
I was hoping we could talk about the case. Mind if I take a look at your research?

MARCUS
(hesitantly)
Of course, be my guest. I've been collecting everything I can find on the killings. Trying to make sense of it all, you know?

Sarah approaches the wall, examining the articles and photos closely. Marcus watches her intently, his fingers twitching slightly.

SARAH
(pointing to a photo)
This victim... she was found just two blocks from here, wasn't she?

MARCUS
(nodding)
Yes, poor thing. It's terrifying to think it happened so close to home.

Sarah turns to face Marcus, her expression serious.

SARAH
That's actually why I'm here, Marcus. We've been going over the evidence again, and... well, there are some questions we need to ask you.

Marcus's eyes widen slightly, but he quickly composes himself.

MARCUS
Questions? About what?

SARAH
Your whereabouts on the nights of the murders, for starters. And we'd like to take a look around your property, if that's alright.

Marcus forces a nervous laugh.

MARCUS
Sarah, you can't be serious. You've known me for years. We've worked together on cases before. You don't actually think I could be involved in this, do you?

Sarah's expression softens slightly.

SARAH
I don't want to believe it, Marcus. But we have to follow every lead, no matter how unlikely it seems.

Marcus nods, his face a mask of understanding and cooperation.

MARCUS
Of course, I understand. You're just doing your job. What do you need from me?

SARAH
For now, just your cooperation. Can you walk me through your movements on the night of the last murder?

Marcus takes a deep breath, as if preparing to recall a difficult memory.

MARCUS
Let's see... That was last Tuesday, right? I was here most of the evening, working on my latest article about the killings. Around 9 PM, I went out for a walk to clear my head. The details of these cases... they can be overwhelming sometimes.

SARAH
(nodding)
Where did you go on your walk?

MARCUS
Just around the neighborhood. I was gone for maybe an hour. When I got back, I made some tea and went to bed early.

Sarah jots down some notes in a small notebook.

SARAH
And can anyone corroborate your story?

MARCUS
(shaking his head)
I'm afraid not. I didn't run into anyone I know, and I live alone, as you're aware.

Sarah looks up from her notebook, her eyes meeting Marcus's.

SARAH
Marcus, I have to ask... Why do you have all of this?

She gestures to the wall of clippings and photos.

MARCUS
(sighing)
I'm a crime journalist, Sarah. This is what I do. I collect information, try to piece together the puzzle. It helps me write my articles, and... well, I guess I hoped I might be able to help catch the killer.

Sarah nods slowly, her expression still skeptical.

SARAH
I see. Well, thank you for your cooperation, Marcus. We'll be in touch if we have any more questions.

As Sarah turns to leave, Marcus's expression darkens for a moment before he quickly composes himself.

MARCUS
Of course, anything I can do to help. Stay safe out there, Sarah.

Sarah pauses at the bottom of the stairs, turning back to Marcus.

SARAH
You too, Marcus. And... lock your doors. We still don't know who we're dealing with.

Marcus nods solemnly as Sarah ascends the stairs and exits the basement. As soon as the door closes, his demeanor changes completely. A wicked grin spreads across his face as he turns back to the workbench, picking up the hunting knife once again.

MARCUS
(to himself)
Oh, Sarah. If only you knew.

FADE TO BLACK.

INT. POLICE STATION - BULLPEN - DAY

The bustling interior of a busy police station. Phones ring, officers shuffle papers, and the air is thick with tension. Detective Sarah Collins sits at her desk, surrounded by case files and crime scene photos.

Her partner, DETECTIVE MIKE REYNOLDS, a gruff man in his 50s, approaches with two cups of coffee. He sets one down in front of Sarah.

MIKE
You look like you could use this. Rough night?

SARAH
(sighing)
Thanks, Mike. Yeah, you could say that. I can't shake this feeling that we're missing something obvious.

Mike pulls up a chair and sits across from Sarah.

MIKE
Talk to me. What's going on in that head of yours?

Sarah takes a sip of coffee and leans back in her chair.

SARAH
I went to see Marcus last night.

MIKE
(surprised)
Marcus? The crime journalist? Why?

SARAH
I don't know. Call it a hunch. There's something about him that's been nagging at me.

Mike leans forward, his interest piqued.

MIKE
What do you mean? Marcus has been helping us with this case from the beginning. Hell, his articles have probably brought in more leads than our own tip line.

SARAH
I know, I know. It's just... He knows so much about the case. Too much, sometimes. And last night, I saw his basement.

MIKE
(raising an eyebrow)
His basement?

SARAH
It was like a shrine to the murders, Mike. Newspaper clippings, photos, timelines... He says it's for his work, but it felt... off.

Mike leans back, considering Sarah's words.

MIKE
That does sound a bit creepy, but it's not exactly damning evidence. The guy's a crime journalist. It's his job to be obsessed with this stuff.

SARAH
(nodding)
I know. But there's more. He doesn't have an alibi for any of the murders. And get this - he lives just blocks away from where the last victim was found.

Mike's expression grows more serious.

MIKE
Okay, that's starting to sound like more than a coincidence. But Sarah, we've known Marcus for years. He's helped us solve cases before. Are you really suggesting he could be our guy?

Sarah runs a hand through her hair, frustration evident on her face.

SARAH
I don't know what I'm suggesting, Mike. It just feels like we're running out of options. This killer is always one step ahead of us, and I can't help but wonder if it's because he has inside knowledge.

Mike nods slowly, processing the information.

MIKE
Alright, let's say you're onto something here. What's our next move?

SARAH
We need to dig deeper into Marcus's background. Check his financials, his phone records, his internet history. And I want to get a warrant to search his house properly.

MIKE
(hesitant)
That's a big step, Sarah. If we're wrong about this, it could blow up in our faces. Not to mention, we'd be alienating one of our best sources of information on this case.

Sarah leans forward, her eyes intense.

SARAH
I know it's a risk, Mike. But we're running out of time. This killer isn't slowing down, and if we don't catch him soon, more people are going to die.

Mike holds Sarah's gaze for a moment, then nods.

MIKE
Alright, I'm with you. Let's start building our case for a warrant. But we need to be discreet about this. If Marcus is our guy, we can't tip him off that we're onto him.

SARAH
Agreed. We'll keep this between us for now.

As Sarah and Mike begin to discuss their plan, we FADE TO:

INT. MARCUS'S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT

Marcus sits in a comfortable armchair, laptop balanced on his knees. The room is dimly lit, with only the glow of the computer screen illuminating his face.

He types furiously, occasionally pausing to reference a notepad beside him. We see the headline of his article-in-progress: "POLICE STRUGGLE AS KILLER REMAINS AT LARGE."

Marcus leans back, a satisfied smirk on his face as he reads over what he's written.

MARCUS
(muttering to himself)
Oh, this is good. They're going to eat this up.

He continues typing, narrating to himself as he goes.

MARCUS (CONT'D)
"Despite the best efforts of law enforcement, the killer known as the 'Nightstalker' continues to elude capture. Sources close to the investigation report that the police are no closer to identifying a suspect than they were when the first body was discovered three months ago."

Marcus chuckles to himself, clearly enjoying the irony of his words.

MARCUS (CONT'D)
If only they knew how close they really are.

Suddenly, his cell phone rings. Marcus glances at the caller ID and his expression shifts to one of mild annoyance. He answers the call.

MARCUS
(into phone)
Sarah, to what do I owe the pleasure of another late-night call?

INTERCUT WITH:

INT. SARAH'S CAR - NIGHT

Sarah is driving, her phone on speaker as she navigates the dark streets.

SARAH
Sorry to bother you so late, Marcus. I was hoping we could meet. There are a few more questions I'd like to ask you about the case.

Marcus's eyes narrow slightly, but his voice remains friendly.

MARCUS
Of course, anything to help. Did you want to come by my place again?

SARAH
Actually, I was thinking we could meet somewhere more neutral. How about the diner on 5th Street? I could use a cup of coffee, and I'm sure you could too.

Marcus pauses for a moment, considering.

MARCUS
The diner? At this hour? Is everything alright, Sarah?

SARAH
(forcing a light tone)
Everything's fine. I just thought a change of scenery might help us look at things from a new angle. Plus, their pie is to die for.

Marcus's lips curl into a small, knowing smile.

MARCUS
Well, when you put it that way, how can I refuse? I'll meet you there in... say, 20 minutes?

SARAH
Perfect. See you soon, Marcus.

Sarah ends the call and takes a deep breath, her knuckles white as she grips the steering wheel.

BACK TO:

INT. MARCUS'S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT

Marcus sets down his phone, his expression thoughtful. He closes his laptop and stands, stretching.

MARCUS
(to himself)
Oh, Sarah. You're playing a dangerous game.

He walks to a nearby bookshelf and pulls out a thick volume. Opening it reveals a hollowed-out interior containing a small, sharp knife. Marcus removes the knife and slips it into his pocket.

MARCUS (CONT'D)
But two can play at that game.

Marcus grabs his coat and keys, then exits the house. As the door closes behind him, we FADE TO:

EXT. DINER - NIGHT

A neon sign flickers above a classic American diner. The parking lot is nearly empty, save for a few cars. Sarah's police-issue sedan pulls into a spot, and she kills the engine.

Sarah sits in her car for a moment, taking deep breaths to calm her nerves. She checks her gun, ensuring it's securely holstered, then exits the vehicle.

As she approaches the diner's entrance, another car pulls into the lot. Marcus steps out, offering a friendly wave to Sarah.

MARCUS
Fancy meeting you here, Detective.

Sarah forces a smile as Marcus joins her at the entrance.

SARAH
Thanks for coming, Marcus. I appreciate your willingness to help, even at this ungodly hour.

MARCUS
(smiling)
Well, as they say, evil never sleeps. Neither should those who hunt it, right?

Sarah's smile falters slightly at his choice of words, but she quickly recovers.

SARAH
Right. Shall we?

Marcus holds the door open for Sarah, and they enter the diner together.

INT. DINER - NIGHT

The diner is mostly empty, with only a couple of late-night patrons scattered about. A tired-looking waitress greets Sarah and Marcus as they enter.

WAITRESS
Sit anywhere you like, folks. I'll be with you in a minute.

Sarah leads Marcus to a booth near the back of the diner, away from the other customers. They sit across from each other, an air of tension between them despite their outwardly friendly demeanors.

MARCUS
So, Sarah, what burning questions couldn't wait until morning?

Before Sarah can answer, the waitress approaches with menus.

WAITRESS
Can I start you two off with some coffee?

SARAH
Yes, please. Black for me.

MARCUS
I'll have the same, thank you.

As the waitress leaves to fetch their coffee, Sarah leans forward, her voice low.

SARAH
Marcus, I'm going to be straight with you. We're looking into you as a potential suspect in the Nightstalker case.

Marcus's eyebrows shoot up in feigned surprise.

MARCUS
Me? Sarah, you can't be serious. We've been over this. I'm just a journalist trying to help catch a killer.

SARAH
I know how it sounds, Marcus. But we have to follow every lead, no matter how unlikely it seems. And right now, there are too many coincidences pointing in your direction for us to ignore.

The waitress returns with their coffee, interrupting the tense conversation. After she leaves, Marcus takes a sip of his coffee, his eyes never leaving Sarah's face.

MARCUS
What kind of coincidences are we talking about here, Detective?

SARAH
Your proximity to the crime scenes, for one. Your extensive knowledge of the case. The fact that you have no alibis for any of the nights in question.

Marcus sets down his coffee cup, leaning back in the booth with a sigh.

MARCUS
Sarah, I've explained all of this before. I live in the area where the killer is active. Of course I'm going to be near the crime scenes. As for my knowledge of the case, that's my job. I'm a crime journalist. I'm supposed to know these things.

SARAH
And the alibis?

MARCUS
(shrugging)
I live alone and work from home. It's not exactly conducive to having rock-solid alibis. But surely you don't think that's enough to make me a killer?

Sarah leans forward, her voice intense but quiet.

SARAH
No, it's not. But it's enough to make us look closer. Marcus, if you're innocent, you have nothing to worry about. We just need your full cooperation.

Marcus's expression darkens slightly, a flicker of something dangerous in his eyes.

MARCUS
And if I don't cooperate? What then, Sarah? Are you going to arrest me on suspicion of being too knowledgeable about the case I'm covering?

SARAH
(taken aback)
No one's talking about arrests, Marcus. We just want to clear you as a suspect so we can move on to more promising leads.

Marcus leans forward, mirroring Sarah's posture. His voice is low and intense.

MARCUS
But what if you can't clear me, Sarah? What if, despite your best efforts, the evidence keeps pointing in my direction? What then?

Sarah's hand instinctively moves closer to her holstered gun.

SARAH
Marcus, what are you saying?

Marcus's face suddenly breaks into a wide, disarming smile.

MARCUS
I'm saying, Detective, that you're barking up the wrong tree. But I understand. You're desperate for a break in the case, and I'm an easy target. I forgive you.

Sarah relaxes slightly, but her guard is still up.

SARAH
So you'll cooperate with our investigation?

MARCUS
(nodding)
Of course. I have nothing to hide. Search my house, check my records, do whatever you need to do. I want this killer caught as much as you do.

Sarah studies Marcus's face, trying to read his true intentions.

SARAH
Thank you, Marcus. I appreciate your understanding.

MARCUS
(smiling)
That's what friends are for, right? Now, how about that pie you mentioned? I hear it's to die for.

As Marcus flags down the waitress, Sarah can't shake the feeling that something is very, very wrong. We FADE TO:

EXT. DINER - PARKING LOT - NIGHT

Sarah and Marcus exit the diner, walking towards their respective cars. The tension between them is palpable, despite their casual conversation.

MARCUS
Well, that was certainly an interesting late-night snack. Who knew accusations of serial murder paired so well with apple pie?

SARAH
(dryly)
I'm glad you can find humor in the situation, Marcus.

They reach Sarah's car first, and she turns to face him.

SARAH (CONT'D)
Listen, I know this isn't easy. But I promise you, we're just doing our job. If you're innocent, you have nothing to worry about.

Marcus steps closer to Sarah, his voice low and intense.

MARCUS
And if I'm not innocent, Sarah? What then?

Sarah's hand moves to her gun, but before she can react, Marcus grabs her wrist, twisting it painfully.

MARCUS (CONT'D)
(whispering)
You should have trusted your instincts, Detective. They were right all along.

Sarah struggles against Marcus's grip, but he's surprisingly strong. With his free hand, he pulls out the small knife from his pocket.

SARAH
(through gritted teeth)
Marcus, don't do this. It's not too late to turn yourself in.

MARCUS
(laughing)
Turn myself in? Oh, Sarah. You still don't get it, do you? I've been right under your nose this whole time, feeding you just enough information to keep you chasing your own tail. And you all fell for it, hook, line, and sinker.

Sarah manages to break free of Marcus's grip and reaches for her gun, but Marcus is faster. He lunges forward with the knife, catching Sarah off guard.

SARAH
(gasping)
Mike... Mike knows. He'll figure it out.

MARCUS
(smirking)
Good old Mike. Always one step behind. By the time he puts it together, I'll be long gone.

As Marcus raises the knife for another strike, suddenly headlights illuminate the parking lot. A car pulls in, startling both Sarah and Marcus.

Taking advantage of the distraction, Sarah manages to draw her gun.

SARAH
(shouting)
Freeze! Drop the knife, Marcus!

Marcus hesitates for a moment, weighing his options. Then, with surprising speed, he turns and runs towards the back of the diner.

SARAH (CONT'D)
(into her radio)
This is Detective Collins! I need backup at the diner on 5th Street! Suspect is armed and dangerous!

Sarah takes off after Marcus, her gun drawn. As she rounds the corner of the diner, she sees Marcus disappearing into the darkness of an alley.

SARAH (CONT'D)
(to herself)
Not this time, you bastard.

She pursues him into the alley, the sound of sirens growing in the distance. We FADE TO:

EXT. ALLEYWAY - NIGHT

The narrow alley is dark and filled with obstacles - dumpsters, discarded boxes, and various debris. Sarah moves cautiously, her gun at the ready, scanning for any sign of Marcus.

SARAH
(calling out)
It's over, Marcus! There's nowhere left to run!

Suddenly, a figure darts out from behind a dumpster. Sarah whirls around, her finger on the trigger.

SARAH (CONT'D)
Stop right there!

The figure freezes, hands raised. It's not Marcus, but a homeless man, terrified and confused.

HOMELESS MAN
Don't shoot! I didn't do nothing!

Sarah lowers her gun slightly, frustrated.

SARAH
I'm sorry, sir. Did you see a man run through here? Tall, well-dressed?

The homeless man nods frantically, pointing further down the alley.

HOMELESS MAN
Yeah, yeah! He went that way, towards the old factory!

Sarah nods her thanks and continues down the alley, her senses on high alert. As she approaches the end of the alley, she sees the looming shape of an abandoned factory.

The factory door is slightly ajar. Sarah takes a deep breath, steeling herself for what's to come.

SARAH
(into her radio)
This is Collins. Suspect has entered the abandoned factory on Elm Street. Requesting immediate backup.

She pushes the door open slowly, wincing at the creaking sound it makes. As Sarah enters the factory, we FADE TO:

INT. ABANDONED FACTORY - NIGHT

The interior of the factory is a maze of old machinery, conveyor belts, and catwalks. Moonlight streams in through broken windows, casting eerie shadows throughout the space.

Sarah moves cautiously, her gun raised, eyes darting from shadow to shadow. Every sound - the creak of metal, the scurry of a rat - makes her tense.

SARAH
(calling out)
Marcus! We can end this peacefully! Just turn yourself in!

Her voice echoes through the empty factory, but there's no response. Sarah continues to move deeper into the building, checking behind every piece of machinery.

Suddenly, a noise from above catches her attention. Sarah looks up to see a figure moving along one of the catwalks.

SARAH (CONT'D)
(shouting)
BCPD! Freeze!

The figure breaks into a run, and Sarah pursues, racing up a nearby staircase to the catwalk level. As she reaches the top, she sees Marcus at the far end of the catwalk, trapped.

SARAH (CONT'D)
It's over, Marcus. There's nowhere left to go.

Marcus turns to face her, his expression a mix of anger and resignation.

MARCUS
You just couldn't leave well enough alone, could you, Sarah? We could have played this game for years.

SARAH
(moving closer, gun trained on Marcus)
This was never a game, Marcus. You killed innocent people.

MARCUS
(laughing bitterly)
Innocent? Please. They were nobodies. Pawns in a much larger story. My story.

SARAH
Drop the knife and put your hands where I can see them. Now!

Marcus looks down at the knife in his hand, then back at Sarah. A wicked grin spreads across his face.

MARCUS
You want to know the truth, Sarah? The real reason you could never catch me?

He takes a step closer, and Sarah tightens her grip on her gun.

SARAH
Don't move! I will shoot!

MARCUS
(ignoring her warning)
It's because deep down, you didn't want to. You all loved the mystery, the chase. I gave your lives meaning, purpose. Without me, what are you?

SARAH
Last warning, Marcus. Drop the knife!

Marcus takes another step forward, raising the knife.

MARCUS
You can't do it, Sarah. You can't end the game. Because if you do, you'll have nothing left.

In that moment, Sarah makes her decision. She fires two shots in rapid succession. Marcus staggers backward, a look of shock on his face. He stumbles, losing his balance on the catwalk.

Sarah rushes forward, trying to grab him, but it's too late. Marcus falls over the railing, plummeting to the factory floor below.

Sarah looks down at Marcus's motionless body, a mix of emotions playing across her face. In the distance, she can hear the sound of approaching sirens.

FADE TO BLACK.

INT. POLICE STATION - SARAH'S DESK - DAY

Sarah sits at her desk, staring at a closed case file. The label reads "NIGHTSTALKER - CASE CLOSED." Mike approaches, setting a cup of coffee in front of her.

MIKE
How you holding up, partner?

Sarah looks up, offering a weak smile.

SARAH
I'm okay. Just... processing, I guess.

Mike pulls up a chair, sitting across from her.

MIKE
You did what you had to do, Sarah. Marcus gave you no choice.

SARAH
(nodding)
I know. It's just... he was right about one thing.

MIKE
(raising an eyebrow)
What's that?

SARAH
This case... hunting him... it did give us purpose. Now that it's over, I can't help but feel a little lost.

Mike reaches across the desk, patting Sarah's hand.

MIKE
That's normal. But remember, there are always more bad guys out there. Our job isn't done just because we caught one killer.

Sarah nods, a determined look coming into her eyes.

SARAH
You're right. And next time, we'll catch them sooner.

MIKE
(smiling)
That's the spirit. Now, how about we go grab some real coffee? I hear there's a great diner on 5th Street.

Sarah laughs, standing up and grabbing her jacket.

SARAH
Sounds perfect. But this time, I'm choosing the booth.

As Sarah and Mike leave the station, we see the city stretching out before them - a landscape of potential crimes and mysteries waiting to be solved.

FADE TO BLACK.

THE END

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: Three girls are walking on the beach in the morning when they notice a body that has been washed up on the sand. Alarmed, they call the police immediately.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 4000 words.
response:
Here's a well-structured screenplay based on the given writing prompt:

EXT. BEACH - EARLY MORNING

The sun is just beginning to peek over the horizon, casting a soft golden glow across the sandy shore. Gentle waves lap at the coastline, and seagulls cry in the distance. Three teenage girls, EMILY (17), SARAH (16), and MELISSA (16), are walking along the water's edge, their bare feet sinking into the wet sand.

Emily, tall and athletic with long blonde hair, leads the group. Sarah, petite with curly red hair, walks in the middle, while Melissa, dark-skinned with braided hair, brings up the rear.

EMILY
(stretching her arms above her head)
I can't believe you guys actually got up this early for a beach walk.

SARAH
(yawning)
Yeah, well, don't get used to it. This is a one-time thing.

MELISSA
(laughing)
Speak for yourself. I love watching the sunrise.

The girls continue walking, chatting and laughing. Suddenly, Emily stops abruptly, causing Sarah to bump into her.

SARAH
(annoyed)
Hey, what's the big idea?

Emily doesn't respond. She's staring at something in the distance, her face pale.

EMILY
(voice trembling)
Guys... do you see that?

Sarah and Melissa follow Emily's gaze. About fifty yards ahead, there's a dark shape lying motionless on the sand.

MELISSA
(squinting)
What is that? Driftwood?

The girls slowly approach the object, their curiosity overcoming their apprehension. As they get closer, the shape becomes clearer.

SARAH
(gasping)
Oh my God... is that...?

EMILY
(nodding gravely)
It's a body.

The three girls stand frozen, staring at the lifeless form before them. It's a man, face-down in the sand, wearing tattered clothes. His skin is pale and bloated.

MELISSA
(voice shaking)
What do we do?

EMILY
(taking charge)
We need to call the police. Now.

Sarah fumbles in her pocket for her phone, her hands trembling as she dials 911.

SARAH
(into the phone)
Hello? We need help. We've found a body on the beach.

As Sarah talks to the dispatcher, Emily and Melissa move closer to examine the body.

EMILY
(whispering)
Do you think he drowned?

MELISSA
(shaking her head)
I don't know. Look at his clothes... they're all ripped up.

Emily notices something glinting in the sand near the man's hand.

EMILY
Wait, what's that?

She bends down to get a closer look.

EMILY (CONT'D)
It's... a watch. An expensive one, by the looks of it.

Melissa grabs Emily's arm, pulling her back.

MELISSA
Don't touch anything! We don't want to contaminate the scene.

Sarah rejoins them, putting her phone away.

SARAH
The police are on their way. They said we should stay here and not touch anything.

The girls huddle together, watching the body and the surrounding area.

MELISSA
(voice low)
Do you think... do you think he was murdered?

EMILY
(shrugging)
I don't know. Maybe he just drowned and got washed up here.

SARAH
(skeptically)
With an expensive watch? Seems fishy to me.

The sound of sirens in the distance catches their attention.

EMILY
That must be the police.

As the sirens grow louder, the girls see two police cars and an ambulance approaching on the beach access road.

CUT TO:

EXT. BEACH - LATER THAT MORNING

The beach is now a hive of activity. Police officers mill about, setting up a perimeter with yellow crime scene tape. A forensics team in white suits carefully examines the body and the surrounding area.

Emily, Sarah, and Melissa sit on a nearby sand dune, wrapped in shock blankets. They watch as DETECTIVE HARRIS (40s), a stern-looking woman with short gray hair, approaches them.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
(addressing the girls)
I'm Detective Harris. I understand you're the ones who found the body?

The girls nod silently.

DETECTIVE HARRIS (CONT'D)
I know this must be difficult for you, but I need to ask you a few questions. Can you tell me exactly what happened?

EMILY
(taking a deep breath)
We were just taking a morning walk on the beach. We do it sometimes, you know? And then... we saw him.

SARAH
(interrupting)
At first, we thought it was just driftwood or something. But when we got closer...

MELISSA
We realized it was a person. We called 911 right away.

Detective Harris nods, jotting down notes in a small notebook.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Did you notice anything unusual about the body or the surrounding area?

The girls exchange glances.

EMILY
(hesitantly)
Well... there was a watch.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
(raising an eyebrow)
A watch?

EMILY
Yeah, near his hand. It looked expensive.

SARAH
(adding)
And his clothes were all torn up. It didn't look like he just drowned.

Detective Harris's expression darkens slightly.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
I see. Did any of you touch the body or move anything around it?

MELISSA
(shaking her head vigorously)
No, ma'am. We made sure not to touch anything.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Good. That's very important.

She closes her notebook and gives the girls a sympathetic look.

DETECTIVE HARRIS (CONT'D)
Thank you for your help. We'll need to take formal statements from each of you down at the station. Is there someone we can call to come pick you up?

The girls nod, still looking shaken.

CUT TO:

INT. POLICE STATION - INTERVIEW ROOM - DAY

Emily sits alone at a table in a small, stark room. Detective Harris enters, carrying a file folder.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Thank you for coming in, Emily. I just have a few more questions for you.

EMILY
(nodding)
Okay.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Can you walk me through exactly what you saw when you first spotted the body?

EMILY
(closing her eyes, recalling)
We were just walking along the water. I was in front, and something caught my eye. At first, I thought it was trash or driftwood. But as we got closer, I could see it was a person.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
And what did you do then?

EMILY
We got closer to make sure. That's when we saw... him. He was face-down in the sand. His clothes were all torn up, and his skin looked... wrong. Pale and puffy.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
(nodding)
That's consistent with a drowning victim. Now, you mentioned a watch earlier. Can you describe it in more detail?

EMILY
(frowning in concentration)
It was gold, I think. Or maybe silver? It was hard to tell with the sand. But it looked expensive. Like something you'd see in a fancy jewelry store window.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Did you notice any markings on it? A brand name, perhaps?

EMILY
(shaking her head)
No, I didn't get that close. I just saw it glinting in the sand near his hand.

Detective Harris makes a note in her file.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Alright. Now, I need to ask you something important, Emily. Did you or your friends take anything from the scene? Even something small?

EMILY
(looking shocked)
What? No! Of course not. We didn't touch anything.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
(leaning forward)
Are you sure? Sometimes people might take a small souvenir without thinking. It's important that you tell me the truth.

EMILY
(getting upset)
I am telling you the truth! We didn't take anything. We're not thieves!

DETECTIVE HARRIS
(holding up a hand)
Okay, okay. I believe you. I just had to ask.

Emily slumps back in her chair, looking drained.

EMILY
Can I go home now?

DETECTIVE HARRIS
(nodding)
Yes, you can go. But we might need to contact you again if we have any more questions. Thank you for your help, Emily.

CUT TO:

EXT. POLICE STATION - DAY

Emily exits the station, looking tired and overwhelmed. Sarah and Melissa are waiting for her on a bench outside.

SARAH
(jumping up)
Emily! Are you okay?

EMILY
(nodding wearily)
Yeah, I'm fine. Just tired.

MELISSA
What did they ask you?

EMILY
Pretty much the same stuff as before. But...

She hesitates, looking troubled.

SARAH
(concerned)
But what?

EMILY
They asked if we took anything from the scene. Like, as a souvenir or something.

MELISSA
(indignant)
What? That's crazy!

SARAH
(quieter)
Is it, though? I mean, we did see that watch...

EMILY
(firmly)
We didn't take anything. End of story.

The girls fall silent, each lost in their own thoughts.

MELISSA
(after a moment)
Do you think they know who he is yet?

EMILY
(shrugging)
They didn't say. But I bet that watch will help them figure it out.

SARAH
(shivering)
This is all so creepy. I can't stop thinking about him lying there on the sand.

EMILY
(putting an arm around Sarah)
I know. Me neither.

MELISSA
Maybe we should do something to take our minds off it. Want to go get ice cream or something?

SARAH
(managing a small smile)
Yeah, that sounds good.

As the girls start to walk away, Emily glances back at the police station, a troubled look on her face.

FADE TO:

EXT. BEACH - NIGHT

The beach is deserted and dark, lit only by the moon and stars. Waves crash ominously in the background. A figure in a hooded sweatshirt walks along the shoreline, scanning the sand intently.

Suddenly, the figure stops and bends down, picking something up. It's the expensive watch, glinting in the moonlight. The figure pockets the watch and quickly walks away.

CUT TO:

INT. EMILY'S BEDROOM - NIGHT

Emily tosses and turns in her bed, clearly having a nightmare. In her dream, she sees flashes of the dead body on the beach, the glinting watch, and Detective Harris's accusatory face.

She wakes up with a gasp, sitting bolt upright in bed. Sweat beads on her forehead as she tries to calm her breathing.

EMILY
(whispering to herself)
It's okay. It's just a dream.

She reaches for her phone on the nightstand and sees a text from Sarah.

CLOSE ON: Phone screen

Sarah: Can't sleep. Keep thinking about what happened. You up?

Emily types back quickly.

Emily: Yeah, just woke up from a nightmare. This whole thing is freaking me out.

Sarah: Same. Want to video chat?

Emily: Sure.

Emily initiates a video call. Sarah's face appears on the screen, looking tired and worried.

SARAH
(whispering)
Hey. You look as bad as I feel.

EMILY
(managing a weak smile)
Thanks. You're no supermodel yourself right now.

SARAH
I keep replaying it in my head. Finding him there...

EMILY
(nodding)
Me too. And that detective asking if we took anything...

SARAH
(hesitating)
About that... Emily, I need to tell you something.

Emily's face grows serious.

EMILY
What is it?

SARAH
(looking guilty)
I... I went back to the beach tonight.

EMILY
(shocked)
What? Why?

SARAH
I don't know. I couldn't stop thinking about that watch. I thought maybe...

EMILY
(interrupting)
Sarah, tell me you didn't.

SARAH
(quickly)
No! I didn't take it. It wasn't even there anymore. But... I saw someone else.

EMILY
What do you mean?

SARAH
There was someone on the beach, right where we found the body. They were looking for something.

EMILY
(alarmed)
Did they see you?

SARAH
(shaking her head)
No, I hid behind some rocks. But I saw them pick something up. I think it was the watch.

EMILY
(running a hand through her hair)
This is bad, Sarah. Really bad. We need to tell the police.

SARAH
(panicking)
We can't! They'll want to know why I was there in the first place. They'll think I took it!

EMILY
But if we don't tell them, and they find out later...

Their conversation is interrupted by another incoming call. It's Melissa.

EMILY (CONT'D)
It's Melissa. Should we tell her?

SARAH
(hesitating)
I don't know...

Emily answers the call, adding Melissa to their chat.

MELISSA
(looking worried)
Hey guys. I couldn't sleep. Have you seen the news?

EMILY
(frowning)
What news?

MELISSA
They've identified the body. It's all over the local news sites.

Sarah and Emily exchange alarmed looks.

SARAH
Who is it?

MELISSA
Some big-shot lawyer from the city. Richard Hartley. They're saying he was murdered.

EMILY
(shocked)
Murdered? Are they sure?

MELISSA
(nodding)
Yeah. The article says he was stabbed multiple times before being dumped in the ocean.

SARAH
(voice shaking)
Oh my God...

EMILY
(to Melissa)
Does it say anything about... evidence? Like, did they find anything on the body?

MELISSA
(looking confused)
No, nothing specific. Why?

Emily and Sarah exchange another significant look.

EMILY
No reason. Just curious.

MELISSA
(yawning)
Well, I'm gonna try to get some sleep. See you guys tomorrow?

EMILY
(distracted)
Yeah, sure. Goodnight.

As soon as Melissa disconnects, Sarah starts to panic.

SARAH
Emily, what are we going to do? If that watch belonged to the victim...

EMILY
(firmly)
Calm down. We don't know for sure that's what it was.

SARAH
But if it was, and someone took it, that's like... tampering with evidence or something, right?

EMILY
(sighing)
Probably. Look, we need to think this through carefully. Let's meet up tomorrow and figure out what to do.

SARAH
(nodding)
Okay. Try to get some sleep.

EMILY
You too. And Sarah?

SARAH
Yeah?

EMILY
Don't go back to the beach. Promise me.

SARAH
(hesitating)
I promise.

They end the call. Emily flops back onto her bed, staring at the ceiling, her mind racing.

FADE TO:

EXT. BEACH BOARDWALK - NEXT DAY

Emily, Sarah, and Melissa sit on a bench overlooking the beach. Police tape still cordons off the area where they found the body. A few curious onlookers mill about, trying to get a glimpse of the crime scene.

MELISSA
(shaking her head)
I still can't believe it. A real murder, right here in our town.

SARAH
(nervously)
Yeah, it's crazy.

Emily notices Sarah's discomfort and changes the subject.

EMILY
So, what do you guys want to do today? We could go to the mall or something.

MELISSA
(enthusiastically)
Oh, good idea! I need to get a new swimsuit anyway.

As they stand up to leave, a familiar voice calls out to them.

DETECTIVE HARRIS (O.S.)
Girls! Can I have a word?

They turn to see Detective Harris approaching, looking serious.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
I'm glad I caught you. We have some new information about the case, and I need to ask you a few more questions.

The girls exchange nervous glances.

EMILY
(trying to sound casual)
Sure, what do you need to know?

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Let's go somewhere more private.

She leads them to a nearby picnic area, away from the crowds.

DETECTIVE HARRIS (CONT'D)
We've identified the victim as Richard Hartley, a prominent lawyer from the city. Does that name mean anything to any of you?

The girls shake their heads.

DETECTIVE HARRIS (CONT'D)
Alright. Now, about that watch you mentioned. We believe it may have belonged to Mr. Hartley. It's a very distinctive piece - a limited edition Rolex. We haven't been able to locate it.

Sarah shifts uncomfortably, avoiding eye contact.

DETECTIVE HARRIS (CONT'D)
(noticing Sarah's discomfort)
Is there something you want to tell me?

SARAH
(hesitating)
I...

Emily jumps in quickly.

EMILY
We're just upset about the whole thing, Detective. It's a lot to process.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
(skeptically)
I see. Well, if any of you remember anything else, anything at all, please don't hesitate to contact me.

She hands them each her business card.

DETECTIVE HARRIS (CONT'D)
Even the smallest detail could be important.

As Detective Harris walks away, Melissa turns to her friends, looking confused.

MELISSA
What was that all about? Sarah, you looked like you were about to say something.

SARAH
(panicking)
I... I can't do this. I have to tell them.

EMILY
(grabbing Sarah's arm)
Wait! Let's talk about this first.

MELISSA
(frustrated)
Talk about what? What's going on?

Emily looks around to make sure no one is listening.

EMILY
(lowering her voice)
Sarah went back to the beach last night.

MELISSA
(shocked)
What? Why?

SARAH
(on the verge of tears)
I don't know! I just... I couldn't stop thinking about that watch. But when I got there, someone else was there. They took it.

MELISSA
(incredulous)
Are you serious? Why didn't you tell me?

EMILY
We were going to. We just found out ourselves last night.

MELISSA
So what do we do now?

EMILY
(sighing)
I think we need to tell Detective Harris everything.

SARAH
(panicking)
But they'll think I took it!

EMILY
(firmly)
They won't. We'll explain everything. It's better to come clean now than have them find out later.

MELISSA
Emily's right. We need to tell the truth.

Sarah nods reluctantly, wiping away tears.

SARAH
Okay. Let's do it.

The girls walk back towards the police tape, where Detective Harris is talking to another officer.

EMILY
(calling out)
Detective Harris? We need to talk to you.

Detective Harris turns, looking surprised.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Yes? What is it?

EMILY
(taking a deep breath)
It's about the watch. There's something you need to know.

FADE TO:

INT. POLICE STATION - INTERVIEW ROOM - LATER

Sarah sits across from Detective Harris, looking nervous. Emily and Melissa sit on either side of her for support.

SARAH
(voice shaking)
I'm sorry I didn't say anything before. I was scared.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
(leaning forward)
It's okay, Sarah. Just tell me exactly what you saw.

SARAH
I went back to the beach last night. I couldn't sleep, and I kept thinking about the watch. I thought maybe... I don't know what I thought.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Did you take the watch, Sarah?

SARAH
(shaking her head vigorously)
No! I swear I didn't. But when I got there, someone else was there. They were searching the sand where we found the body.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
(interested)
Can you describe this person?

SARAH
They were wearing a dark hoodie. I couldn't see their face. But I saw them pick something up. I think it was the watch.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Did you see where this person went?

SARAH
(shaking her head)
No, I was hiding. I was too scared to follow them.

Detective Harris nods, jotting down notes.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Thank you for coming forward with this information, Sarah. It's very helpful.

EMILY
(speaking up)
We're sorry we didn't say anything sooner. We were just scared and confused.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
(smiling slightly)
I understand. You girls have been through a lot. But in the future, always remember that it's best to be honest with the police from the start.

The girls nod, looking relieved.

DETECTIVE HARRIS (CONT'D)
Now, I'm going to need you to work with a sketch artist to try and get a description of the person you saw, Sarah. Even if you didn't see their face, any details could be helpful.

SARAH
(nodding)
Okay, I'll try my best.

DETECTIVE HARRIS
Good. And girls? Thank you for doing the right thing.

As they leave the interview room, the girls feel a weight lift off their shoulders.

MELISSA
(sighing)
Well, that wasn't so bad.

EMILY
(putting an arm around Sarah)
See? I told you it would be okay.

SARAH
(managing a small smile)
Yeah, you were right. Thanks for being there for me, guys.

As they walk out of the police station, they see a crowd of reporters gathered outside.

EMILY
(groaning)
Great. Just what we need.

MELISSA
(determinedly)
Come on, let's go out the back way.

The girls sneak out through a side door, avoiding the media frenzy.

FADE TO:

EXT. BEACH - SUNSET - ONE WEEK LATER

Emily, Sarah, and Melissa sit on the sand, watching the sun sink into the ocean. The police tape is gone, and the beach looks peaceful once again.

MELISSA
I can't believe it's only been a week. It feels like forever ago.

SARAH
I know. So much has happened.

EMILY
(curiously)
Have you guys seen the news? They arrested someone for Mr. Hartley's murder.

MELISSA
(surprised)
Really? Who?

EMILY
His business partner. Apparently, they were involved in some shady deals, and Mr. Hartley was going to turn him in.

SARAH
(shaking her head)
That's awful. And to think, we were right here when they dumped his body.

MELISSA
(shuddering)
